author: Shrabani Basu
title: From pacifist to spy: WWII's surprising secret agent

authortitle: Rick Doblin: The future of psychedelic-assisted psychotherapy
author: Rick Doblin
title: The future of psychedelic-assisted psychotherapy

authortitle: Michael Tubbs: The political power of being a good neighbor
author: Michael Tubbs
title: The political power of being a good neighbor

authortitle: Erika Hamden: What it takes to launch a telescope
author: Erika Hamden
title: What it takes to launch a telescope

authortitle: Suchitra Krishnan-Sarin: What you should know about vaping and e-cigarettes
author: Suchitra Krishnan-Sarin
title: What you should know about vaping and e-cigarettes

authortitle: Romain Lacombe: A personal air-quality tracker that lets you know what you're breathing
author: Romain Lacombe
title: A personal air-quality tracker that lets you know what you're breathing

authortitle: César Hidalgo: A bold idea to replace politicians
author: César Hidalgo
title: A bold idea to replace politicians

authortitle: Tim Harford: A powerful way to unleash your natural creativity
author: Tim Harford
title: A powerful way to unleash your natural creativity

authortitle: Shohini Ghose: A beginner's guide to quantum computing
author: Shohini Ghose
title: A beginner's guide to quantum computing

authortitle: Douglas Rushkoff: How to be "Team Human" in the digital future
author: Douglas Rushkoff
title: How to be "Team Human" in the digital future

authortitle: Sebastien de Halleux: How a fleet of wind-powered drones is changing our understanding of the ocean
author: Sebastien de Halleux
title: How a fleet of wind-powered drones is changing our understanding of the ocean

authortitle: Chip Conley: What baby boomers can learn from millennials at work -- and vice versa
author: Chip Conley
title: What baby boomers can learn from millennials at work -- and vice versa

authortitle: Fabio Pacucci: Could the Earth be swallowed by a black hole?
author: Fabio Pacucci
title: Could the Earth be swallowed by a black hole?

authortitle: Heba Shaheed: Is it bad to hold your pee?
author: Heba Shaheed
title: Is it bad to hold your pee?

authortitle: Leticia Gasca: Don't fail fast -- fail mindfully
author: Leticia Gasca
title: Don't fail fast -- fail mindfully

authortitle: Stephen Webb: Where are all the aliens?
author: Stephen Webb
title: Where are all the aliens?

authortitle: Lindsay Malloy: Why teens confess to crimes they didn't commit
author: Lindsay Malloy
title: Why teens confess to crimes they didn't commit

authortitle: Sam Rodriques: What we'll learn about the brain in the next century
author: Sam Rodriques
title: What we'll learn about the brain in the next century

authortitle: Emily Levine: How I made friends with reality
author: Emily Levine
title: How I made friends with reality

authortitle: Gwynne Shotwell: SpaceX's plan to fly you across the globe in 30 minutes
author: Gwynne Shotwell
title: SpaceX's plan to fly you across the globe in 30 minutes

authortitle: Simone Bianco and Tom Zimmerman: The wonderful world of life in a drop of water
author: Simone Bianco and Tom Zimmerman
title: The wonderful world of life in a drop of water
description: "Hold your breath," says inventor Tom Zimmerman. "This is the world without plankton." These tiny organisms produce two-thirds of our planet's oxygen -- without them, life as we know it wouldn't exist. In this talk and tech demo, Zimmerman and cell engineer Simone Bianco hook up a 3D microscope to a drop of water and take you scuba diving with plankton. Learn more about these mesmerizing creatures and get inspired to protect them against ongoing threats from climate change.

authortitle: Nina Dølvik Brochmann and Ellen Støkken Dahl: The virginity fraud
author: Nina Dølvik Brochmann and Ellen Støkken Dahl
title: The virginity fraud
description: The hymen is still the most misunderstood part of the female body. Nina Dølvik Brochmann and Ellen Støkken Dahl share their mission to empower young people through better sex education, debunking the popular (and harmful) myths we're told about female virginity and the hymen.

authortitle: Gianluca Ambrosetti: A local, sustainable solution to the energy crisis
author: Gianluca Ambrosetti
title: A local, sustainable solution to the energy crisis

authortitle: Susan David: The gift and power of emotional courage
author: Susan David
title: The gift and power of emotional courage
description: Psychologist Susan David shares how the way we deal with our emotions shapes everything that matters: our actions, careers, relationships, health and happiness. In this deeply moving, humorous and potentially life-changing talk, she challenges a culture that prizes positivity over emotional truth and discusses the powerful strategies of emotional agility. A talk to share.

authortitle: Stewart Brand and Chris Anderson: Mammoths resurrected, geoengineering and other thoughts from a futurist
author: Stewart Brand and Chris Anderson
title: Mammoths resurrected, geoengineering and other thoughts from a futurist
description: Stewart Brand is a futurist, counterculturist and visionary with a very wide-ranging mind. In conversation with TED Curator Chris Anderson, Brand discusses ... just about everything: human nature, bringing back the wooly mammoth, geoengineering, rewilding and science as organized skepticism -- plus the story of an acid trip on a San Francisco rooftop in the '60s that sparked a perspective-shifting idea. "The story we're told is that we're the next meteor," Brand says, but "things are capable of getting better."

authortitle: WOLF: A marriage of opposites: Krump meets Mozart
author: WOLF
title: A marriage of opposites: Krump meets Mozart

authortitle: David Dunning: Why incompetent people think they're amazing
author: David Dunning
title: Why incompetent people think they're amazing

authortitle: Sara Menker: A global food crisis may be less than a decade away
author: Sara Menker
title: A global food crisis may be less than a decade away
description: Sara Menker quit a career in commodities trading to figure out how the global value chain of agriculture works. Her discoveries have led to some startling predictions: "We could have a tipping point in global food and agriculture if surging demand surpasses the agricultural system's structural capacity to produce food," she says. "People could starve and governments may fall." Menker's models predict that this scenario could happen in a decade -- that the world could be short 214 trillion calories per year by 2027. She offers a vision of this impossible world as well as some steps we can take today to avoid it.

authortitle: Tomás Saraceno: Would you live in a floating city in the sky?
author: Tomás Saraceno
title: Would you live in a floating city in the sky?
description: In a mind-bending talk that blurs the line between science and art, Tomás Saraceno exhibits a series of air-inspired sculptures and installations designed to usher in a new era of sustainability, the "Aerocene." From giant, cloud-like playgrounds suspended 22 meters in the air to a balloon sculpture that travels the world without burning a single drop of fossil fuel, Saraceno's work invites us to explore the bounds of our fragile human and terrestrial ecosystems. (In Spanish with English subtitles.)

authortitle: Kristen Marhaver: Why I still have hope for coral reefs
author: Kristen Marhaver
title: Why I still have hope for coral reefs
description: Corals in the Pacific Ocean have been dying at an alarming rate, particularly from bleaching brought on by increased water temperatures. But it's not too late to act, says TED Fellow Kristen Marhaver. She points to the Caribbean -- given time, stable temperatures and strong protection, corals there have shown the ability to survive and recover from trauma. Marhaver reminds us why we need to keep working to protect the precious corals we have left. "Corals have always been playing the long game," she says, "and now so are we."

authortitle: Michael Bierut: How to design a library that makes kids want to read
author: Michael Bierut
title: How to design a library that makes kids want to read

authortitle: Kenny Coogan: Why are sloths so slow?
author: Kenny Coogan
title: Why are sloths so slow?

authortitle: Thomas Boothby: Meet the tardigrade, the toughest animal on Earth
author: Thomas Boothby
title: Meet the tardigrade, the toughest animal on Earth

authortitle: Peter Weinstock: Lifelike simulations that make real-life surgery safer
author: Peter Weinstock
title: Lifelike simulations that make real-life surgery safer
description: Critical care doctor Peter Weinstock shows how surgical teams are using a blend of Hollywood special effects and 3D printing to create amazingly lifelike reproductions of real patients -- so they can practice risky surgeries ahead of time. Think: "Operate twice, cut once." Glimpse the future of surgery in this forward-thinking talk.

authortitle: Helen M. Farrell: What is bipolar disorder?
author: Helen M. Farrell
title: What is bipolar disorder?

authortitle: Jeff Speck: 4 ways to make a city more walkable
author: Jeff Speck
title: 4 ways to make a city more walkable
description: Freedom from cars, freedom from sprawl, freedom to walk your city! City planner Jeff Speck shares his "general theory of walkability" -- four planning principles to transform sprawling cities of six-lane highways and 600-foot blocks into safe, walkable oases full of bike lanes and tree-lined streets.

authortitle: Chinaka Hodge: What will you tell your daughters about 2016?
author: Chinaka Hodge
title: What will you tell your daughters about 2016?
description: With words like shards of glass, Chinaka Hodge cuts open 2016 and lets 12 months of violence, grief, fear, shame, courage and hope spill out in this original poem about a year none of us will soon forget.

authortitle: Nina Klietsch: Why do airlines sell too many tickets?
author: Nina Klietsch
title: Why do airlines sell too many tickets?

authortitle: Suzanne Barakat: Islamophobia killed my brother. Let's end the hate
author: Suzanne Barakat
title: Islamophobia killed my brother. Let's end the hate
description: On February 10, 2015, Suzanne Barakat's brother Deah, her sister-in-law Yusor and Yusor's sister Razan were murdered by their neighbor in Chapel Hill, North Carolina. The perpetrator's story, that he killed them over a traffic dispute, went unquestioned by the media and police until Barakat spoke out at a press conference, calling the murders what they really were: hate crimes. As she reflects on how she and her family reclaimed control of their narrative, Barakat calls on us to speak up when we witness hateful bigotry and express our allyship with those who face discrimination.

authortitle: Halla Tómasdóttir: It's time for women to run for office
author: Halla Tómasdóttir
title: It's time for women to run for office
description: With warmth and wit, Halla Tómasdóttir shares how she overcame media bias, changed the tone of the political debate and surprised her entire nation when she ran for president of Iceland -- inspiring the next generation of leaders along the way. "What we see, we can be," she says. "It matters that women run."

authortitle: John McWhorter: 4 reasons to learn a new language
author: John McWhorter
title: 4 reasons to learn a new language
description: English is fast becoming the world's universal language, and instant translation technology is improving every year. So why bother learning a foreign language? Linguist and Columbia professor John McWhorter shares four alluring benefits of learning an unfamiliar tongue.

authortitle: Rainn Wilson: Ideas worth dating
author: Rainn Wilson
title: Ideas worth dating
description: Being alone takes its toll. Feel like it's time to make a real connection? Third-wheel with Rainn Wilson (star of "The Office") as he dates some of the best ideas on TED.com and discover your perfect "idea mate" along the way.

authortitle: Vanessa Ruiz: The spellbinding art of human anatomy
author: Vanessa Ruiz
title: The spellbinding art of human anatomy
description: Vanessa Ruiz takes us on an illustrated journey of human anatomical art over the centuries, sharing captivating images that bring this visual science -- and the contemporary artists inspired by it -- to life. "Anatomical art has the power to reach far beyond the pages of a medical textbook," she says, "connecting our innermost selves with our bodies through art."

authortitle: Don Tapscott: How the blockchain is changing money and business
author: Don Tapscott
title: How the blockchain is changing money and business
description: What is the blockchain? If you don't know, you should; if you do, chances are you still need some clarification on how it actually works. Don Tapscott is here to help, demystifying this world-changing, trust-building technology which, he says, represents nothing less than the second generation of the internet and holds the potential to transform money, business, government and society.

authortitle: Emma Bryce: How to use a semicolon
author: Emma Bryce
title: How to use a semicolon

authortitle: Alexander Betts: Why Brexit happened -- and what to do next
author: Alexander Betts
title: Why Brexit happened -- and what to do next
description: We are embarrassingly unaware of how divided our societies are, and Brexit grew out of a deep, unexamined divide between those that fear globalization and those that embrace it, says social scientist Alexander Betts. How do we now address that fear as well as growing disillusionment with the political establishment, while refusing to give in to xenophobia and nationalism? Join Betts as he discusses four post-Brexit steps toward a more inclusive world.

authortitle: Joseph Ravenell: How barbershops can keep men healthy
author: Joseph Ravenell
title: How barbershops can keep men healthy
description: The barbershop can be a safe haven for black men, a place for honest conversation and trust -- and, as physician Joseph Ravenell suggests, a good place to bring up tough topics about health. He's turning the barbershop into a place to talk about medical problems that statistically affect black men more often and more seriously, like high blood pressure. It's a new approach to problem solving with broad applications. "What is your barbershop?" he asks. "Where is that place for you where people affected by a unique problem can meet a unique solution?"

authortitle: Zaria Forman: Drawings that show the beauty and fragility of Earth
author: Zaria Forman
title: Drawings that show the beauty and fragility of Earth
description: Zaria Forman's large-scale compositions of melting glaciers, icebergs floating in glassy water and waves cresting with foam explore moments of transition, turbulence and tranquility. Join her as she discusses the meditative process of artistic creation and the motivation behind her work. "My drawings celebrate the beauty of what we all stand to lose," she says. "I hope they can serve as records of sublime landscapes in flux."

authortitle: Astro Teller: The unexpected benefit of celebrating failure
author: Astro Teller
title: The unexpected benefit of celebrating failure
description: "Great dreams aren't just visions," says Astro Teller, "They're visions coupled to strategies for making them real." The head of X (formerly Google X), Teller takes us inside the "moonshot factory," as it's called, where his team seeks to solve the world's biggest problems through experimental projects like balloon-powered Internet and wind turbines that sail through the air. Find out X's secret to creating an organization where people feel comfortable working on big, risky projects and exploring audacious ideas.

authortitle: Paula Hammond: A new superweapon in the fight against cancer
author: Paula Hammond
title: A new superweapon in the fight against cancer
description: Cancer is a very clever, adaptable disease. To defeat it, says medical researcher and educator Paula Hammond, we need a new and powerful mode of attack. With her colleagues at MIT, Hammond engineered a nanoparticle one-hundredth the size of a human hair that can treat the most aggressive, drug-resistant cancers. Learn more about this molecular superweapon and join Hammond's quest to fight a disease that affects us all.

authortitle: Reshma Saujani: Teach girls bravery, not perfection
author: Reshma Saujani
title: Teach girls bravery, not perfection
description: We're raising our girls to be perfect, and we're raising our boys to be brave, says Reshma Saujani, the founder of Girls Who Code. Saujani has taken up the charge to socialize young girls to take risks and learn to program -- two skills they need to move society forward. To truly innovate, we cannot leave behind half of our population, she says. "I need each of you to tell every young woman you know to be comfortable with imperfection."

authortitle: Travis Kalanick: Uber's plan to get more people into fewer cars
author: Travis Kalanick
title: Uber's plan to get more people into fewer cars
description: Uber didn't start out with grand ambitions to cut congestion and pollution. But as the company took off, co-founder Travis Kalanick wondered if there was a way to get people using Uber along the same routes to share rides, reducing costs and carbon footprint along the way. The result: uberPOOL, the company's carpooling service, which in its first eight months took 7.9 million miles off the roads and 1,400 metric tons of carbon dioxide out of the air in Los Angeles. Now, Kalanick says carpooling could work for commuters in the suburbs, too. "With the technology in our pockets today, and a little smart regulation," he says, "we can turn every car into a shared car, and we can reclaim our cities starting today."

authortitle: Yanis Varoufakis: Capitalism will eat democracy -- unless we speak up
author: Yanis Varoufakis
title: Capitalism will eat democracy -- unless we speak up
description: Have you wondered why politicians aren't what they used to be, why governments seem unable to solve real problems? Economist Yanis Varoufakis, the former Minister of Finance for Greece, says that it's because you can be in politics today but not be in power -- because real power now belongs to those who control the economy. He believes that the mega-rich and corporations are cannibalizing the political sphere, causing financial crisis. In this talk, hear his dream for a world in which capital and labor no longer struggle against each other, "one that is simultaneously libertarian, Marxist and Keynesian."

authortitle: Elizabeth Lev: The unheard story of the Sistine Chapel
author: Elizabeth Lev
title: The unheard story of the Sistine Chapel
description: The Sistine Chapel is one of the most iconic buildings on earth -- but there's a lot you probably don't know about it. In this tour-de-force talk, art historian Elizabeth Lev guides us across the famous building's ceiling and Michelangelo's vital depiction of traditional stories, showing how the painter reached beyond the religious iconography of the time to chart new artistic waters. Five hundred years after the artist painted it, says Lev, the Sistine Chapel forces us to look around as if it were a mirror and ask, "Who am I, and what role do I play in this great theater of life?"

authortitle: Dan Van der Vieren: Can you solve "Einstein's Riddle"?
author: Dan Van der Vieren
title: Can you solve "Einstein's Riddle"?

authortitle: : Year In Ideas 2015
title: Year In Ideas 2015

authortitle: Scott Szwast: The global business next door
author: Scott Szwast
title: The global business next door

authortitle: Peter Harris: Taking trash talk to a whole new level
author: Peter Harris
title: Taking trash talk to a whole new level

authortitle: Noah Tavlin: What "Orwellian" really means
author: Noah Tavlin
title: What "Orwellian" really means

authortitle: Martin Pistorius: How my mind came back to life — and no one knew
author: Martin Pistorius
title: How my mind came back to life — and no one knew
description: Imagine being unable to say, "I am hungry," "I am in pain," "thank you," or "I love you,” -- losing your ability to communicate, being trapped inside your body, surrounded by people yet utterly alone. For 13 long years, that was Martin Pistorius’s reality. After contracting a brain infection at the age of twelve, Pistorius lost his ability to control his movements and to speak, and eventually he failed every test for mental awareness. He had become a ghost. But then a strange thing started to happen -- his mind began to knit itself back together. In this moving talk, Pistorius tells how he freed himself from a life locked inside his own body.

authortitle: Alex Gendler: Can you solve the bridge riddle?
author: Alex Gendler
title: Can you solve the bridge riddle?

authortitle: Elizabeth Nyamayaro: An invitation to men who want a better world for women
author: Elizabeth Nyamayaro
title: An invitation to men who want a better world for women
description: Around the world, women still struggle for equality in basic matters like access to education, equal pay and the right to vote. But how to enlist everyone, men and women, as allies for change? Meet Elizabeth Nyamayaro, head of UN Women's HeForShe initiative, which has created more than 2.4 billion social media conversations about a more equal world. She invites us all to join in as allies in our shared humanity.

authortitle: Latif Nasser: The amazing story of the man who gave us modern pain relief
author: Latif Nasser
title: The amazing story of the man who gave us modern pain relief
description: For the longest time, doctors basically ignored the most basic and frustrating part of being sick -- pain. In this lyrical, informative talk, Latif Nasser tells the extraordinary story of wrestler and doctor John J. Bonica, who persuaded the medical profession to take pain seriously -- and transformed the lives of millions.

authortitle: Jimmy Carter: Why I believe the mistreatment of women is the number one human rights abuse
author: Jimmy Carter
title: Why I believe the mistreatment of women is the number one human rights abuse
description: With his signature resolve, former US President Jimmy Carter dives into three unexpected reasons why the mistreatment of women and girls continues in so many manifestations in so many parts of the world, both developed and developing. The final reason he gives? "In general, men don't give a damn."

authortitle: Roman Mars: Why city flags may be the worst-designed thing you've never noticed
author: Roman Mars
title: Why city flags may be the worst-designed thing you've never noticed
description: Roman Mars is obsessed with flags -- and after you watch this talk, you might be, too. These ubiquitous symbols of civic pride are often designed, well, pretty terribly. But they don't have to be. In this surprising and hilarious talk about vexillology -- the study of flags -- Mars reveals the five basic principles of flag design and shows why he believes they can be applied to just about anything.

authortitle: Elora Hardy: Magical houses, made of bamboo
author: Elora Hardy
title: Magical houses, made of bamboo
description: You've never seen buildings like this. The stunning bamboo homes built by Elora Hardy and her team in Bali twist, curve and surprise at every turn. They defy convention because the bamboo itself is so enigmatic. No two poles of bamboo are alike, so every home, bridge and bathroom is exquisitely unique. In this beautiful, immersive talk, she shares the potential of bamboo, as both a sustainable resource and a spark for the imagination. "We have had to invent our own rules," she says.

authortitle: Mel Rosenberg: What causes bad breath?
author: Mel Rosenberg
title: What causes bad breath?

authortitle: Daniel Kish: How I use sonar to navigate the world
author: Daniel Kish
title: How I use sonar to navigate the world
description: Daniel Kish has been blind since he was 13 months old, but has learned to "see" using a form of echolocation. He clicks his tongue and sends out flashes of sound that bounce off surfaces in the environment and return to him, helping him to construct an understanding of the space around him. In a rousing talk, Kish shows how this works -- and asks us all to let go of our fear of the dark unknown.

authortitle: Nadine Burke Harris: How childhood trauma affects health across a lifetime
author: Nadine Burke Harris
title: How childhood trauma affects health across a lifetime
description: Childhood trauma isn’t something you just get over as you grow up. Pediatrician Nadine Burke Harris explains that the repeated stress of abuse, neglect and parents struggling with mental health or substance abuse issues has real, tangible effects on the development of the brain. This unfolds across a lifetime, to the point where those who’ve experienced high levels of trauma are at triple the risk for heart disease and lung cancer. An impassioned plea for pediatric medicine to confront the prevention and treatment of trauma, head-on.

authortitle: Guy Winch: Why we all need to practice emotional first aid
author: Guy Winch
title: Why we all need to practice emotional first aid
description: We'll go to the doctor when we feel flu-ish or a nagging pain. So why don’t we see a health professional when we feel emotional pain: guilt, loss, loneliness? Too many of us deal with common psychological-health issues on our own, says Guy Winch. But we don’t have to. He makes a compelling case to practice emotional hygiene — taking care of our emotions, our minds, with the same diligence we take care of our bodies.

authortitle: Michael Rubinstein: See invisible motion, hear silent sounds
author: Michael Rubinstein
title: See invisible motion, hear silent sounds
description: Meet the “motion microscope,” a video-processing tool that plays up tiny changes in motion and color impossible to see with the naked eye. Video researcher Michael Rubinstein plays us clip after jaw-dropping clip showing how this tech can track an individual’s pulse and heartbeat simply from a piece of footage. Watch him re-create a conversation by amplifying the movements from sound waves bouncing off a bag of chips. The wow-inspiring and sinister applications of this tech you have to see to believe.

authortitle: Anthony Hazard: The Atlantic slave trade: What too few textbooks told you
author: Anthony Hazard
title: The Atlantic slave trade: What too few textbooks told you

authortitle: Michael Mauser: What are those floaty things in your eye?
author: Michael Mauser
title: What are those floaty things in your eye?

authortitle: Oren Yakobovich: Hidden cameras that film injustice in the world’s most dangerous places
author: Oren Yakobovich
title: Hidden cameras that film injustice in the world’s most dangerous places
description: To see is to believe, says Oren Yakobovich — which is why he helps everyday people use hidden cameras to film dangerous situations of violence, political fraud and abuse. His organization, Videre, uncovers, verifies and publicizes human-rights abuses that the world needs to witness.

authortitle: Alessandra Orofino: It’s our city. Let’s fix it
author: Alessandra Orofino
title: It’s our city. Let’s fix it
description: Too often, people feel checked out of politics — even at the level of their own city. But urban activist Alessandra Orofino thinks that can change, using a mix of tech and old-fashioned human connection. Sharing examples from her hometown of Rio, she says: "It is up to us to decide whether we want schools or parking lots, recycling projects or construction sites, cars or buses, loneliness or solidarity."

authortitle: Jeremy Heimans: What new power looks like
author: Jeremy Heimans
title: What new power looks like
description: We can see the power of distributed, crowd-sourced business models every day — witness Uber, Kickstarter, Airbnb. But veteran online activist Jeremy Heimans asks: When does that kind of "new power" start to work in politics? His surprising answer: Sooner than you think. It’s a bold argument about the future of politics and power; watch and see if you agree.

authortitle: Antonio Donato Nobre: The magic of the Amazon: A river that flows invisibly all around us
author: Antonio Donato Nobre
title: The magic of the Amazon: A river that flows invisibly all around us
description: The Amazon River is like a heart, pumping water from the seas through it, and up into the atmosphere through 600 billion trees, which act like lungs. Clouds form, rain falls and the forest thrives. In a lyrical talk, Antonio Donato Nobre talks us through the interconnected systems of this region, and how they provide environmental services to the entire world. A parable for the extraordinary symphony that is nature.

authortitle: Avi Reichental: What's next in 3D printing
author: Avi Reichental
title: What's next in 3D printing
description: Just like his beloved grandfather, Avi Reichental is a maker of things. The difference is, now he can use 3D printers to make almost anything, out of almost any material. Reichental tours us through the possibilities of 3D printing, for everything from printed candy to highly custom sneakers.

authortitle: Aziza Chaouni: How I brought a river, and my city, back to life
author: Aziza Chaouni
title: How I brought a river, and my city, back to life
description: The Fez River winds through the medina of Fez, Morocco—a mazelike medieval city that's a World Heritage site. Once considered the "soul" of this celebrated city, the river succumbed to sewage and pollution, and in the 1950s was covered over bit by bit until nothing remained. TED Fellow Aziza Chaouni recounts her 20 year effort to restore this river to its former glory, and to transform her city in the process.

authortitle: Tim Berners-Lee: A Magna Carta for the web
author: Tim Berners-Lee
title: A Magna Carta for the web
description: Sir Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web 25 years ago. So it’s worth a listen when he warns us: There’s a battle ahead. Eroding net neutrality, filter bubbles and centralizing corporate control all threaten the web’s wide-open spaces. It’s up to users to fight for the right to access and openness. The question is, What kind of Internet do we want?

authortitle: Lorrie Faith Cranor: What’s wrong with your pa$$w0rd?
author: Lorrie Faith Cranor
title: What’s wrong with your pa$$w0rd?
description: Lorrie Faith Cranor studied thousands of real passwords to figure out the surprising, very common mistakes that users -- and secured sites -- make to compromise security. And how, you may ask, did she study thousands of real passwords without compromising the security of any users? That's a story in itself. It's secret data worth knowing, especially if your password is 123456 ...

authortitle: Doug Levinson: What gives a dollar bill its value?
author: Doug Levinson
title: What gives a dollar bill its value?

authortitle: William Black: How to rob a bank (from the inside, that is)
author: William Black
title: How to rob a bank (from the inside, that is)
description: William Black is a former bank regulator who’s seen firsthand how banking systems can be used to commit fraud — and how “liar's loans” and other tricky tactics led to the 2008 US banking crisis that threatened the international economy. In this engaging talk, Black, now an academic, reveals the best way to rob a bank — from the inside.

authortitle: Mark Ronson: How sampling transformed music
author: Mark Ronson
title: How sampling transformed music
description: Sampling isn't about "hijacking nostalgia wholesale," says Mark Ronson. It's about inserting yourself into the narrative of a song while also pushing that story forward. In this mind-blowingly original talk, watch the DJ scramble 15 TED Talks into an audio-visual omelette, and trace the evolution of "La Di Da Di," Doug E. Fresh and Slick Rick's 1984 hit that has been reimagined for every generation since.

authortitle: Allan Adams: The discovery that could rewrite physics
author: Allan Adams
title: The discovery that could rewrite physics
description: On March 17, 2014, a group of physicists announced a thrilling discovery: the “smoking gun” data for the idea of an inflationary universe, a clue to the Big Bang. For non-physicists, what does it mean? TED asked Allan Adams to briefly explain the results, in this improvised talk illustrated by Randall Munroe of xkcd.

authortitle: TED staff: It's TED, the Musical
author: TED staff
title: It's TED, the Musical
description: Do you have a TED Talk inside, just bursting to come out? Take this tongue-in-cheek musical journey to "Give Your Talk." A musical love letter to our speakers -- written, directed and performed by the TED staff.

authortitle: Ash Beckham: We're all hiding something. Let's find the courage to open up
author: Ash Beckham
title: We're all hiding something. Let's find the courage to open up
description: In this touching talk, Ash Beckham offers a fresh approach to empathy and openness. It starts with understanding that everyone, at some point in their life, has experienced hardship. The only way out, says Beckham, is to open the door and step out of your closet.

authortitle: Christopher Ryan: Are we designed to be sexual omnivores?
author: Christopher Ryan
title: Are we designed to be sexual omnivores?
description: An idea permeates our modern view of relationships: that men and women have always paired off in sexually exclusive relationships. But before the dawn of agriculture, humans may actually have been quite promiscuous. Author Christopher Ryan walks us through the controversial evidence that human beings are sexual omnivores by nature, in hopes that a more nuanced understanding may put an end to discrimination, shame and the kind of unrealistic expectations that kill relationships.

authortitle: Luke Syson: How I learned to stop worrying and love "useless" art
author: Luke Syson
title: How I learned to stop worrying and love "useless" art
description: Luke Syson was a curator of Renaissance art, of transcendent paintings of saints and solemn Italian ladies -- Very Serious Art. And then he changed jobs, and inherited the Met's collection of ceramics -- pretty, frilly, "useless" candlesticks and vases. He didn't like it. He didn't get it. Until one day ...

authortitle: Sheryl Sandberg: So we leaned in ... now what?
author: Sheryl Sandberg
title: So we leaned in ... now what?
description: Sheryl Sandberg admits she was terrified to step onto the TED stage in 2010 -- because she was going to talk, for the first time, about the lonely experience of being a woman in the top tiers of business. Millions of views (and a best-selling book) later, the Facebook COO talks with the woman who pushed her to give that first talk, Pat Mitchell. Sandberg opens up about the reaction to her idea, and explores the ways that women still struggle with success.

authortitle: Jared Diamond: How societies can grow old better
author: Jared Diamond
title: How societies can grow old better
description: There's an irony behind the latest efforts to extend human life: It's no picnic to be an old person in a youth-oriented society. Older people can become isolated, lacking meaningful work and low on funds. In this intriguing talk, Jared Diamond looks at how many different societies treat their elders -- some better, some worse -- and suggests we all take advantage of experience.

authortitle: Peter Doolittle: How your "working memory" makes sense of the world
author: Peter Doolittle
title: How your "working memory" makes sense of the world
description: "Life comes at us very quickly, and what we need to do is take that amorphous flow of experience and somehow extract meaning from it." In this funny, enlightening talk, educational psychologist Peter Doolittle details the importance -- and limitations -- of your "working memory," that part of the brain that allows us to make sense of what's happening right now.

authortitle: Steve Howard: Let's go all-in on selling sustainability
author: Steve Howard
title: Let's go all-in on selling sustainability
description: The big blue buildings of Ikea have sprouted solar panels and wind turbines; inside, shelves are stocked with LED lighting and recycled cotton. Why? Because as Steve Howard puts it: “Sustainability has gone from a nice-to-do to a must-do.” Howard, the chief sustainability officer at the furniture megastore, talks about his quest to sell eco-friendly materials and practices -- both internally and to worldwide customers -- and lays a challenge for other global giants.

authortitle: Hetain Patel: Who am I? Think again
author: Hetain Patel
title: Who am I? Think again
description: How do we decide who we are? Hetain Patel's surprising performance plays with identity, language and accent -- and challenges you to think deeper than surface appearances. A delightful meditation on self, with performer Yuyu Rau, and inspired by Bruce Lee.

authortitle: Sonia Shah: 3 reasons we still haven’t gotten rid of malaria
author: Sonia Shah
title: 3 reasons we still haven’t gotten rid of malaria
description: We’ve known how to cure malaria since the 1600s, so why does the disease still kill hundreds of thousands every year? It’s more than just a problem of medicine, says journalist Sonia Shah. A look into the history of malaria reveals three big-picture challenges to its eradication. Photos: Adam Nadel.

authortitle: Ron McCallum: How technology allowed me to read
author: Ron McCallum
title: How technology allowed me to read
description: Months after he was born, in 1948, Ron McCallum became blind. In this charming, moving talk, he shows how he reads -- and celebrates the progression of clever tools and adaptive computer technologies that make it possible. With their help, and the help of volunteers, he's become a lawyer, an academic, and, most of all, a voracious reader. Welcome to the blind reading revolution.

authortitle: John McWhorter: A brief history of plural word...s
author: John McWhorter
title: A brief history of plural word...s

authortitle: John Searle: Our shared condition -- consciousness
author: John Searle
title: Our shared condition -- consciousness
description: Philosopher John Searle lays out the case for studying human consciousness -- and systematically shoots down some of the common objections to taking it seriously. As we learn more about the brain processes that cause awareness, accepting that consciousness is a biological phenomenon is an important first step. And no, he says, consciousness is not a massive computer simulation.

authortitle: Lesley Hazleton: The doubt essential to faith
author: Lesley Hazleton
title: The doubt essential to faith
description: When Lesley Hazleton was writing a biography of Muhammad, she was struck by something: The night he received the revelation of the Koran, according to early accounts, his first reaction was doubt, awe, even fear. And yet this experience became the bedrock of his belief. Hazleton calls for a new appreciation of doubt and questioning as the foundation of faith -- and an end to fundamentalism of all kinds.

authortitle: Camille Seaman: Photos from a storm chaser
author: Camille Seaman
title: Photos from a storm chaser
description: Photographer Camille Seaman has been chasing storms for 5 years. In this talk she shows stunning, surreal photos of the heavens in tumult.

authortitle: Ray Laurence: Four sisters in Ancient Rome
author: Ray Laurence
title: Four sisters in Ancient Rome

authortitle: Maria Bezaitis: Why we need strangeness
author: Maria Bezaitis
title: Why we need strangeness
description: In our digital world, social relations have become mediated by data. Without even realizing it, we're barricading ourselves against strangeness -- people and ideas that don't fit the patterns of who we already know, what we already like and where we've already been. Maria Bezaitis makes a bold call for technology to deliver us to what and who we need, even if it's unfamiliar and strange.

authortitle: Eric Dishman: Health care should be a team sport
author: Eric Dishman
title: Health care should be a team sport
description: When Eric Dishman was in college, doctors told him he had 2 to 3 years to live. That was a long time ago. Now, Dishman puts his experience and his expertise as a medical tech specialist together to suggest a bold idea for reinventing health care -- by putting the patient at the center of a treatment team.

authortitle: Bill Shribman: What cameras see that our eyes don't
author: Bill Shribman
title: What cameras see that our eyes don't

authortitle: Elon Musk: The mind behind Tesla, SpaceX, SolarCity ...
author: Elon Musk
title: The mind behind Tesla, SpaceX, SolarCity ...
description: Entrepreneur Elon Musk is a man with many plans. The founder of PayPal, Tesla Motors and SpaceX sits down with TED curator Chris Anderson to share details about his visionary projects, which include a mass-marketed electric car, a solar energy leasing company and a fully reusable rocket.

authortitle: Danny Hillis: The Internet could crash. We need a Plan B
author: Danny Hillis
title: The Internet could crash. We need a Plan B
description: The Internet connects billions of people and machines; it's the backbone of modern life. But tech pioneer Danny Hillis thinks the Internet just wasn't designed to grow this big -- and he fears that one big cyber-attack or glitch could shut it down and take civilization with it. To head off a digital dark age, he sounds a clarion call to develop a Plan B: a parallel system to fall back on if -- or when -- the Internet crashes.

authortitle: Ayanna Howard: Make robots smarter
author: Ayanna Howard
title: Make robots smarter

authortitle: Cesar Kuriyama: One second every day
author: Cesar Kuriyama
title: One second every day
description: There are so many tiny, beautiful, funny, tragic moments in your life -- how are you going to remember them all? Director Cesar Kuriyama shoots one second of video every day as part of an ongoing project to collect all the special bits of his life.

authortitle: Gina Cooke: Why is there a "b" in doubt?
author: Gina Cooke
title: Why is there a "b" in doubt?

authortitle: Robin Chase: Excuse me, may I rent your car?
author: Robin Chase
title: Excuse me, may I rent your car?
description: A decade ago, Robin Chase founded Zipcar in the US, now the largest car-sharing company in the world. Now she's exploring the next level of car-sharing: Buzzcar, a French startup that lets people rent their own cars to others. The details are fascinating (how does insurance work, exactly?), and the larger vision (she calls it Peers, Inc.) points to a new definition of ownership and entrepreneurship.

authortitle: Ariel Anbar: A needle in countless haystacks: Finding habitable worlds
author: Ariel Anbar
title: A needle in countless haystacks: Finding habitable worlds

authortitle: Georgette Mulheir: The tragedy of orphanages
author: Georgette Mulheir
title: The tragedy of orphanages
description: Orphanages are costly and can cause irreparable damage both mentally and physically for its charges -- so why are they still so ubiquitous? Georgette Mulheir gravely describes the tragedy of orphanages and urges us to end our reliance on them, by finding alternate ways of supporting children in need.

authortitle: Vicki Arroyo: Let's prepare for our new climate
author: Vicki Arroyo
title: Let's prepare for our new climate
description: As Vicki Arroyo says, it's time to prepare our homes and cities for our changing climate, with its increased risk of flooding, drought and uncertainty. She illustrates this inspiring talk with bold projects from cities all over the world -- local examples of thinking ahead.

authortitle: Aris Venetikidis: Making sense of maps
author: Aris Venetikidis
title: Making sense of maps
description: Aris Venetikidis is fascinated by the maps we draw in our minds as we move around a city -- less like street maps, more like schematics or wiring diagrams, abstract images of relationships between places. How can we learn from these mental maps to make better real ones? As a test case, he remakes the notorious Dublin bus map.

authortitle: Pam Warhurst: How we can eat our landscapes
author: Pam Warhurst
title: How we can eat our landscapes
description: What should a community do with its unused land? Plant food, of course. With energy and humor, Pam Warhurst tells at the TEDSalon the story of how she and a growing team of volunteers came together to turn plots of unused land into communal vegetable gardens, and to change the narrative of food in their community.

authortitle: Max Little: A test for Parkinson's with a phone call
author: Max Little
title: A test for Parkinson's with a phone call
description: Parkinson's disease affects 6.3 million people worldwide, causing weakness and tremors, but there's no objective way to detect it early on. Yet. Applied mathematician and TED Fellow Max Little is testing a simple, cheap tool that in trials is able to detect Parkinson's with 99 percent accuracy -- in a 30-second phone call.

authortitle: Alanna Shaikh: How I'm preparing to get Alzheimer's
author: Alanna Shaikh
title: How I'm preparing to get Alzheimer's
description: When faced with a parent suffering from Alzheimer's, most of us respond with denial ("It won't happen to me") or extreme efforts at prevention. But global health expert and TED Fellow Alanna Shaikh sees it differently. She's taking three concrete steps to prepare for the moment -- should it arrive -- when she herself gets Alzheimer's disease.

authortitle: Jill Tarter: Calculating the odds of intelligent alien life
author: Jill Tarter
title: Calculating the odds of intelligent alien life

authortitle: Ken Goldberg: 4 lessons from robots about being human
author: Ken Goldberg
title: 4 lessons from robots about being human
description: The more that robots ingrain themselves into our everyday lives, the more we're forced to examine ourselves as people. At TEDxBerkeley, Ken Goldberg shares four very human lessons that he's learned from working with robots.

authortitle: David MacKay: A reality check on renewables
author: David MacKay
title: A reality check on renewables
description: How much land mass would renewables need to power a nation like the UK? An entire country's worth. In this pragmatic talk, David MacKay tours the basic mathematics that show worrying limitations on our sustainable energy options ... and explains why we should pursue them anyway.

authortitle: Adrián Paenza: How folding paper can get you to the moon
author: Adrián Paenza
title: How folding paper can get you to the moon

authortitle: Michael Norton: How to buy happiness
author: Michael Norton
title: How to buy happiness
description: At TEDxCambridge, Michael Norton shares fascinating research on how money can indeed buy happiness -- when you don't spend it on yourself. Listen for surprising data on the many ways pro-social spending can benefit you, your work, and (of course) other people.

authortitle: Scott Summit: Beautiful artificial limbs
author: Scott Summit
title: Beautiful artificial limbs
description: Prosthetics can't replicate the look and feel of lost limbs but they can carry a lot of personality. Designer Scott Summit shows 3D-printed, individually designed prosthetic legs that are unabashedly artificial and completely personal -- from macho to fabulous.

authortitle: Brené Brown: Listening to shame
author: Brené Brown
title: Listening to shame
description: Shame is an unspoken epidemic, the secret behind many forms of broken behavior. Brené Brown, whose earlier talk on vulnerability became a viral hit, explores what can happen when people confront their shame head-on. Her own humor, humanity and vulnerability shine through every word.

authortitle: Tyrone Hayes + Penelope Jagessar Chaffer: The toxic baby
author: Tyrone Hayes + Penelope Jagessar Chaffer
title: The toxic baby
description: Filmmaker Penelope Jagessar Chaffer was curious about the chemicals she was exposed to while pregnant: Could they affect her unborn child? So she asked scientist Tyrone Hayes to brief her on one he studied closely: atrazine, a herbicide used on corn. (Hayes, an expert on amphibians, is a critic of atrazine, which displays a disturbing effect on frog development.) Onstage together at TEDWomen, Hayes and Chaffer tell their story.

authortitle: Keith Nolan: Deaf in the military
author: Keith Nolan
title: Deaf in the military
description: Keith Nolan always wanted to join the United States military. The challenge: He is Deaf, which is an automatic disqualification according to military rules. In this talk, he describes his fight to fight for his country. (In American Sign Language, with real-time translation.)

authortitle: Tyler Cowen: Be suspicious of simple stories
author: Tyler Cowen
title: Be suspicious of simple stories
description: Like all of us, economist Tyler Cowen loves a good story. But in this intriguing talk, he asks us to step away from thinking of our lives -- and our messy, complicated irrational world -- in terms of a simple narrative.

authortitle: Michelle Borkin: Can astronomers help doctors?
author: Michelle Borkin
title: Can astronomers help doctors?
description: How do you measure a nebula? With a brain scan. In this talk, TED Fellow Michelle Borkin shows why collaboration between doctors and astronomers can lead to surprising discoveries.

authortitle: Péter Fankhauser: Meet Rezero, the dancing ballbot
author: Péter Fankhauser
title: Meet Rezero, the dancing ballbot
description: Engineering student Péter Fankhauser demonstrates Rezero, a robot that balances on a ball. Designed and built by students, Rezero is the first ballbot made to move quickly and gracefully -- and even dance. (Could the Star Wars sphere droid be real? Watch this and judge.)

authortitle: Phil Plait: How to defend Earth from asteroids
author: Phil Plait
title: How to defend Earth from asteroids
description: What's six miles wide and can end civilization in an instant? An asteroid -- and there are lots of them out there. With humor and great visuals, Phil Plait shows us all the ways asteroids can kill us (yipes), and what we must do to avoid them.

authortitle: Richard Seymour: How beauty feels
author: Richard Seymour
title: How beauty feels
description: A story, a work of art, a face, a designed object -- how do we tell that something is beautiful?  And why does it matter so much to us? Designer Richard Seymour explores our response to beauty and the surprising power of objects that exhibit it.

authortitle: Alison Gopnik: What do babies think?
author: Alison Gopnik
title: What do babies think?
description: "Babies and young children are like the R&D division of the human species," says psychologist Alison Gopnik. Her research explores the sophisticated intelligence-gathering and decision-making that babies are really doing when they play.

authortitle: Dyan deNapoli: The great penguin rescue
author: Dyan deNapoli
title: The great penguin rescue
description: The world's largest volunteer animal rescue, saved more than 40,000 penguins after an oil spill off the coast of South Africa. Dyan deNapoli tells the triumphant story. How does a job this big get done? Penguin by penguin by penguin ...

authortitle: Alex Steffen: The shareable future of cities
author: Alex Steffen
title: The shareable future of cities
description: How can cities help save the future? Alex Steffen shows some cool neighborhood-based green projects that expand our access to things we want and need -- while reducing the time we spend in cars.

authortitle: Camille Seaman: Haunting photos of polar ice
author: Camille Seaman
title: Haunting photos of polar ice
description: Photographer Camille Seaman shoots icebergs, showing the world the complex beauty of these massive, ancient chunks of ice. Dive in to her photo slideshow, "The Last Iceberg."

authortitle: Steve Keil: A manifesto for play, for Bulgaria and beyond
author: Steve Keil
title: A manifesto for play, for Bulgaria and beyond
description: Steve Keil fights the "serious meme" that has infected his home of Bulgaria -- and calls for a return to play to revitalize the economy, education and society. A sparkling talk with a universal message for people everywhere who are reinventing their workplaces, schools, lives.

authortitle: Eli Pariser: Beware online "filter bubbles"
author: Eli Pariser
title: Beware online "filter bubbles"
description: As web companies strive to tailor their services (including news and search results) to our personal tastes, there's a dangerous unintended consequence: We get trapped in a "filter bubble" and don't get exposed to information that could challenge or broaden our worldview. Eli Pariser argues powerfully that this will ultimately prove to be bad for us and bad for democracy.

authortitle: Arvind Gupta: Turning trash into toys for learning
author: Arvind Gupta
title: Turning trash into toys for learning
description: At the INK Conference, Arvind Gupta shares simple yet stunning plans for turning trash into seriously entertaining, well-designed toys that kids can build themselves -- while learning basic principles of science and design.

authortitle: Janna Levin: The sound the universe makes
author: Janna Levin
title: The sound the universe makes
description: We think of space as a silent place. But physicist Janna Levin says the universe has a soundtrack -- a sonic composition that records some of the most dramatic events in outer space. (Black holes, for instance, bang on spacetime like a drum.) An accessible and mind-expanding soundwalk through the universe.

authortitle: David Brooks: The social animal
author: David Brooks
title: The social animal
description: Columnist David Brooks unpacks new insights into human nature from the cognitive sciences -- insights with massive implications for economics and politics as well as our own self-knowledge. In a talk full of humor, he shows how you can't hope to understand humans as separate individuals making choices based on their conscious awareness.

authortitle: Heather Knight: Silicon-based comedy
author: Heather Knight
title: Silicon-based comedy
description: In this first-of-its-kind demo, Heather Knight introduces Data, a robotic stand-up comedian that does much more than rattle off one-liners -- it gathers audience feedback (using software co-developed with Scott Satkin and Varun Ramakrishna at CMU) and tunes its act as the crowd responds. Is this thing on?

authortitle: Anders Ynnerman: Visualizing the medical data explosion
author: Anders Ynnerman
title: Visualizing the medical data explosion
description: Medical scans can produce thousands of images for a single patient in seconds, but how do doctors know what's useful? Scientific visualization expert Anders Ynnerman shows us sophisticated new tools -- like virtual autopsies -- for analyzing our data, and hints at the sci-fi-sounding medical technologies coming up next. This talk contains some graphic medical imagery.

authortitle: Kim Gorgens: Protecting the brain against concussion
author: Kim Gorgens
title: Protecting the brain against concussion
description: Neuropsychologist Kim Gorgens makes the case for better protecting our brains against the risk of concussion -- with a compelling pitch for putting helmets on kids.

authortitle: Kristina Gjerde: Making law on the high seas
author: Kristina Gjerde
title: Making law on the high seas
description: Kristina Gjerde studies the law of the high seas -- the 64 percent of our ocean that isn't protected by any national law at all. Gorgeous photos show the hidden worlds that Gjerde and other lawyers are working to protect from trawling and trash-dumping, through smart policymaking and a healthy dose of PR.

authortitle: Eben Bayer: Are mushrooms the new plastic?
author: Eben Bayer
title: Are mushrooms the new plastic?
description: Product designer Eben Bayer reveals his recipe for a new, fungus-based packaging material that protects fragile stuff like furniture, plasma screens -- and the environment.

authortitle: Mechai Viravaidya: How Mr. Condom made Thailand a better place for life and love
author: Mechai Viravaidya
title: How Mr. Condom made Thailand a better place for life and love
description: Thailand's "Mr. Condom," Mechai Viravaidya, retells the country's bold plan to raise its standard of living, starting in the 1970s. First step: population control. And that means a lot of frank, funny -- and very effective -- talk about condoms.

authortitle: Peter Molyneux: Meet Milo, the virtual boy
author: Peter Molyneux
title: Meet Milo, the virtual boy
description: Peter Molyneux demos Milo, a hotly anticipated video game for Microsoft's Kinect controller. Perceptive and impressionable like a real 11-year-old, the virtual boy watches, listens and learns -- recognizing and responding to you.

authortitle: Margaret Gould Stewart: How YouTube thinks about copyright
author: Margaret Gould Stewart
title: How YouTube thinks about copyright
description: Margaret Gould Stewart, YouTube's head of user experience, talks about how the ubiquitous video site works with copyright holders and creators to foster (at the best of times) a creative ecosystem where everybody wins.

authortitle: Michael Shermer: The pattern behind self-deception
author: Michael Shermer
title: The pattern behind self-deception
description: Michael Shermer says the human tendency to believe strange things -- from alien abductions to dowsing rods -- boils down to two of the brain's most basic, hard-wired survival skills. He explains what they are, and how they get us into trouble.

authortitle: Roz Savage: Why I'm rowing across the Pacific
author: Roz Savage
title: Why I'm rowing across the Pacific
description: Five years ago, Roz Savage quit her high-powered London job to become an ocean rower. She's crossed the Atlantic solo, and just started the third leg of a Pacific solo row, the first for a woman. Why does she do it? Hear her reasons, both deeply personal and urgently activist.

authortitle: Stephen Wolfram: Computing a theory of all knowledge
author: Stephen Wolfram
title: Computing a theory of all knowledge
description: Stephen Wolfram, creator of Mathematica, talks about his quest to make all knowledge computational -- able to be searched, processed and manipulated. His new search engine, Wolfram Alpha, has no lesser goal than to model and explain the physics underlying the universe.

authortitle: Eric Mead: The magic of the placebo
author: Eric Mead
title: The magic of the placebo
description: Sugar pills, injections of nothing -- studies show that, more often than you'd expect, placebos really work. At TEDMED, magician Eric Mead does a trick to prove that, even when you know something's not real, you can still react as powerfully as if it is. (Warning: This talk is not suitable for viewers who are disturbed by needles or blood.)

authortitle: Anupam Mishra: The ancient ingenuity of water harvesting
author: Anupam Mishra
title: The ancient ingenuity of water harvesting
description: With wisdom and wit, Anupam Mishra talks about the amazing feats of engineering built centuries ago by the people of India's Golden Desert to harvest water. These ancient aqueducts and stepwells are still used today -- and are often superior to modern water megaprojects.

authortitle: Andrea Ghez: The hunt for a supermassive black hole
author: Andrea Ghez
title: The hunt for a supermassive black hole
description: With new data from the Keck telescopes, Andrea Ghez shows how state-of-the-art adaptive optics are helping astronomers understand our universe's most mysterious objects: black holes. She shares evidence that a supermassive black hole may be lurking at the center of the Milky Way.

authortitle: David Logan: Tribal leadership
author: David Logan
title: Tribal leadership
description: David Logan talks about the five kinds of tribes that humans naturally form -- in schools, workplaces, even the driver's license bureau. By understanding our shared tribal tendencies, we can help lead each other to become better individuals.

authortitle: Carolyn Steel: How food shapes our cities
author: Carolyn Steel
title: How food shapes our cities
description: Every day, in a city the size of London, 30 million meals are served. But where does all the food come from? Architect Carolyn Steel discusses the daily miracle of feeding a city, and shows how ancient food routes shaped the modern world.

authortitle: Golan Levin: Art that looks back at you
author: Golan Levin
title: Art that looks back at you
description: Golan Levin, an artist and engineer, uses modern tools -- robotics, new software, cognitive research -- to make artworks that surprise and delight. Watch as sounds become shapes, bodies create paintings, and a curious eye looks back at the curious viewer.

authortitle: Alain de Botton: A kinder, gentler philosophy of success
author: Alain de Botton
title: A kinder, gentler philosophy of success
description: Alain de Botton examines our ideas of success and failure -- and questions the assumptions underlying these two judgments. Is success always earned? Is failure? He makes an eloquent, witty case to move beyond snobbery to find true pleasure in our work.

authortitle: Jay Walker: The world's English mania
author: Jay Walker
title: The world's English mania
description: Jay Walker explains why two billion people around the world are trying to learn English. He shares photos and spine-tingling audio of Chinese students rehearsing English -- "the world's second language" -- by the thousands.

authortitle: Michelle Obama: A passionate, personal case for education
author: Michelle Obama
title: A passionate, personal case for education
description: Speaking to an audience of students, US First Lady Michelle Obama reminds each one to take their education seriously -- and never take it for granted. This new, brilliant generation, she tells us, is the one that could close the gap between the world as it is and the world as it should be.

authortitle: Bruce Bueno de Mesquita: A prediction for the future of Iran
author: Bruce Bueno de Mesquita
title: A prediction for the future of Iran
description: Bruce Bueno de Mesquita uses mathematical analysis to predict (very often correctly) such messy human events as war, political power shifts, Intifada ... After a crisp explanation of how he does it, he offers three predictions on the future of Iran.

authortitle: Nathaniel Kahn: Scenes from "My Architect"
author: Nathaniel Kahn
title: Scenes from "My Architect"
description: Nathaniel Kahn shares clips from his documentary "My Architect," about his quest to understand his father, the legendary architect Louis Kahn. It's a film with meaning to anyone who seeks to understand the relationship between art and love.

authortitle: Juan Enriquez: The next species of human
author: Juan Enriquez
title: The next species of human
description: While the mega-banks were toppling in early 2009, Juan Enriquez took the stage to say: The really big reboot is yet to come. But don't look for it on the stock exchange or the political ballot. It'll come from science labs, and it promises keener bodies and minds. Our kids are going to be ... different.

authortitle: Barry Schwartz: Our loss of wisdom
author: Barry Schwartz
title: Our loss of wisdom
description: Barry Schwartz makes a passionate call for "practical wisdom" as an antidote to a society gone mad with bureaucracy. He argues powerfully that rules often fail us, incentives often backfire, and practical, everyday wisdom will help rebuild our world.

authortitle: Nick Sears: Demo: The Orb
author: Nick Sears
title: Demo: The Orb
description: Inventor Nick Sears demos the first generation of the Orb, a rotating persistence-of-vision display that creates glowing 3D images. A short, cool tale of invention.

authortitle: Larry Burns: The future of cars
author: Larry Burns
title: The future of cars
description: General Motors veep Larry Burns previews cool next-gen car design: sleek, customizable (and computer-enhanced) vehicles that run clean on hydrogen -- and pump energy back into the electrical grid when they're idle.

authortitle: Virginia Postrel: On glamour
author: Virginia Postrel
title: On glamour
description: In a timely talk, cultural critic Virginia Postrel muses on the true meaning, and the powerful uses, of glamour -- which she defines as any calculated, carefully polished image designed to impress and persuade.

authortitle: Paola Antonelli: Design and the Elastic Mind
author: Paola Antonelli
title: Design and the Elastic Mind
description: MOMA design curator Paola Antonelli previews the groundbreaking show Design and the Elastic Mind -- full of products and designs that reflect the way we think now.

authortitle: Lennart Green: Close-up card magic with a twist
author: Lennart Green
title: Close-up card magic with a twist
description: Like your uncle at a family party, the rumpled Swedish doctor Lennart Green says, "Pick a card, any card." But what he does with those cards is pure magic -- flabbergasting, lightning-fast, how-does-he-do-it? magic.

authortitle: David Griffin: How photography connects us
author: David Griffin
title: How photography connects us
description: The photo director for National Geographic, David Griffin knows the power of photography to connect us to our world. In a talk filled with glorious images, he talks about how we all use photos to tell our stories.

authortitle: George Dyson: The birth of the computer
author: George Dyson
title: The birth of the computer
description: Historian George Dyson tells stories from the birth of the modern computer -- from its 17th-century origins to the hilarious notebooks of some early computer engineers.

authortitle: Murray Gell-Mann: The ancestor of language
author: Murray Gell-Mann
title: The ancestor of language
description: After speaking at TED2007 on elegance in physics, the amazing Murray Gell-Mann gives a quick overview of another passionate interest: finding the common ancestry of our modern languages.

authortitle: Karen Armstrong: My wish: The Charter for Compassion
author: Karen Armstrong
title: My wish: The Charter for Compassion
description: People want to be religious, says scholar Karen Armstrong; we should help make religion a force for harmony. She asks the TED community to help build a Charter for Compassion -- to restore the Golden Rule as the central global religious doctrine.

authortitle: Dave Eggers: My wish: Once Upon a School
author: Dave Eggers
title: My wish: Once Upon a School
description: Accepting his 2008 TED Prize, author Dave Eggers asks  the TED community to personally, creatively engage with local public schools. With spellbinding eagerness, he talks about how his 826 Valencia tutoring center inspired others around the world to open

authortitle: Arthur Benjamin: A performance of "Mathemagic"
author: Arthur Benjamin
title: A performance of "Mathemagic"
description: In a lively show, mathemagician Arthur Benjamin races a team of calculators to figure out 3-digit squares, solves another massive mental equation and guesses a few birthdays. How does he do it? He’ll tell you.

authortitle: Amory Lovins: Winning the oil endgame
author: Amory Lovins
title: Winning the oil endgame
description: In this energizing talk, Amory Lovins lays out his simple plan for weaning the US off oil and revitalizing the economy.

authortitle: Chris Abani: Telling stories from Africa
author: Chris Abani
title: Telling stories from Africa
description: In this deeply personal talk, Nigerian writer Chris Abani says that "what we know about how to be who we are" comes from stories. He searches for the heart of Africa through its poems and narrative, including his own.

authortitle: Patrick Awuah: How to educate leaders? Liberal arts
author: Patrick Awuah
title: How to educate leaders? Liberal arts
description: A liberal arts education is critical to forming true leaders, says university head Patrick Awuah -- because it builds decision-making skills, an ethical framework and a broad vision. Awuah himself left a career at Microsoft in the US to found a liberal arts school in Africa: Ashesi University, in his home nation of Ghana. A passionate talk about dreaming, doing and leading.

authortitle: Richard Dawkins: Militant atheism
author: Richard Dawkins
title: Militant atheism
description: Richard Dawkins urges all atheists to openly state their position -- and to fight the incursion of the church into politics and science. A fiery, funny, powerful talk.

authortitle: Tom Honey: Why would God create a tsunami?
author: Tom Honey
title: Why would God create a tsunami?
description: In the days following the tragic South Asian tsunami of 2004, the Rev. Tom Honey pondered the question, "How could a loving God have done this?" Here is his answer.

authortitle: Saul Griffith: Everyday inventions
author: Saul Griffith
title: Everyday inventions
description: Inventor and MacArthur fellow Saul Griffith shares some innovative ideas from his lab -- from "smart rope" to a house-sized kite for towing large loads.

authortitle: Pilobolus: A dance of "Symbiosis"
author: Pilobolus
title: A dance of "Symbiosis"
description: Two Pilobolus dancers perform "Symbiosis." Does it trace the birth of a relationship? Or the co-evolution of symbiotic species? Music: "God Music," George Crumb; "Fratres," Arvo Part; "Morango...Almost a Tango," Thomas Oboe Lee.

authortitle: Helen Fisher: Why we love, why we cheat
author: Helen Fisher
title: Why we love, why we cheat
description: Anthropologist Helen Fisher takes on a tricky topic – love – and explains its evolution, its biochemical foundations and its social importance. She closes with a warning about the potential disaster inherent in antidepressant abuse.

authortitle: Eve Ensler: Happiness in body and soul
author: Eve Ensler
title: Happiness in body and soul
description: Eve Ensler, creator of "The Vagina Monologues," shares how a discussion about menopause with her friends led to talking about all sorts of sexual acts onstage, waging a global campaign to end violence toward women and finding her own happiness.

authortitle: Neal Katyal: How to win an argument (at the US Supreme Court, or anywhere)
author: Neal Katyal
title: How to win an argument (at the US Supreme Court, or anywhere)

author: Leah Garcés
title: A lesson in turning adversaries into allies

author: Kirsty Duncan

author: Sarah Murray

authortitle: Priya Vulchi and Winona Guo: What it takes to be racially literate
author: Priya Vulchi and Winona Guo

authortitle: Laura L. Dunn: It's time for the law to protect victims of gender violence

author: John Amory

authortitle: Eric Berridge: Why tech needs the humanities
author: Eric Berridge

authortitle: Clemantine Wamariya: War and what comes after
author: Clemantine Wamariya

authortitle: Nancy Rabalais: The "dead zone" of the Gulf of Mexico
author: Nancy Rabalais

author: Hannah Bürckstümmer

author: Aaron Duffy, Lake Buckley and Jack Foster
title: "Illusions for a better society"

authortitle: Shane Griffin: "Chromatic"
