authortitle: Robin Steinberg: What if we ended the injustice of bail?
author: Robin Steinberg
title: What if we ended the injustice of bail?

authortitle: Jaron Lanier: How we need to remake the internet
author: Jaron Lanier
title: How we need to remake the internet

authortitle: Malika Whitley: How the arts help homeless youth heal and build
author: Malika Whitley
title: How the arts help homeless youth heal and build

authortitle: Lera Boroditsky: How language shapes the way we think
author: Lera Boroditsky
title: How language shapes the way we think

authortitle: José Andrés: How a team of chefs fed Puerto Rico after Hurricane Maria
author: José Andrés
title: How a team of chefs fed Puerto Rico after Hurricane Maria

authortitle: Tara Houska: The Standing Rock resistance and our fight for indigenous rights
author: Tara Houska
title: The Standing Rock resistance and our fight for indigenous rights

authortitle: Kasiva Mutua: How I use the drum to tell my story
author: Kasiva Mutua
title: How I use the drum to tell my story

authortitle: Danny Hillis: Should we create a solar shade to cool the earth?
author: Danny Hillis
title: Should we create a solar shade to cool the earth?

authortitle: Andrew Dent: To eliminate waste, we need to rediscover thrift
author: Andrew Dent
title: To eliminate waste, we need to rediscover thrift

authortitle: Raj Panjabi: Community health heroes
author: Raj Panjabi
title: Community health heroes

authortitle: JR: Undocumented lives, inside out
author: JR
title: Undocumented lives, inside out

authortitle: Karen Armstrong: Passion for compassion
author: Karen Armstrong
title: Passion for compassion

authortitle: Jamie Oliver: Food revolutionaries
author: Jamie Oliver
title: Food revolutionaries

authortitle: Sarah Parcak: Armchair archaeologist
author: Sarah Parcak
title: Armchair archaeologist

authortitle: Drew Philp: My $500 house in Detroit -- and the neighbors who helped me rebuild it
author: Drew Philp
title: My $500 house in Detroit -- and the neighbors who helped me rebuild it

authortitle: Irina Kareva: Math can help uncover cancer's secrets
author: Irina Kareva
title: Math can help uncover cancer's secrets

authortitle: Anika Hazra: A simple way to tell insects apart
author: Anika Hazra
title: A simple way to tell insects apart

authortitle: Raphael Arar: How we can teach computers to make sense of our emotions
author: Raphael Arar
title: How we can teach computers to make sense of our emotions

authortitle: Christian Picciolini: My descent into America's neo-Nazi movement -- and how I got out
author: Christian Picciolini
title: My descent into America's neo-Nazi movement -- and how I got out

authortitle: Judith Heumann: Our fight for disability rights -- and why we're not done yet
author: Judith Heumann
title: Our fight for disability rights -- and why we're not done yet

authortitle: Leo Igwe: Why I choose humanism over faith
author: Leo Igwe
title: Why I choose humanism over faith

authortitle: Ndidi Nwuneli: The role of faith and belief in modern Africa
author: Ndidi Nwuneli
title: The role of faith and belief in modern Africa
description: Ndidi Nwuneli has advice for Africans who believe in God -- and Africans who don't. To the religious, she advises against using God to outsource responsibility for what happens in their lives. To the non-religious, she asks that they keep an open mind and work with faith-based organizations, especially on issues like health care and education. "There's so much potential that can be realized when we walk across the divide of faith and, hand in hand, try to solve many of our problems," Nwuneli says.

authortitle: Erica Stone: Academic research is publicly funded -- why isn't it publicly available?
author: Erica Stone
title: Academic research is publicly funded -- why isn't it publicly available?
description: In the US, your taxes fund academic research at public universities. Why then do you need to pay expensive, for-profit journals for the results of that research? Erica Stone advocates for a new, open-access relationship between the public and scholars, making the case that academics should publish in more accessible media. "A functioning democracy requires that the public be well-educated and well-informed," Stone says. "Instead of research happening behind paywalls and bureaucracy, wouldn't it be better if it was unfolding right in front of us?"

authortitle: Mennat El Ghalid: How fungi recognize (and infect) plants
author: Mennat El Ghalid
title: How fungi recognize (and infect) plants
description: Each year, the world loses enough food to feed half a billion people to fungi, the most destructive pathogens of plants. Mycologist and TED Fellow Mennat El Ghalid explains how a breakthrough in our understanding of the molecular signals fungi use to attack plants could disrupt this interaction -- and save our crops.

authortitle: Vikram Sharma: How quantum physics can make encryption stronger
author: Vikram Sharma
title: How quantum physics can make encryption stronger
description: As quantum computing matures, it's going to bring unimaginable increases in computational power along with it -- and the systems we use to protect our data (and our democratic processes) will become even more vulnerable. But there's still time to plan against the impending data apocalypse, says encryption expert Vikram Sharma. Learn more about how he's fighting quantum with quantum: designing security devices and programs that use the power of quantum physics to defend against the most sophisticated attacks.

authortitle: Matthias Müllenbeck: What if we paid doctors to keep people healthy?
author: Matthias Müllenbeck
title: What if we paid doctors to keep people healthy?

authortitle: Amishi Jha: How to tame your wandering mind
author: Amishi Jha
title: How to tame your wandering mind
description: Amishi Jha studies how we pay attention: the process by which our brain decides what's important out of the constant stream of information it receives. Both external distractions (like stress) and internal ones (like mind-wandering) diminish our attention's power, Jha says -- but some simple techniques can boost it. "Pay attention to your attention," Jha says.

authortitle: Sauti Sol: The rhythm of Afrobeat
author: Sauti Sol
title: The rhythm of Afrobeat

authortitle: Eve Abrams: The human stories behind mass incarceration
author: Eve Abrams
title: The human stories behind mass incarceration
description: The United States locks up more people than any other country in the world, says documentarian Eve Abrams, and somewhere between one and four percent of those in prison are likely innocent. That's 87,000 brothers, sisters, mothers and fathers -- predominantly African American -- unnecessarily separated from their families, their lives and dreams put on hold. Using audio from her interviews with incarcerated people and their families, Abrams shares touching stories of those impacted by mass incarceration and calls on us all to take a stand and ensure that the justice system works for everyone.

authortitle: Vittorio Loreto: Need a new idea? Start at the edge of what is known
author: Vittorio Loreto
title: Need a new idea? Start at the edge of what is known
description: "Where do great ideas come from?" Starting with this question in mind, Vittorio Loreto takes us on a journey to explore a possible mathematical scheme that explains the birth of the new. Learn more about the "adjacent possible" -- the crossroads of what's actual and what's possible -- and how studying the math that drives it could explain how we create new ideas.

authortitle: Soka Moses: For survivors of Ebola, the crisis isn't over
author: Soka Moses
title: For survivors of Ebola, the crisis isn't over
description: In 2014, as a newly trained physician, Soka Moses took on one of the toughest jobs in the world: treating highly contagious patients at the height of Liberia's Ebola outbreak. In this intense, emotional talk, he details what he saw on the frontlines of the crisis -- and reveals the challenges and stigma that thousands of survivors still face.

authortitle: Bob Stein: A rite of passage for late life
author: Bob Stein
title: A rite of passage for late life
description: We use rituals to mark the early stages of our lives, like birthdays and graduations -- but what about our later years? In this meditative talk about looking both backward and forward, Bob Stein proposes a new tradition of giving away your things (and sharing the stories behind them) as you get older, to reflect on your life so far and open the door to whatever comes next.

authortitle: Liz Ogbu: What if gentrification was about healing communities instead of displacing them?
author: Liz Ogbu
title: What if gentrification was about healing communities instead of displacing them?
description: Liz Ogbu is an architect who works on spatial justice: the idea that justice has a geography and that the equitable distribution of resources and services is a human right. In San Francisco, she's questioning the all too familiar story of gentrification: that poor people will be pushed out by development and progress. "Why is it that we treat culture erasure and economic displacement as inevitable?" she asks, calling on developers, architects and policymakers to instead "make a commitment to build people's capacity to stay in their homes, to stay in their communities, to stay where they feel whole."

authortitle: Adong Judith: How I use art to bridge misunderstanding
author: Adong Judith
title: How I use art to bridge misunderstanding
description: Director and playwright Adong Judith creates provocative art that sparks dialogue on issues from LGBTQ rights to war crimes. In this quick but powerful talk, the TED Fellow details her work -- including the play "Silent Voices," which brought victims of the Northern Ugandan war against Joseph Kony's rebel group together with political, religious and cultural leaders for transformative talks. "Listening to one another will not magically solve all problems," Judith says. "But it will give a chance to create avenues to start to work together to solve many of humanity's problems."

authortitle: Chris Nowinski: Can I have your brain? The quest for truth on concussions and CTE
author: Chris Nowinski
title: Can I have your brain? The quest for truth on concussions and CTE

authortitle: Sally Kohn: What we can do about the culture of hate
author: Sally Kohn
title: What we can do about the culture of hate
description: We're all against hate, right? We agree it's a problem -- their problem, not our problem, that is. But as Sally Kohn discovered, we all hate -- some of us in subtle ways, others in obvious ones. As she confronts a hard story from her own life, she shares ideas on how we can recognize, challenge and heal from hatred in our institutions and in ourselves.

authortitle: Rei: "my mama" / "BLACK BANANA"
author: Rei
title: "my mama" / "BLACK BANANA"

authortitle: Hadi Eldebek: Why must artists be poor?
author: Hadi Eldebek
title: Why must artists be poor?
description: The arts bring meaning to our lives and spirit to our culture -- so why do we expect artists to struggle to make a living? Hadi Eldebek is working to create a society where artists are valued through an online platform that matches artists with grants and funding opportunities -- so they can focus on their craft instead of their side hustle.

authortitle: Isabel Wilkerson: The Great Migration and the power of a single decision
author: Isabel Wilkerson
title: The Great Migration and the power of a single decision
description: Sometimes, a single decision can change the course of history. Join journalist and author Isabel Wilkerson as she tells the story of the Great Migration, the outpouring of six million African Americans from the Jim Crow South to cities in the North and West between World War I and the 1970s. This was the first time in American history that the lowest caste people signaled they had options and were willing to take them -- and the first time they had a chance to choose for themselves what they would do with their innate talents, Wilkerson explains. "These people, by their actions, were able to do what the powers that be, North and South, could not or would not do," she says. "They freed themselves."

authortitle: Margaret Gould Stewart: How the hyperlink changed everything
author: Margaret Gould Stewart
title: How the hyperlink changed everything
description: The hyperlink is the LEGO block of the internet. Here's the bizarre history of how it came to be, as told by user experience master Margaret Gould Stewart.

authortitle: David Rockwell: The hidden ways stairs shape your life
author: David Rockwell
title: The hidden ways stairs shape your life
description: Stairs don't just get you from point A to point B. Architect David Rockwell explains how they shape your movement -- and your feelings.

authortitle: Isaac Mizrahi: How the button changed fashion
author: Isaac Mizrahi
title: How the button changed fashion
description: How the simple button changed the world, according to fashion designer Isaac Mizrahi.

authortitle: Paola Antonelli: The 3,000-year history of the hoodie
author: Paola Antonelli
title: The 3,000-year history of the hoodie
description: The hoodie is a lot more than just a comfy sweatshirt. Design curator Paola Antonelli takes us through its history.

authortitle: Kyra Gaunt: How the jump rope got its rhythm
author: Kyra Gaunt
title: How the jump rope got its rhythm
description: "Down down, baby, down down the roller coaster..." Hip-hop owes a lot of the queens of double dutch. Ethnomusicologist Kyra Gaunt takes us on a tour of the fascinating history of the jump rope.

authortitle: Daniel Engber: How the progress bar keeps you sane
author: Daniel Engber
title: How the progress bar keeps you sane
description: The progress bar makes waiting more exciting... and mitigates our fear of death. Journalist Daniel Engber explores how it came into existence.

authortitle: Caroline Weaver: Why the pencil is perfect
author: Caroline Weaver
title: Why the pencil is perfect
description: Why are pencils shaped like hexagons, and how did they get their iconic yellow color? Pencil shop owner Caroline Weaver takes us inside the fascinating history of the pencil.

authortitle: Michael Bierut: The genius of the London Tube Map
author: Michael Bierut
title: The genius of the London Tube Map
description: Design legend Michael Bierut tells the story of the accidental success of one of the most famous maps in the world -- the London Tube Map.

authortitle: Daniel Susskind: 3 myths about the future of work (and why they're not true)
author: Daniel Susskind
title: 3 myths about the future of work (and why they're not true)
description: "Will machines replace humans?" This question is on the mind of anyone with a job to lose. Daniel Susskind confronts this question and three misconceptions we have about our automated future, suggesting we ask something else: How will we distribute wealth in a world when there will be less -- or even no -- work?

authortitle: Alvin Irby: How to inspire every child to be a lifelong reader
author: Alvin Irby
title: How to inspire every child to be a lifelong reader
description: According to the US Department of Education, more than 85 percent of black fourth-grade boys aren't proficient in reading. What kind of reading experiences should we be creating to ensure that all children read well? In a talk that will make you rethink how we teach, educator and author Alvin Irby explains the reading challenges that many black children face -- and tells us what culturally competent educators do to help all children identify as readers.

authortitle: Deanna Van Buren: What a world without prisons could look like
author: Deanna Van Buren
title: What a world without prisons could look like
description: Deanna Van Buren designs restorative justice centers that, instead of taking the punitive approach used by a system focused on mass incarceration, treat crime as a breach of relationships and justice as a process where all stakeholders come together to repair that breach. With help and ideas from incarcerated men and women, Van Buren is creating dynamic spaces that provide safe venues for dialogue and reconciliation; employment and job training; and social services to help keep people from entering the justice system in the first place. "Imagine a world without prisons," Van Buren says. "And join me in creating all the things that we could build instead."

authortitle: Iké Udé: The radical beauty of Africa, in portraits
author: Iké Udé
title: The radical beauty of Africa, in portraits

authortitle: Sophie Andrews: The best way to help is often just to listen
author: Sophie Andrews
title: The best way to help is often just to listen
description: A 24-hour helpline in the UK known as Samaritans helped Sophie Andrews become a survivor of abuse rather than a victim. Now she's paying the favor back as the founder of The Silver Line, a helpline that supports lonely and isolated older people. In a powerful, personal talk, she shares why the simple act of listening (instead of giving advice) is often the best way to help someone in need.

authortitle: Musimbi Kanyoro: To solve the world's biggest problems, invest in women and girls
author: Musimbi Kanyoro
title: To solve the world's biggest problems, invest in women and girls
description: As CEO of the Global Fund for Women, Musimbi Kanyoro works to support women and their ideas so they can expand and grow. She introduces us to the Maragoli concept of "isirika" -- a pragmatic way of life that embraces the mutual responsibility to care for one another -- something she sees women practicing all over the world. And she calls for those who have more to give more to people working to improve their communities. "Imagine what it would look like if you embraced isirika and made it your default," Kanyoro says. "What could we achieve for each other? For humanity?" Let's find out -- together.

authortitle: Kaustav Dey: How fashion helps us express who we are -- and what we stand for
author: Kaustav Dey
title: How fashion helps us express who we are -- and what we stand for
description: No one thinks twice about a woman wearing blue jeans in New York City -- but when Nobel laureate Malala wears them, it's a political act. Around the globe, individuality can be a crime, and clothing can be a form of protest. In a talk about the power of what we wear, Kaustav Dey examines how fashion gives us a nonverbal language of dissent and encourages us to embrace our authentic selves.

authortitle: Petter Johansson:  Do you really know why you do what you do?
author: Petter Johansson
title: Do you really know why you do what you do?

authortitle: Marc Bamuthi Joseph: What soccer can teach us about freedom
author: Marc Bamuthi Joseph
title: What soccer can teach us about freedom
description: "Soccer is the only thing on this planet that we can all agree to do together," says theater maker and TED Fellow Marc Bamuthi Joseph. Through his performances and an engagement initiative called "Moving and Passing," Joseph combines music, dance and soccer to reveal accessible, joyful connections between the arts and sports. Learn more about how he's using the beautiful game to foster community and highlight issues facing immigrants.

authortitle: Minda Dentler: What I learned when I conquered the world's toughest triathlon
author: Minda Dentler
title: What I learned when I conquered the world's toughest triathlon
description: A 2.4-mile swim, a 112-mile bicycle ride and then a full-length marathon on hot, dry ground -- with no breaks in between: the legendary Ironman triathlon in Kona, Hawaii, is a bucket list goal for champion athletes. But when Minda Dentler decided to take it on, she had bigger aspirations than just another medal around her neck. She tells the story of how she conquered this epic race, and what it inspired her to do next.

authortitle: Bill Bernat: How to connect with depressed friends
author: Bill Bernat
title: How to connect with depressed friends

authortitle: Felice Belle and Jennifer Murphy: How we became sisters
author: Felice Belle and Jennifer Murphy
title: How we became sisters
description: Poets Felice Belle and Jennifer Murphy perform excerpts from their play "Other Women," which is created and directed by Monica L. Williams. In a captivating journey, they weave together stories full of laughter, loyalty, tragedy and heartbreak, recalling the moments that made them sisters.

authortitle: Shameem Akhtar: To learn is to be free
author: Shameem Akhtar
title: To learn is to be free
description: Shameem Akhtar posed as a boy during her early childhood in Pakistan so she could enjoy the privileges Pakistani girls are rarely afforded: to play outside and attend school. In an eye-opening, personal talk, Akhtar recounts how the opportunity to get an education altered the course of her life -- and ultimately changed the culture of her village, where today every young girl goes to school.

authortitle: Dustin Schroeder: How we look kilometers below the Antarctic ice sheet
author: Dustin Schroeder
title: How we look kilometers below the Antarctic ice sheet
description: Antarctica is a vast and dynamic place, but radar technologies -- from World War II-era film to state-of-the-art miniaturized sensors -- are enabling scientists to observe and understand changes beneath the continent's ice in unprecedented detail. Join radio glaciologist Dustin Schroeder on a flight high above Antarctica and see how ice-penetrating radar is helping us learn about future sea level rise -- and what the melting ice will mean for us all.

authortitle: Wendy Suzuki: The brain-changing benefits of exercise
author: Wendy Suzuki
title: The brain-changing benefits of exercise
description: What's the most transformative thing that you can do for your brain today? Exercise! says neuroscientist Wendy Suzuki. Get inspired to go to the gym as Suzuki discusses the science of how working out boosts your mood and memory -- and protects your brain against neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's.

authortitle: Chuck Nice: A funny look at the unintended consequences of technology
author: Chuck Nice
title: A funny look at the unintended consequences of technology
description: Technology should work for us, but what happens when it doesn't? Comedian Chuck Nice explores the unintended consequences of technological advancement and human interaction -- with hilarious results.

authortitle: Raymond Tang: Be humble -- and other lessons from the philosophy of water
author: Raymond Tang
title: Be humble -- and other lessons from the philosophy of water
description: How do we find fulfillment in a world that's constantly changing? Raymond Tang struggled with this question until he came across the ancient Chinese philosophy of the Tao Te Ching. In it, he found a passage comparing goodness to water, an idea he's now applying to his everyday life. In this charming talk, he shares three lessons he's learned so far from the "philosophy of water." "What would water do?" Tang asks. "This simple and powerful question ... has changed my life for the better."

authortitle: Ilona Stengel: The role of human emotions in science and research
author: Ilona Stengel
title: The role of human emotions in science and research
description: Do human emotions have a role to play in science and research? Material researcher Ilona Stengel suggests that instead of opposing each other, emotions and logic complement and reinforce each other. She shares a case study on how properly using emotions (like the empowering feeling of being dedicated to something meaningful) can boost teamwork and personal development -- and catalyze scientific breakthroughs and innovation.

authortitle: Howard C. Stevenson: How to resolve racially stressful situations
author: Howard C. Stevenson
title: How to resolve racially stressful situations
description: If we hope to heal the racial tensions that threaten to tear the fabric of society apart, we're going to need the skills to openly express ourselves in racially stressful situations. Through racial literacy -- the ability to read, recast and resolve these situations -- psychologist Howard C. Stevenson helps children and parents reduce and manage stress and trauma. In this inspiring, quietly awesome talk, learn more about how this approach to decoding racial threat can help youth build confidence and stand up for themselves in productive ways.

authortitle: Tapiwa Chiwewe: You don't have to be an expert to solve big problems
author: Tapiwa Chiwewe
title: You don't have to be an expert to solve big problems
description: Driving in Johannesburg one day, Tapiwa Chiwewe noticed an enormous cloud of air pollution hanging over the city. He was curious and concerned but not an environmental expert -- so he did some research and discovered that nearly 14 percent of all deaths worldwide in 2012 were caused by household and ambient air pollution. With this knowledge and an urge to do something about it, Chiwewe and his colleagues developed a platform that uncovers trends in pollution and helps city planners make better decisions. "Sometimes just one fresh perspective, one new skill set, can make the conditions right for something remarkable to happen," Chiwewe says. "But you need to be bold enough to try."

authortitle: Robert Hakiza: Refugees want empowerment, not handouts
author: Robert Hakiza
title: Refugees want empowerment, not handouts
description: The prevailing image of where refugees live is of temporary camps in isolated areas -- but in reality, nearly 60 percent of them worldwide end up in urban areas. TED Fellow Robert Hakiza takes us inside the lives of urban refugees -- and shows us how organizations like the one that he started can provide them with the skills they need to ultimately become self-sufficient.

authortitle: Tiffany Kagure Mugo and Siphumeze Khundayi: How to have a healthier, positive relationship to sex
author: Tiffany Kagure Mugo and Siphumeze Khundayi
title: How to have a healthier, positive relationship to sex
description: From our fear of women's bodies to our sheepishness around the word "nipple," our ideas about sex need an upgrade, say sex educators (and hilarious women) Tiffany Kagure Mugo and Siphumeze Khundayi. For a radical new take on sex positivity, the duo take the TED stage to suggest we look to Africa for erotic wisdom both ancient and modern, showing us how we can shake off problematic ideas about sex we've internalized and re-define pleasure on our own terms. (This talk contains mature content.)

authortitle: Nilay Kulkarni: A life-saving invention that prevents human stampedes
author: Nilay Kulkarni
title: A life-saving invention that prevents human stampedes
description: Every three years, more than 30 million Hindu worshippers gather for the Kumbh Mela in India, the world's largest religious gathering, in order to wash away their sins. With massive crowds descending on small cities and towns, stampedes inevitably happen, and in 2003, 39 people were killed during the festival. In 2014, then 15-year-old Nilay Kulkarni decided to put his skills as a self-taught programmer to use by building a tech solution to help prevent stampedes. Learn more about his invention -- and how it helped the 2015 Nashik Kumbh Mela have zero stampedes and casualties.

authortitle: Jason Shen: Looking for a job? Highlight your ability, not your experience
author: Jason Shen
title: Looking for a job? Highlight your ability, not your experience
description: Very few of us hold jobs that line up directly with our past experiences or what we studied in college. Take TED Resident Jason Shen; he studied biology but later became a product manager at a tech company. In this quick, insightful talk about human potential, Shen shares some new thinking on how job seekers can make themselves more attractive -- and why employers should look for ability over credentials.

authortitle: Margaret Mitchell: How we can build AI to help humans, not hurt us
author: Margaret Mitchell
title: How we can build AI to help humans, not hurt us
description: As a research scientist at Google, Margaret Mitchell helps develop computers that can communicate about what they see and understand. She tells a cautionary tale about the gaps, blind spots and biases we subconsciously encode into AI -- and asks us to consider what the technology we create today will mean for tomorrow. "All that we see now is a snapshot in the evolution of artificial intelligence," Mitchell says. "If we want AI to evolve in a way that helps humans, then we need to define the goals and strategies that enable that path now."

authortitle: Tanya Menon: The secret to great opportunities? The person you haven't met yet
author: Tanya Menon
title: The secret to great opportunities? The person you haven't met yet
description: We often find ourselves stuck in narrow social circles with similar people. What habits confine us, and how can we break them? Organizational psychologist Tanya Menon considers how we can be more intentional about expanding our social universes -- and how it can lead to new ideas and opportunities.

authortitle: Amit Kalra: 3 creative ways to fix fashion's waste problem
author: Amit Kalra
title: 3 creative ways to fix fashion's waste problem
description: What happens to the clothes we don't buy? You might think that last season's coats, trousers and turtlenecks end up being put to use, but most of it (nearly 13 million tons each year in the United States alone) ends up in landfills. Fashion has a waste problem, and Amit Kalra wants to fix it. He shares some creative ways the industry can evolve to be more conscientious about the environment -- and gain a competitive advantage at the same time.

authortitle: Rowan Fitzpatrick and Heart of Mind: Facing the future together
author: Rowan Fitzpatrick and Heart of Mind
title: Facing the future together

authortitle: Shadé Zahrai and Aric Yegudkin: The rhythmic beauty of collaboration
author: Shadé Zahrai and Aric Yegudkin
title: The rhythmic beauty of collaboration

author: Will Jenkins
title: The most precious commodity of all?

authortitle: Tomer Garzberg: What happens when we take humans out of work?
author: Tomer Garzberg
title: What happens when we take humans out of work?

authortitle: Rach Ranton: Where are we trying to end up?
author: Rach Ranton
title: Where are we trying to end up?

authortitle: Olivia Tyler: The complex path to sustainability
author: Olivia Tyler
title: The complex path to sustainability

authortitle: Michael Mieni: Using Aboriginal traditions to teach tech
author: Michael Mieni
title: Using Aboriginal traditions to teach tech

authortitle: Linda Zhang: Why schools should teach entrepreneurship
author: Linda Zhang
title: Why schools should teach entrepreneurship

authortitle: Hayley Yeates: It's (past) time to appreciate cultural diversity
author: Hayley Yeates
title: It's (past) time to appreciate cultural diversity

authortitle: Alastair O'Neill: When genetic choice becomes personal
author: Alastair O'Neill
title: When genetic choice becomes personal

authortitle: Walé Oyéjidé: Fashion that celebrates African strength and spirit
author: Walé Oyéjidé
title: Fashion that celebrates African strength and spirit
description: "To be African is to be inspired by culture and to be filled with undying hope for the future," says designer and TED Fellow Walé Oyéjidé. With his label Ikiré Jones (you'll see their work in Marvel's "Black Panther"), he uses classic design to showcase the elegance and grace of often-marginalized groups, in beautifully cut clothing that tells a story.

authortitle: Dixon Chibanda: Why I train grandmothers to treat depression
author: Dixon Chibanda
title: Why I train grandmothers to treat depression
description: Dixon Chibanda is one of 12 psychiatrists in Zimbabwe -- for a population of more than 16 million. Realizing that his country would never be able to scale traditional methods of treating those with mental health issues, Chibanda helped to develop a beautiful solution powered by a limitless resource: grandmothers. In this extraordinary, inspirational talk, learn more about the friendship bench program, which trains grandmothers in evidence-based talk therapy and brings care, and hope, to those in need.

authortitle: The Holladay Brothers: To the beat of light
author: The Holladay Brothers
title: To the beat of light

authortitle: Tanmay Bakshi: Technology that tackles the teen suicide epidemic
author: Tanmay Bakshi
title: Technology that tackles the teen suicide epidemic

authortitle: Robin Hauser: Can we protect AI from our biases?
author: Robin Hauser
title: Can we protect AI from our biases?

authortitle: Rana Novack: How we'll predict the next refugee crisis
author: Rana Novack
title: How we'll predict the next refugee crisis

authortitle: Phil Tetlow: 8 steps to understanding information (and maybe the universe)
author: Phil Tetlow
title: 8 steps to understanding information (and maybe the universe)

authortitle: Natalie Gunn: The mind-body problem of scientific discovery
author: Natalie Gunn
title: The mind-body problem of scientific discovery

authortitle: IN-Q: A poet's plea to save our planet
author: IN-Q
title: A poet's plea to save our planet

authortitle: The Ferocious Few: "San Francisco"
author: The Ferocious Few
title: "San Francisco"

authortitle: Eleftheria Pissadaki: A mathematical model for predicting Parkinson's
author: Eleftheria Pissadaki
title: A mathematical model for predicting Parkinson's

authortitle: Bruno Michel: How our brains will keep up with AI
author: Bruno Michel
title: How our brains will keep up with AI

authortitle: Adam Cutler: Can we be friends with our AI?
author: Adam Cutler
title: Can we be friends with our AI?

authortitle: Vinith Misra: Machines need an algorithm for humor. This is what it looks like
author: Vinith Misra
title: Machines need an algorithm for humor. This is what it looks like

author: Shoel Perelman
title: How a company can nurture its internal rebels

authortitle: Robert Prill: The microbes in our food can save lives
author: Robert Prill
title: The microbes in our food can save lives

authortitle: Nir Eyal: What makes technology so habit-forming?
author: Nir Eyal
title: What makes technology so habit-forming?

authortitle: Maria Dubovitskaya: Take back control of your personal data
author: Maria Dubovitskaya
title: Take back control of your personal data

authortitle: Lloyd Treinish: This weather forecasting model is actually accurate
author: Lloyd Treinish
title: This weather forecasting model is actually accurate

authortitle: Lisa-Marie Johnston: "Home to Oakland" and "Walk Away"
author: Lisa-Marie Johnston
title: "Home to Oakland" and "Walk Away"

authortitle: Kala Fleming: Easing water scarcity by understanding when and where it flows
author: Kala Fleming
title: Easing water scarcity by understanding when and where it flows

authortitle: Jerry Chow: The future of supercomputers? A quantum chip colder than outer space
author: Jerry Chow
title: The future of supercomputers? A quantum chip colder than outer space

authortitle: Jeannette Garcia: A super-strong plastic that reverts to dust
author: Jeannette Garcia
title: A super-strong plastic that reverts to dust

authortitle: Jared Kleinert: Why millennials today hold more power than ever before
author: Jared Kleinert
title: Why millennials today hold more power than ever before

authortitle: Florian Pinel: How IBM's Watson is redefining the future of cooking
author: Florian Pinel
title: How IBM's Watson is redefining the future of cooking

authortitle: Charlene Li: Efficient leadership in the digital era
author: Charlene Li
title: Efficient leadership in the digital era

authortitle: Eric Mibuari: Can credit scores be determined by cellphone data?
author: Eric Mibuari
title: Can credit scores be determined by cellphone data?

authortitle: Aaron Horowitz: Can a teddybear change how children relate to their own disease?
author: Aaron Horowitz
title: Can a teddybear change how children relate to their own disease?

authortitle: Tan Le: How does the brain work in everyday situations?
author: Tan Le
title: How does the brain work in everyday situations?

authortitle: Monika Blaumueller: How we could use big data to forecast the next global outbreak
author: Monika Blaumueller
title: How we could use big data to forecast the next global outbreak

authortitle: Bhu Srinivasan: Capitalism isn't an ideology -- it's an operating system
author: Bhu Srinivasan
title: Capitalism isn't an ideology -- it's an operating system
description: Bhu Srinivasan researches the intersection of capitalism and technological progress. Instead of thinking about capitalism as a firm, unchanging ideology, he suggests that we should think of it as an operating system -- one that needs upgrades to keep up with innovation, like the impending take-off of drone delivery services. Learn more about the past and future of the free market (and a potential coming identity crisis for the United States' version of capitalism) with this quick, forward-thinking talk.

authortitle: Mike Sempert: "Good Morning Young Artist" and "Ms. Metronome"
author: Mike Sempert
title: "Good Morning Young Artist" and "Ms. Metronome"

authortitle: Marie Wallace: The ethics of collecting data
author: Marie Wallace
title: The ethics of collecting data

authortitle: Lisa Seacat DeLuca: A vision of the future from IBM's most prolific inventor
author: Lisa Seacat DeLuca
title: A vision of the future from IBM's most prolific inventor

authortitle: Kareem Yusuf: The importance of emotional tone in the digital age
author: Kareem Yusuf
title: The importance of emotional tone in the digital age

authortitle: Inhi Cho Suh: How to achieve more quality hospital care (with less noise)
author: Inhi Cho Suh
title: How to achieve more quality hospital care (with less noise)

authortitle: Bryan Kramer: Why social media is reimagining our future
author: Bryan Kramer
title: Why social media is reimagining our future

authortitle: Wobbly World: Diversity in harmony
author: Wobbly World
title: Diversity in harmony

authortitle: Villy Wang: A business against racism
author: Villy Wang
title: A business against racism

authortitle: Tim Exile: An instrument anyone can play
author: Tim Exile
title: An instrument anyone can play

authortitle: Laxmi Parida: What if the best fertilizer was an algorithm?
author: Laxmi Parida
title: What if the best fertilizer was an algorithm?

authortitle: Juliane Gallina: A library of minds
author: Juliane Gallina
title: A library of minds

authortitle: James Kozloski: Why the brain is simpler than we think
author: James Kozloski
title: Why the brain is simpler than we think

authortitle: Ise Lyfe: We are not mud
author: Ise Lyfe
title: We are not mud

authortitle: Bob Nease: How to trick yourself into good behavior
author: Bob Nease
title: How to trick yourself into good behavior

authortitle: Andrew Arruda: The world's first AI legal assistant
author: Andrew Arruda
title: The world's first AI legal assistant

authortitle: Valarie Kaur: 3 lessons of revolutionary love in a time of rage
author: Valarie Kaur
title: 3 lessons of revolutionary love in a time of rage
description: What's the antidote to rising nationalism, polarization and hate? In this inspiring, poetic talk, Valarie Kaur asks us to reclaim love as a revolutionary act. As she journeys from the birthing room to tragic sites of bloodshed, Kaur shows us how the choice to love can be a force for justice.

authortitle: Tito Deler: "My Fine Reward"
author: Tito Deler
title: "My Fine Reward"
description: Blues musician Tito Deler combines the sounds of his New York upbringing with the style of pre-war Mississippi Delta blues. He takes the stage, singing and strumming a stirring rendition of his song, "My Fine Reward."

authortitle: Zachariah Mampilly: How protest is redefining democracy around the world
author: Zachariah Mampilly
title: How protest is redefining democracy around the world
description: The democratic process is messy, complicated and often inefficient -- but across Africa, activists are redefining democracy by putting protest at its center. In an illuminating talk, political scientist Zachariah Mampilly gives us a primer on the current wave of protests reshaping countries like Tunisia, Malawi and Zimbabwe -- and explains how this form of political dissension expands our political imaginations beyond what we're told is possible.

authortitle: Mohamad Jebara: This company pays kids to do their math homework
author: Mohamad Jebara
title: This company pays kids to do their math homework
description: Mohamad Jebara loves mathematics -- but he's concerned that too many students grow up thinking that this beautiful, rewarding subject is difficult and boring. His company is experimenting with a bold idea: paying students for completing weekly math homework. He explores the ethics of this model and how it's helping students -- and why learning math is crucial in the era of fake news.

authortitle: John Cary: How architecture can create dignity for all
author: John Cary
title: How architecture can create dignity for all
description: If architect and writer John Cary has his way, women will never need to stand in pointlessly long bathroom lines again. Lines like these are representative of a more serious issue, Cary says: the lack of diversity in design that leads to thoughtless, compassionless spaces. Design has a unique ability to dignify and make people feel valued, respected, honored and seen -- but the flip side is also true. Cary calls for architects and designers to expand their ranks and commit to serving the public good, not just the privileged few. "Well-designed spaces are not just a matter of taste or a questions of aesthetics," he says. "They literally shape our ideas about who we are in the world and what we deserve." And we all deserve better.

authortitle: Su Kahumbu: How we can help hungry kids, one text at a time
author: Su Kahumbu
title: How we can help hungry kids, one text at a time
description: Su Kahumbu raises badass cows -- healthy, well-fed animals whose protein is key to solving a growing crisis in Africa: childhood nutritional stunting. With iCow, a simple SMS service she developed to support small-scale livestock farmers, the TED Fellow is helping farmers across the continent by texting them tips on caring for and raising animals. Learn more about how this cheap innovation is helping feed hungry kids, one text at a time.

authortitle: Karen Lloyd: This deep-sea mystery is changing our understanding of life
author: Karen Lloyd
title: This deep-sea mystery is changing our understanding of life
description: How deep into the Earth can we go and still find life? Marine microbiologist Karen Lloyd introduces us to deep-subsurface microbes: tiny organisms that live buried meters deep in ocean mud and have been on Earth since way before animals. Learn more about these mysterious microbes, which refuse to grow in the lab and seem to have a fundamentally different relationship with time and energy than we do.

authortitle: Guy Winch: How to fix a broken heart
author: Guy Winch
title: How to fix a broken heart
description: At some point in our lives, almost every one of us will have our heart broken. Imagine how different things would be if we paid more attention to this unique emotional pain. Psychologist Guy Winch reveals how recovering from heartbreak starts with a determination to fight our instincts to idealize and search for answers that aren't there -- and offers a toolkit on how to, eventually, move on. Our hearts might sometimes be broken, but we don't have to break with them.

authortitle: Stuart Duncan: How I use Minecraft to help kids with autism
author: Stuart Duncan
title: How I use Minecraft to help kids with autism
description: The internet can be an ugly place, but you won't find bullies or trolls on Stuart Duncan's Minecraft server, AutCraft. Designed for children with autism and their families, AutCraft creates a safe online environment for play and self-expression for kids who sometimes behave a bit differently than their peers (and who might be singled out elsewhere). Learn more about one of the best places on the internet with this heartwarming talk.

authortitle: Peter Ouko: From death row to law graduate
author: Peter Ouko
title: From death row to law graduate
description: Peter Ouko spent 18 years in Kamiti Prison in Kenya, sometimes locked up in a cell with 13 other grown men for 23 and a half hours a day. In a moving talk, he tells the story of how he was freed -- and his current mission with the African Prisons Project: to set up the first law school behind bars and empower people in prison to drive positive change.

authortitle: Danielle Wood: 6 space technologies we can use to improve life on Earth
author: Danielle Wood
title: 6 space technologies we can use to improve life on Earth
description: Danielle Wood leads the Space Enabled research group at the MIT Media Lab, where she works to tear down the barriers that limit the benefits of space exploration to only the few, the rich or the elite. She identifies six technologies developed for space exploration that can contribute to sustainable development across the world -- from observation satellites that provide information to aid organizations to medical research on microgravity that can be used to improve health care on Earth. "Space truly is useful for sustainable development for the benefit of all peoples," Wood says.

authortitle: Mwende "FreeQuency" Katwiwa: Black life at the intersection of birth and death
author: Mwende "FreeQuency" Katwiwa
title: Black life at the intersection of birth and death
description: "It is the artist's job to unearth stories that people try to bury with shovels of complacency and time," says poet and freedom fighter Mwende "FreeQuency" Katwiwa. Performing her poem "The Joys of Motherhood," Katwiwa explores the experience of Black mothers in America and discusses the impact of the Movement for Black Lives -- because, she says, it's impossible to separate the two.

authortitle: Anjali Kumar: My failed mission to find God -- and what I found instead
author: Anjali Kumar
title: My failed mission to find God -- and what I found instead
description: Anjali Kumar went looking for God and ended up finding something else entirely. In an uplifting, funny talk about our shared humanity, she takes us on a spiritual pilgrimage to meet witches in New York, a shaman in Peru, an infamous "healer" in Brazil and others, sharing an important lesson: what binds us together is far stronger than what separates us, and our differences are not insurmountable.

authortitle: Tim Exile: Finding music in mundanity
author: Tim Exile
title: Finding music in mundanity

authortitle: Lena Bieber: Using happiness to evaluate a company's success
author: Lena Bieber
title: Using happiness to evaluate a company's success

authortitle: Emilie Weight: 3 things I learned from my intellectually disabled son
author: Emilie Weight
title: 3 things I learned from my intellectually disabled son

authortitle: Dan Walker: Can we "print" smart objects?
author: Dan Walker
title: Can we "print" smart objects?

authortitle: Christian Wickert: How fiction can help us better understand our reality
author: Christian Wickert
title: How fiction can help us better understand our reality

authortitle: Christian Schröter: How we're tracking medical donations across the world
author: Christian Schröter
title: How we're tracking medical donations across the world

authortitle: Carl Vause: Meet the robot designed like an octopus tentacle
author: Carl Vause
title: Meet the robot designed like an octopus tentacle

authortitle: Bijan Zakeri: From flesh eating bacteria to molecular superglue
author: Bijan Zakeri
title: From flesh eating bacteria to molecular superglue

authortitle: Mike Gil: Could fish social networks help us save coral reefs?
author: Mike Gil
title: Could fish social networks help us save coral reefs?
description: Mike Gil spies on fish: using novel multi-camera systems and computer vision technology, the TED Fellow and his colleagues explore how coral reef fish behave, socialize and affect their ecosystems. Learn more about how fish of different species communicate via social networks -- and what disrupting these networks might mean to the delicate ecology of reefs, which help feed millions of us and support the global economy.

authortitle: Amar Inamdar: The thrilling potential for off-grid solar energy
author: Amar Inamdar
title: The thrilling potential for off-grid solar energy
description: There's an energy revolution happening in villages and towns across Africa -- off-grid solar energy is becoming a viable alternative to traditional electricity systems. In a bold talk about a true leapfrog moment, Amar Inamdar introduces us to proud owners of off-grid solar kits -- and explains how this technology has the opportunity to meet two extraordinary goals: energy access for all and a low-carbon future. "Every household a proud producer as well as consumer of energy," Inamdar says. "That's the democracy of energy." (Followed by a brief Q&A with TED Curator Chris Anderson)

authortitle: Leila Takayama: What's it like to be a robot?
author: Leila Takayama
title: What's it like to be a robot?
description: We already live among robots: tools and machines like dishwashers and thermostats so integrated into our lives that we'd never think to call them that. What will a future with even more robots look like? Social scientist Leila Takayama shares some unique challenges of designing for human-robot interactions -- and how experimenting with robotic futures actually leads us to a better understanding of ourselves.

authortitle: David Katz: The surprising solution to ocean plastic
author: David Katz
title: The surprising solution to ocean plastic
description: Can we solve the problem of ocean plastic pollution and end extreme poverty at the same time? That's the ambitious goal of The Plastic Bank: a worldwide chain of stores where everything from school tuition to cooking fuel and more is available for purchase in exchange for plastic garbage -- which is then sorted, shredded and sold to brands who reuse "social plastic" in their products. Join David Katz to learn more about this step towards closing the loop in the circular economy. "Preventing ocean plastic could be humanity's richest opportunity," Katz says.

authortitle: George Steinmetz: Photos of Africa, taken from a flying lawn chair
author: George Steinmetz
title: Photos of Africa, taken from a flying lawn chair
description: George Steinmetz's spectacular photos show Africa from the air, taken from the world's slowest, lightest aircraft. Join Steinmetz to discover the surprising historical, ecological and sociopolitical patterns that emerge when you go low and slow in a flying lawn chair.

authortitle: Edsel Salvaña: The dangerous evolution of HIV
author: Edsel Salvaña
title: The dangerous evolution of HIV
description: Think we're winning the battle against HIV? Maybe not, as the next wave of drug-resistant viruses arrives. In an eye-opening talk, TED Fellow Edsel Salvana describes the aggressive HIV subtype AE that's currently plaguing his home of the Philippines -- and warns us about what might become a global epidemic.

authortitle: Wendy Woods: The business benefits of doing good
author: Wendy Woods
title: The business benefits of doing good
description: "The only way we're going to make substantial progress on the challenging problems of our time is for business to drive the solutions," says social impact strategist Wendy Woods. In a data-packed talk, Woods shares a fresh way to assess the impact all parts of business can have on all parts of society, and then adjust them to not only do less harm but actually improve things. Learn more about how executives can move beyond corporate social responsibility to "total societal impact" -- for the benefit of both a company's bottom line and society at large.

authortitle: Naoko Ishii: An economic case for protecting the planet
author: Naoko Ishii
title: An economic case for protecting the planet
description: We all share one planet -- we breathe the same air, drink the same water and depend on the same oceans, forests and biodiversity. Economist Naoko Ishii is on a mission to protect these shared resources, known as the global commons, that are vital for our survival. In an eye-opening talk about the wellness of the planet, Ishii outlines four economic systems we need to change to safeguard the global commons, making the case for a new kind of social contract with the earth.

authortitle: Azim Khamisa and Ples Felix: What comes after tragedy? Forgiveness
author: Azim Khamisa and Ples Felix
title: What comes after tragedy? Forgiveness
description: On one awful night in 1995, Ples Felix's 14-year-old grandson murdered Azim Khamisa's son in a gang initiation fueled by drugs, alcohol and a false sense of belonging. The deadly encounter sent Khamisa and Felix down paths of deep meditation, to forgive and to be forgiven -- and in an act of bravery and reconciliation, the two men met and forged a lasting bond. Together, they've used their story as an outline for a better, more merciful society, where victims of tragedy can grow and heal. Prepare to be moved by their unimaginable story. "Peace is possible," Khamisa says. "How do I know that? Because I am at peace."

authortitle: Cleo Wade: Want to change the world? Start by being brave enough to care
author: Cleo Wade
title: Want to change the world? Start by being brave enough to care
description: Artist and poet Cleo Wade recites a moving poem about being an advocate for love and acceptance in a time when both seem in short supply. Woven between stories of people at the beginning and end of their lives, she shares some truths about growing up (and speaking up) and reflects on the wisdom of a life well-lived, leaving us with a simple yet enduring takeaway: be good to yourself, be good to others, be good to the earth. "The world will say to you, 'Be a better person,'" Wade says. "Do not be afraid to say, 'Yes.'"

authortitle: Anna Rosling Rönnlund: See how the rest of the world lives, organized by income
author: Anna Rosling Rönnlund
title: See how the rest of the world lives, organized by income
description: What does it look like when someone in Sweden brushes their teeth or when someone in Rwanda makes their bed? Anna Rosling Rönnlund wants all of us to find out, so she sent photographers to 264 homes in 50 countries (and counting!) to document the stoves, bed, toilets, toys and more in households from every income bracket around the world. See how families live in Latvia or Burkina Faso or Peru as Rosling Rönnlund explains the power of data visualization to help us better understand the world.

authortitle: Bob Inglis: American bipartisan politics can be saved -- here's how
author: Bob Inglis
title: American bipartisan politics can be saved -- here's how
description: Former Republican member of the U.S. Congress Bob Inglis shares an optimistic message about how conservatives can lead on climate change and other pressing problems -- and how free enterprise (and working together across ideologies) hold the solutions. "The United States was not built by those who waited and wished to look behind them," Inglis says. "Lead now ... Tell the American people that we still have moon shots in us."

authortitle: Scott Williams: The hidden role informal caregivers play in health care
author: Scott Williams
title: The hidden role informal caregivers play in health care
description: Once a cared-for patient and now a caregiver himself, Scott Williams highlights the invaluable role of informal caregivers -- those friends and relatives who, out of love, go the extra mile for patients in need. From personal care to advocacy to emotional support, unpaid caregivers form the invisible backbone of health and social systems all over the world, Williams says -- and without them, these systems would crumble. "How can we make sure that their value to patients and society is recognized?" he asks.

authortitle: Michelle Knox: Talk about your death while you're still healthy
author: Michelle Knox
title: Talk about your death while you're still healthy
description: Do you know what you want when you die? Do you know how you want to be remembered? In a candid, heartfelt talk about a subject most of us would rather not discuss, Michelle Knox asks each of us to reflect on our core values around death and share them with our loved ones, so they can make informed decisions without fear of having failed to honor our legacies. "Life would be a lot easier to live if we talked about death now," Knox says. "We need to discuss these issues when we are fit and healthy so we can take the emotion out of it -- and then we can learn not just what is important, but why it's important."

authortitle: Matt Goldman: The search for "aha!" moments
author: Matt Goldman
title: The search for "aha!" moments
description: In 1988, Matt Goldman co-founded Blue Man Group, an off-Broadway production that became a sensation known for its humor, blue body paint and wild stunts. The show works on the premise that certain conditions can create "aha moments" -- moments of surprise, learning and exuberance -- frequent and intentional rather than random and occasional. Now Goldman is working to apply the lessons learned from Blue Man Group to education, creating Blue School, a school that balances academic mastery, creative thinking and self and social intelligence. "We need to cultivate safe and conducive conditions for new and innovative ideas to evolve and thrive," Goldman says.

authortitle: Vivek Maru: How to put the power of law in people's hands
author: Vivek Maru
title: How to put the power of law in people's hands
description: What can you do when the wheels of justice don't turn fast enough? Or when they don't turn at all? Vivek Maru is working to transform the relationship between people and law, turning law from an abstraction or threat into something that everyone can understand, use and shape. Instead of relying solely on lawyers, Maru started a global network of community paralegals, or barefoot lawyers, who serve in their own communities and break the law down into simple terms to help people find solutions. Learn more about how this innovative approach to using the law is helping socially excluded people claim their rights. "A little bit of legal empowerment can go a long way," Maru says.

authortitle: Jacob Collier: A one-man musical phenomenon
author: Jacob Collier
title: A one-man musical phenomenon
description: Jacob Collier is a one-man band and force of nature. In a dynamic, colorful performance, he recreates the magical room at his home in London where he produces music, performing three songs in which he sings every part and plays every instrument -- accompanied by kaleidoscopic visuals that take cues from the music and grow in real time.

authortitle: Marily Oppezzo: Want to be more creative? Go for a walk
author: Marily Oppezzo
title: Want to be more creative? Go for a walk
description: When trying to come up with a new idea, we all have times when we get stuck. But according to research by behavioral and learning scientist Marily Oppezzo, getting up and going for a walk might be all it takes to get your creative juices flowing. In this fun, fast talk, she explains how walking could help you get the most out of your next brainstorm.

authortitle: Alexis Charpentier: How record collectors find lost music and preserve our cultural heritage
author: Alexis Charpentier
title: How record collectors find lost music and preserve our cultural heritage
description: For generations, record collectors have played a vital role in the preservation of musical and cultural heritage by "digging" for obscure music created by overlooked artists. Alexis Charpentier shares his love of records -- and stories of how collectors have given forgotten music a second chance at being heard. Learn more about the culture of record digging (and, maybe, pick up a new hobby) with this fun, refreshing talk.

authortitle: Kevin Njabo: How we can stop Africa's scientific brain drain
author: Kevin Njabo
title: How we can stop Africa's scientific brain drain
description: How can Africans find solutions to Africa's problems? Conservation biologist Kevin Njabo tells his personal story of how he nearly became part of the group of African scientists who seek an education abroad and never return -- and why he's now building a permanent base on the continent to nurture and support local talent. "I'm not coming back alone. I'm bringing with me Western scientists, entrepreneurs and students," Njabo says. "When that happens, Africa will be on the way to solving Africa's problems."

authortitle: Soyapi Mumba: Medical tech designed to meet Africa's needs
author: Soyapi Mumba
title: Medical tech designed to meet Africa's needs
description: In sub-Saharan Africa, power outages, low technology penetration, slow internet and understaffed hospitals plague health care systems. To make progress on these problems in Malawi, TED Fellow Soyapi Mumba and his team created a new system from scratch -- from the software that powers their electronic health records to the infrastructure used to support it. In this quick, hopeful talk, Mumba shares how his jack-of-all-trades mindset can help reshape health care in low-resource environments.

authortitle: Mindy Scheier: How adaptive clothing empowers people with disabilities
author: Mindy Scheier
title: How adaptive clothing empowers people with disabilities
description: Do you have a favorite T-shirt or pair of jeans that transforms you and makes you feel confident -- makes you feel like you? That's because what you wear can affect your mood, your health and your self-esteem, says fashion designer Mindy Scheier. Inspired by her son, who was born with a degenerative disorder that makes it hard for him to dress himself or wear clothing with buttons or zippers, Scheier set out to make clothing that works for everyone, including the differently abled. Learn more about how she's made fashion history by producing the world's first mainstream adaptive clothing line.

authortitle: Tomas Elemans: The inspiring truth in fiction
author: Tomas Elemans
title: The inspiring truth in fiction

authortitle: Steve Brown: How data is driving the future of fashion
author: Steve Brown
title: How data is driving the future of fashion

authortitle: Touria El Glaoui:  Inside Africa's thriving art scene
author: Touria El Glaoui
title: Inside Africa's thriving art scene

authortitle: Daniela Zamudio: A millennial's unexpected secret to success
author: Daniela Zamudio
title: A millennial's unexpected secret to success

authortitle: Nicole Wilson: Lessons from a lifetime of bad advice
author: Nicole Wilson
title: Lessons from a lifetime of bad advice

authortitle: Dwight Stitt: One dad's mission to rebuild bonds between kids and their fathers
author: Dwight Stitt
title: One dad's mission to rebuild bonds between kids and their fathers

authortitle: Gabriela Roa: How a child's mess could help you rediscover your creativity
author: Gabriela Roa
title: How a child's mess could help you rediscover your creativity

authortitle: Irene Mora: For women in pursuit of motherhood and a career
author: Irene Mora
title: For women in pursuit of motherhood and a career

authortitle: Andrew Millar: Why your business needs dissenters
author: Andrew Millar
title: Why your business needs dissenters

authortitle: Jonathan Koch: A data translation toolkit that anyone can use
author: Jonathan Koch
title: A data translation toolkit that anyone can use

authortitle: Mahir Can Işik: How companies predict fashion trends and kill individuality
author: Mahir Can Işik
title: How companies predict fashion trends and kill individuality

authortitle: Arik Hartmann: Our treatment of HIV has advanced. Why hasn't the stigma changed?
author: Arik Hartmann
title: Our treatment of HIV has advanced. Why hasn't the stigma changed?
description: The treatment of HIV has significantly advanced over the past three decades -- why hasn't our perception of people with the disease advanced along with it? After being diagnosed with HIV, Arik Hartmann chose to live transparently, being open about his status, in an effort to educate people. In this candid, personal talk, he shares what it's like to live with HIV -- and calls on us to dismiss our misconceptions about the disease.

authortitle: Lana Mazahreh: 3 thoughtful ways to conserve water
author: Lana Mazahreh
title: 3 thoughtful ways to conserve water
description: According to the UN, nearly one in three people worldwide live in a country facing a water crisis, and less than five percent of the world lives in a country that has more water today than it did 20 years ago. Lana Mazahreh grew up in Jordan, a state that has experienced absolute water scarcity since 1973, where she learned how to conserve water as soon as she was old enough to learn how to write her name. In this practical talk, she shares three lessons from water-poor countries on how to save water and address what's fast becoming a global crisis.

authortitle: Lisa Feldman Barrett: You aren't at the mercy of your emotions -- your brain creates them
author: Lisa Feldman Barrett
title: You aren't at the mercy of your emotions -- your brain creates them
description: Can you look at someone's face and know what they're feeling? Does everyone experience happiness, sadness and anxiety the same way? What are emotions anyway? For the past 25 years, psychology professor Lisa Feldman Barrett has mapped facial expressions, scanned brains and analyzed hundreds of physiology studies to understand what emotions really are. She shares the results of her exhaustive research -- and explains how we may have more control over our emotions than we think.

authortitle: Christopher Ategeka: How adoption worked for me
author: Christopher Ategeka
title: How adoption worked for me
description: Talent is universal, but opportunity isn't, says TED Fellow Christopher Ategeka. In this charming, hopeful talk, Ategeka tells his story of being orphaned at a young age -- and how being adopted gave him the chance to experience a new culture, acquire an education and live up to his full potential. "We may not be able to solve the bigotry and the racism of this world today," Ategeka says, "But certainly we can raise children to create a positive, inclusive, connected world full of empathy, love and compassion."

authortitle: Brian Christian: How to manage your time more effectively (according to machines)
author: Brian Christian
title: How to manage your time more effectively (according to machines)

authortitle: Heather Lanier: "Good" and "bad" are incomplete stories we tell ourselves
author: Heather Lanier
title: "Good" and "bad" are incomplete stories we tell ourselves
description: Heather Lanier's daughter Fiona has Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome, a genetic condition that results in developmental delays -- but that doesn't make her tragic, angelic or any of the other stereotypes about kids like her. In this talk about the beautiful, complicated, joyful and hard journey of raising a rare girl, Lanier questions our assumptions about what makes a life "good" or "bad," challenging us to stop fixating on solutions for whatever we deem not normal, and instead to take life as it comes.

authortitle: Christian Benimana: The next generation of African architects and designers
author: Christian Benimana
title: The next generation of African architects and designers
description: Christian Benimana wants to build a network of architects who can help Africa's booming cities flourish in sustainable, equitable ways -- balancing growth with values that are uniquely African. From Nigeria to Burkina Faso and beyond, he shares examples of architecture bringing communities together. A pan-African movement of architects, designers and engineers on the continent and in diaspora are learning from and inspiring each other, and Benimana invites us to imagine future African cities as the most resilient, socially inclusive places on earth.

authortitle: Deb Willis and Hank Willis Thomas: A mother and son united by love and art
author: Deb Willis and Hank Willis Thomas
title: A mother and son united by love and art

authortitle: Yvette Alberdingk Thijm: The power of citizen video to create undeniable truths
author: Yvette Alberdingk Thijm
title: The power of citizen video to create undeniable truths
description: Could smartphones and cameras be our most powerful weapons for social justice? Through her organization Witness, Yvette Alberdingk Thijm is developing strategies and technologies to help activists use video to protect and defend human rights. She shares stories of the growing power of distant witnesses -- and a call to use the powerful tools at our disposal to capture incidents of injustice.

authortitle: Joel Jackson: A vehicle built in Africa, for Africa
author: Joel Jackson
title: A vehicle built in Africa, for Africa
description: Joel Jackson wants to reimagine transportation around the needs of the African consumer. He's designed an SUV that's rugged enough for long stretches of uneven terrain and affordable enough to be within reach of those who need it most. Learn more about the challenges of mobility and manufacturing in Africa -- and what a localized motor industry could mean for the future of the continent.

authortitle: Tiffany Watt Smith: The history of human emotions
author: Tiffany Watt Smith
title: The history of human emotions
description: The words we use to describe our emotions affect how we feel, says historian Tiffany Watt Smith, and they've often changed (sometimes very dramatically) in response to new cultural expectations and ideas. Take nostalgia, for instance: first defined in 1688 as an illness and considered deadly, today it's seen as a much less serious affliction. In this fascinating talk about the history of emotions, learn more about how the language we use to describe how we feel continues to evolve -- and pick up some new words used in different cultures to capture those fleeting feelings in words.

authortitle: Javed Akhtar: The gift of words
author: Javed Akhtar
title: The gift of words
description: "Do you know what I mean?" Legendary poet, lyricist and screenwriter Javed Akhtar asks why we seem to be losing our power to use words -- and inspires us to better understand and communicate with one another using this near-magical tool that carries our culture across generations. (In Hindi with English subtitles)

authortitle: Atul Gawande: Want to get great at something? Get a coach
author: Atul Gawande
title: Want to get great at something? Get a coach
description: How do we improve in the face of complexity? Atul Gawande has studied this question with a surgeon's precision. He shares what he's found to be the key: having a good coach to provide a more accurate picture of our reality, to instill positive habits of thinking, and to break our actions down and then help us build them back up again. "It's not how good you are now; it's how good you're going to be that really matters," Gawande says.

authortitle: Angela Wang: How China is changing the future of shopping
author: Angela Wang
title: How China is changing the future of shopping
description: China is a huge laboratory of innovation, says retail expert Angela Wang, and in this lab, everything takes place on people's phones. Five hundred million Chinese consumers -- the equivalent of the combined populations of the US, UK and Germany -- regularly make purchases via mobile platforms, even in brick-and-mortar stores. What will this transformation mean for the future of shopping? Learn more about the new business-as-usual, where everything is ultra-convenient, ultra-flexible and ultra-social.

authortitle: David Brenner: A new weapon in the fight against superbugs
author: David Brenner
title: A new weapon in the fight against superbugs
description: Since the widespread use of antibiotics began in the 1940s, we've tried to develop new drugs faster than bacteria can evolve -- but this strategy isn't working. Drug-resistant bacteria known as superbugs killed nearly 700,000 people last year, and by 2050 that number could be 10 million -- more than cancer kills each year. Can physics help? In a talk from the frontiers of science, radiation scientist David Brenner shares his work studying a potentially life-saving weapon: a wavelength of ultraviolet light known as far-UVC, which can kill superbugs safely, without penetrating our skin. Followed by a Q&A with TED Curator Chris Anderson.

authortitle: Kamau Gachigi: Success stories from Kenya's first makerspace
author: Kamau Gachigi
title: Success stories from Kenya's first makerspace
description: Africa needs engineers, but its engineering students often end up working at auditing firms and banks. Why? Kamau Gachigi suspects it's because they don't have the spaces and materials needed to test their ideas and start businesses. To solve this problem, Gachigi started Gearbox, a makerspace and hardware accelerator that provides a rapid prototyping environment for both professionals and people with no formal engineering background. In this forward-thinking talk, he shares some of the extraordinary projects and innovations coming out of his Kenyan fab lab.

authortitle: Miho Janvier: Lessons from a solar storm chaser
author: Miho Janvier
title: Lessons from a solar storm chaser
description: Space physicist Miho Janvier studies solar storms: giant clouds of particles that escape from the Sun and can disrupt life on Earth (while also producing amazing auroras). How do you study the atmosphere on the Sun, which burns at temperatures of up to around 10 million degrees Kelvin? With math! Join the TED Fellow as she shares her work trying to better understand how the Sun affects us here on Earth.

authortitle: Joan Blades and John Gable: Free yourself from your filter bubbles
author: Joan Blades and John Gable
title: Free yourself from your filter bubbles
description: Joan Blades and John Gable want you to make friends with people who vote differently than you do. A pair of political opposites, the two longtime pals know the value of engaging in honest conversations with people you don't immediately agree with. Join them as they explain how to bridge the gaps in understanding between people on opposite sides of the political spectrum -- and create opportunities for mutual listening and consideration (and, maybe, lasting friendships).

authortitle: Xavier De Kestelier: Adventures of an interplanetary architect
author: Xavier De Kestelier
title: Adventures of an interplanetary architect
description: How will we live elsewhere in the galaxy? On Earth, natural resources for creating structures are abundant, but sending these materials up with us to the Moon or Mars is clunky and cost-prohibitive. Enter architect Xavier De Kestelier, who has a radical plan to use robots and space dust to 3D print our interplanetary homes. Learn more about the emerging field of space architecture with this fascinating talk about the (potentially) not-too-distant future.

authortitle: Gautam Bhan: A bold plan to house 100 million people
author: Gautam Bhan
title: A bold plan to house 100 million people
description: Mumbai, Delhi, Chennai, Kolkata -- all the major cities across India have one great thing in common: they welcome people arriving in search of work. But what lies at the other end of such openness and acceptance? Sadly, a shortage of housing for an estimated 100 million people, many of whom end up living in informal settlements. Gautam Bhan, a human settlement expert and researcher, is boldly reimagining a solution to this problem. He shares a new vision of urban India where everyone has a safe, sturdy home. (In Hindi with English subtitles)

authortitle: Nadine Hachach-Haram: How augmented reality could change the future of surgery
author: Nadine Hachach-Haram
title: How augmented reality could change the future of surgery
description: If you're undergoing surgery, you want the best surgical team to collaborate on your case, no matter where they are. Surgeon and entrepreneur Nadine Hachach-Haram is developing a new system that helps surgeons operate together and train one another on new techniques -- from remote locations using low-cost augmented reality tools. Watch the system in action as she joins a surgeon in Minnesota performing a knee surgery, live on her laptop from the TED stage in New Orleans. As Hachach-Haram says: "Through simple, everyday devices that we take for granted, we can really do miraculous things." (This talk contains graphic images of surgery.)

authortitle: Devita Davison: How urban agriculture is transforming Detroit
author: Devita Davison
title: How urban agriculture is transforming Detroit
description: There's something amazing growing in the city of Detroit: healthy, accessible, delicious, fresh food. In a spirited talk, fearless farmer Devita Davison explains how features of Detroit's decay actually make it an ideal spot for urban agriculture. Join Davison for a walk through neighborhoods in transformation as she shares stories of opportunity and hope. "These aren't plots of land where we're just growing tomatoes and carrots," Davison says. "We're building social cohesion as well as providing healthy, fresh food."

authortitle: Dao Nguyen: What makes something go viral?
author: Dao Nguyen
title: What makes something go viral?
description: What's the secret to making content people love? Join BuzzFeed's Publisher Dao Nguyen for a glimpse at how her team creates their tempting quizzes, lists and videos -- and learn more about how they've developed a system to understand how people use content to connect and create culture.

authortitle: Alastair Gray: How fake handbags fund terrorism and organized crime
author: Alastair Gray
title: How fake handbags fund terrorism and organized crime
description: What's the harm in buying a knock-off purse or a fake designer watch? According to counterfeit investigator Alastair Gray, fakes like these fund terrorism and organized crime. Learn more about the trillion-dollar underground economy of counterfeiting -- from the criminal organizations that run it to the child labor they use to produce its goods -- as well as measures you can take to help stop it. "Let's shine a light on the dark forces of counterfeiting that are hiding in plain sight," Gray says.

authortitle: Martina Flor: The secret language of letter design
author: Martina Flor
title: The secret language of letter design
description: Look at the letters around you: on street signs, stores, restaurant menus, the covers of books. Whether you realize it or not, the letters are speaking to you, telling you something beyond the literal text -- that whatever they represent is modern or finely crafted or fantastical or zany. Learn to decode this secret language with lettering designer Martina Flor as she explains how altering the shapes, colors and textures of letters changes how we perceive them. (In Spanish with English subtitles)

authortitle: Dan Gartenberg: The brain benefits of deep sleep -- and how to get more of it
author: Dan Gartenberg
title: The brain benefits of deep sleep -- and how to get more of it
description: There's nothing quite like a good night's sleep. What if technology could help us get more out of it?
