authortitle: Jonathan Drori: Why we're storing billions of seeds
author: Jonathan Drori
title: Why we're storing billions of seeds
description: In this brief talk from TED U 2009, Jonathan Drori encourages us to save biodiversity -- one seed at a time. Reminding us that plants support human life, he shares the vision of the Millennium Seed Bank, which has stored over 3 billion seeds to date from dwindling yet essential plant species.

authortitle: Joachim de Posada: Don't eat the marshmallow!
author: Joachim de Posada
title: Don't eat the marshmallow!
description: In this short talk from TED U, Joachim de Posada shares a landmark experiment on delayed gratification -- and how it can predict future success. With priceless video of kids trying their hardest not to eat the marshmallow.

authortitle: Yves Béhar: A supercharged motorcycle design
author: Yves Béhar
title: A supercharged motorcycle design

authortitle: Carolyn Porco: Could a Saturn moon harbor life?
author: Carolyn Porco
title: Could a Saturn moon harbor life?
description: Carolyn Porco shares exciting new findings from the Cassini spacecraft's recent sweep of one of Saturn's moons, Enceladus. Samples gathered from the moon's icy geysers hint that an ocean under its surface could harbor life.

authortitle: Mary Roach: 10 things you didn't know about orgasm
author: Mary Roach
title: 10 things you didn't know about orgasm
description: "Bonk" author Mary Roach delves into obscure scientific research, some of it centuries old, to make 10 surprising claims about sexual climax, ranging from the bizarre to the hilarious. (This talk is aimed at adults. Viewer discretion advised.)

authortitle: Dan Ariely: Are we in control of our own decisions?
author: Dan Ariely
title: Are we in control of our own decisions?
description: Behavioral economist Dan Ariely, the author of Predictably Irrational, uses classic visual illusions and his own counterintuitive (and sometimes shocking) research findings to show how we're not as rational as we think when we make decisions.

authortitle: Ray Anderson: The business logic of sustainability
author: Ray Anderson
title: The business logic of sustainability
description: At his carpet company, Ray Anderson has increased sales and doubled profits while turning the traditional "take / make / waste" industrial system on its head. In a gentle, understated way, he shares a powerful vision for sustainable commerce.

authortitle: Naturally 7: A full-band beatbox
author: Naturally 7
title: A full-band beatbox
description: One-of-a-kind R&B group Naturally 7 beatboxes an orchestra's worth of instruments to groove through their smooth single, "Fly Baby."

authortitle: Nandan Nilekani: Ideas for India's future
author: Nandan Nilekani
title: Ideas for India's future
description: Nandan Nilekani, the visionary co-founder of outsourcing pioneer Infosys, explains four brands of ideas that will determine whether India can continue its recent breakneck progress.

authortitle: Hans Rosling: Insights on HIV, in stunning data visuals
author: Hans Rosling
title: Insights on HIV, in stunning data visuals
description: Hans Rosling unveils data visuals that untangle the complex risk factors of one of the world's deadliest (and most misunderstood) diseases: HIV. By following the data, he suggests a surprising key to ending the epidemic.

authortitle: Eric Lewis: Chaos and harmony on piano
author: Eric Lewis
title: Chaos and harmony on piano
description: Eric Lewis explores the piano's expressive power as he pounds and caresses the keys (and the strings) in a performance during the 2009 TED Prize session. He plays an original song, a tribute to ocean and sky and the vision of the TED Prize winners.

authortitle: Seth Godin: The tribes we lead
author: Seth Godin
title: The tribes we lead
description: Seth Godin argues the Internet has ended mass marketing and revived a human social unit from the distant past: tribes. Founded on shared ideas and values, tribes give ordinary people the power to lead and make big change. He urges us to do so.

authortitle: Al Gore: What comes after An Inconvenient Truth?
author: Al Gore
title: What comes after An Inconvenient Truth?
description: At TED2009, Al Gore presents updated slides from around the globe to make the case that worrying climate trends are even worse than scientists predicted, and to make clear his stance on "clean coal."

authortitle: Louise Fresco: We need to feed the whole world
author: Louise Fresco
title: We need to feed the whole world
description: Louise Fresco shows us why we should celebrate mass-produced, supermarket-style white bread. She says environmentally sound mass production will feed the world, yet leave a role for small bakeries and traditional methods.

authortitle: Tom Shannon: Anti-gravity sculpture
author: Tom Shannon
title: Anti-gravity sculpture
description: Tom Shannon shows off his gravity-defying, otherworldly sculpture -- made of simple, earthly materials -- that floats and spins like planets on magnets and suspension wire. It's science-inspired art at its most heavenly.

authortitle: Mae Jemison: Teach arts and sciences together
author: Mae Jemison
title: Teach arts and sciences together
description: Mae Jemison is an astronaut, a doctor, an art collector, a dancer ... Telling stories from her own education and from her time in space, she calls on educators to teach both the arts and sciences, both intuition and logic, as one -- to create bold thinkers.

authortitle: Sean Gourley: The mathematics of war
author: Sean Gourley
title: The mathematics of war
description: By analyzing raw data on violent incidents in the Iraq war and others, Sean Gourley and his team claim to have found a surprisingly strong mathematical relationship linking the fatality and frequency of attacks.

authortitle: Brian Cox: What went wrong at the LHC
author: Brian Cox
title: What went wrong at the LHC
description: In this short talk from TED U 2009, Brian Cox shares what's new with the CERN supercollider. He covers the repairs now underway and what the future holds for the largest science experiment ever attempted.

authortitle: Laurie Garrett: Lessons from the 1918 flu
author: Laurie Garrett
title: Lessons from the 1918 flu
description: In 2007, as the world worried about a possible avian flu epidemic, Laurie Garrett, author of "The Coming Plague," gave this powerful talk to a small TED University audience. Her insights from past pandemics are suddenly more relevant than ever.

authortitle: Sarah Jones: A one-woman global village
author: Sarah Jones
title: A one-woman global village
description: In this hilariously lively performance, actress Sarah Jones channels an opinionated elderly Jewish woman, a fast-talking Dominican college student and more, giving TED2009 just a sample of her spectacular character range.

authortitle: Michael Merzenich: Growing evidence of brain plasticity
author: Michael Merzenich
title: Growing evidence of brain plasticity
description: Neuroscientist Michael Merzenich looks at one of the secrets of the brain's incredible power: its ability to actively re-wire itself. He's researching ways to harness the brain's plasticity to enhance our skills and recover lost function.

authortitle: Alex Tabarrok: How ideas trump crises
author: Alex Tabarrok
title: How ideas trump crises
description: The "dismal science" truly shines in this optimistic talk, as economist Alex Tabarrok argues free trade and globalization are shaping our once-divided world into a community of idea-sharing more healthy, happy and prosperous than anyone's predictions.

authortitle: Ben Katchor: Comics of bygone New York
author: Ben Katchor
title: Comics of bygone New York
description: In this captivating talk from the TED archive, cartoonist Ben Katchor reads from his comic strips. These perceptive, surreal stories find the profound hopes and foibles of history (and modern New York) preserved in objects like light switches and signs.

authortitle: Nate Silver: Does racism affect how you vote?
author: Nate Silver
title: Does racism affect how you vote?
description: Nate Silver has data that answers big questions about race in politics. For instance, in the 2008 presidential race, did Obama's skin color actually keep him from getting votes in some parts of the country? Stats and myths collide in this fascinating talk that ends with a remarkable insight.

authortitle: Erik Hersman: Reporting crisis via texting
author: Erik Hersman
title: Reporting crisis via texting
description: At TEDU 2009, Erik Hersman presents the remarkable story of Ushahidi, a GoogleMap mashup that allowed Kenyans to report and track violence via cell phone texts following the 2008 elections, and has evolved to continue saving lives in other countries.

authortitle: Niels Diffrient: Rethinking the way we sit down
author: Niels Diffrient
title: Rethinking the way we sit down
description: Design legend Niels Diffrient talks about his life in industrial design (and the reason he became a designer instead of a jet pilot). He details his quest to completely rethink the office chair starting from one fundamental data set: the human body.

authortitle: Margaret Wertheim: The beautiful math of coral
author: Margaret Wertheim
title: The beautiful math of coral
description: Margaret Wertheim leads a project to re-create the creatures of the coral reefs using a crochet technique invented by a mathematician -- celebrating the amazements of the reef, and deep-diving into the hyperbolic geometry underlying coral creation.

authortitle: Matthew Childs: 9 life lessons from rock climbing
author: Matthew Childs
title: 9 life lessons from rock climbing
description: In this talk from TED University 2009, veteran rock climber Matthew Childs shares nine pointers for rock climbing. These handy tips bear on an effective life at sea level, too.

authortitle: Tim Ferriss: Smash fear, learn anything
author: Tim Ferriss
title: Smash fear, learn anything
description: From the EG conference: Productivity guru Tim Ferriss' fun, encouraging anecdotes show how one simple question -- "What's the worst that could happen?" -- is all you need to learn to do anything.

authortitle: JoAnn Kuchera-Morin: Stunning data visualization in the AlloSphere
author: JoAnn Kuchera-Morin
title: Stunning data visualization in the AlloSphere
description: JoAnn Kuchera-Morin demos the AlloSphere, a new way to see, hear and interpret scientific data. Dive into the brain, feel electron spin, hear the music of the elements ... and detect previously unseen patterns that could lead to new discoveries.

authortitle: Gregory Stock: To upgrade is human
author: Gregory Stock
title: To upgrade is human
description: In this prophetic 2003 talk -- just days before Dolly the sheep was stuffed -- biotech ethicist Gregory Stock looked forward to new, more meaningful (and controversial) technologies, like customizable babies, whose adoption might drive human evolution.

authortitle: Shai Agassi: A new ecosystem for electric cars
author: Shai Agassi
title: A new ecosystem for electric cars
description: Forget about the hybrid auto -- Shai Agassi says it's electric cars or bust if we want to impact emissions. His company, Better Place, has a radical plan to take entire countries oil-free by 2020.

authortitle: Renny Gleeson: Our antisocial phone tricks
author: Renny Gleeson
title: Our antisocial phone tricks
description: In this funny (and actually poignant) 3-minute talk, social strategist Renny Gleeson breaks down our always-on social world -- where the experience we're having right now is less interesting than what we'll tweet about it later.

authortitle: Emily Levine: A theory of everything
author: Emily Levine
title: A theory of everything
description: Philosopher-comedian Emily Levine talks (hilariously) about science, math, society and the way everything connects. She's a brilliant trickster, poking holes in our fixed ideas and bringing hidden truths to light. Settle in and let her ping your brain.

authortitle: Bonnie Bassler: How bacteria "talk"
author: Bonnie Bassler
title: How bacteria "talk"
description: Bonnie Bassler discovered that bacteria "talk" to each other, using a chemical language that lets them coordinate defense and mount attacks. The find has stunning implications for medicine, industry -- and our understanding of ourselves.

authortitle: P.W. Singer: Military robots and the future of war
author: P.W. Singer
title: Military robots and the future of war
description: In this powerful talk, P.W. Singer shows how the widespread use of robots in war is changing the realities of combat. He shows us scenarios straight out of science fiction -- that now may not be so fictitious.

authortitle: Christopher C. Deam: The Airstream, restyled
author: Christopher C. Deam
title: The Airstream, restyled
description: In this low-key, image-packed talk from 2002, designer Christopher C. Deam talks about his makeover of an American classic: the Airstream travel trailer.

authortitle: Ueli Gegenschatz: Extreme wingsuit flying
author: Ueli Gegenschatz
title: Extreme wingsuit flying
description: Wingsuit jumping is the leading edge of extreme sports -- an exhilarating feat of almost unbelievable daring, where skydivers soar through canyons at over 100MPH. Ueli Gegenschatz talks about how (and why) he does it, and shows jawdropping film.

authortitle: Jacek Utko: Can design save newspapers?
author: Jacek Utko
title: Can design save newspapers?
description: Jacek Utko is an extraordinary Polish newspaper designer whose redesigns for papers in Eastern Europe not only win awards, but increase circulation by up to 100%. Can good design save the newspaper? It just might.

authortitle: C.K. Williams: Poetry of youth and age
author: C.K. Williams
title: Poetry of youth and age
description: Poet C.K. Williams reads his work at TED2001. As he colors scenes of childhood resentments, college loves, odd neighbors and the literal death of youth, he reminds us of the unique challenges of living.

authortitle: Nathan Wolfe: The jungle search for viruses
author: Nathan Wolfe
title: The jungle search for viruses
description: Virus hunter Nathan Wolfe is outwitting the next pandemic by staying two steps ahead: discovering deadly new viruses where they first emerge -- passing from animals to humans among poor subsistence hunters in Africa -- before they claim millions of lives.

authortitle: John Wooden: The difference between winning and succeeding
author: John Wooden
title: The difference between winning and succeeding
description: With profound simplicity, Coach John Wooden redefines success and urges us all to pursue the best in ourselves. In this inspiring talk he shares the advice he gave his players at UCLA, quotes poetry and remembers his father's wisdom.

authortitle: David Pogue: Cool tricks your phone can do
author: David Pogue
title: Cool tricks your phone can do
description: In this engaging talk from the EG'08 conference, New York Times tech columnist David Pogue rounds up some handy cell phone tools and services that can boost your productivity and lower your bills (and your blood pressure).

authortitle: Jacqueline Novogratz: An escape from poverty
author: Jacqueline Novogratz
title: An escape from poverty
description: Jacqueline Novogratz tells a moving story of  an encounter in a Nairobi slum with Jane, a former prostitute, whose dreams of escaping poverty, of becoming a doctor and of getting married were fulfilled in an unexpected way.

authortitle: Saul Griffith: High-altitude wind energy from kites!
author: Saul Griffith
title: High-altitude wind energy from kites!
description: In this brief talk, Saul Griffith unveils the invention his new company Makani Power has been working on: giant kite turbines that create surprising amounts of clean, renewable energy.

authortitle: Kamal Meattle: How to grow fresh air
author: Kamal Meattle
title: How to grow fresh air
description: Researcher Kamal Meattle shows how an arrangement of three common houseplants, used in specific spots in a home or office building, can result in measurably cleaner indoor air.

authortitle: Bruce McCall: What is retro-futurism?
author: Bruce McCall
title: What is retro-futurism?
description: Bruce McCall paints a retro-future that never happened -- full of flying cars, polo-playing tanks and the RMS Tyrannic, "The Biggest Thing in All the World." At Serious Play '08, he narrates a brisk and funny slideshow of his faux-nostalgic art.

authortitle: Adam Savage: My obsession with objects and the stories they tell
author: Adam Savage
title: My obsession with objects and the stories they tell
description: Adam Savage talks about his fascination with the dodo bird, and how it led him on a strange and surprising double quest. It's an entertaining adventure through the mind of a creative obsessive.

authortitle: Dan Ariely: Our buggy moral code
author: Dan Ariely
title: Our buggy moral code
description: Behavioral economist Dan Ariely studies the bugs in our moral code: the hidden reasons we think it's OK to cheat or steal (sometimes). Clever studies help make his point that we're predictably irrational -- and can be influenced in ways we can't grasp.

authortitle: Dan Dennett: Cute, sexy, sweet, funny
author: Dan Dennett
title: Cute, sexy, sweet, funny
description: Why are babies cute? Why is cake sweet? Philosopher Dan Dennett has answers you wouldn't expect, as he shares evolution's counterintuitive reasoning on cute, sweet and sexy things (plus a new theory from Matthew Hurley on why jokes are funny).

authortitle: Tim Berners-Lee: The next web
author: Tim Berners-Lee
title: The next web
description: 20 years ago, Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web. For his next project, he's building a web for open, linked data that could do for numbers what the Web did for words, pictures, video: unlock our data and reframe the way we use it together.

authortitle: Stuart Brown: Play is more than just fun
author: Stuart Brown
title: Play is more than just fun
description: A pioneer in research on play, Dr. Stuart Brown says humor, games, roughhousing, flirtation and fantasy are more than just fun. Plenty of play in childhood makes for happy, smart adults -- and keeping it up can make us smarter at any age.

authortitle: Aimee Mullins: My 12 pairs of legs
author: Aimee Mullins
title: My 12 pairs of legs
description: Athlete, actor and activist Aimee Mullins talks about her prosthetic legs -- she's got a dozen amazing pairs -- and the superpowers they grant her: speed, beauty, an extra 6 inches of height ... Quite simply, she redefines what the body can be.

authortitle: Pattie Maes + Pranav Mistry: Meet the SixthSense interaction
author: Pattie Maes + Pranav Mistry
title: Meet the SixthSense interaction
description: This demo -- from Pattie Maes' lab at MIT, spearheaded by Pranav Mistry -- was the buzz of TED. It's a wearable device with a projector that paves the way for profound interaction with our environment. Imagine "Minority Report" and then some.

authortitle: Don Norman: 3 ways good design makes you happy
author: Don Norman
title: 3 ways good design makes you happy
description: In this talk from 2003, design critic Don Norman turns his incisive eye toward beauty, fun, pleasure and emotion, as he looks at design that makes people happy. He names the three emotional cues that a well-designed product must hit to succeed.

authortitle: Eric Lewis: Piano jazz that rocks
author: Eric Lewis
title: Piano jazz that rocks
description: Eric Lewis, an astonishingly talented crossover jazz pianist -- seen by many for the first time at TED2009 -- sets fire to the keys with his shattering rendition of Evanescence's chart-topper, "Going Under."

authortitle: Mike Rowe: Learning from dirty jobs
author: Mike Rowe
title: Learning from dirty jobs
description: Mike Rowe, the host of "Dirty Jobs," tells some compelling (and horrifying) real-life job stories. Listen for his insights and observations about the nature of hard work, and how it’s been unjustifiably degraded in society today.

authortitle: Nalini Nadkarni: Conserving the canopy
author: Nalini Nadkarni
title: Conserving the canopy
description: A unique ecosystem of plants, birds and monkeys thrives in the treetops of the rainforest. Nalini Nadkarni explores these canopy worlds -- and shares her findings with the world below, through dance, art and bold partnerships.

authortitle: Willie Smits: How to restore a rainforest
author: Willie Smits
title: How to restore a rainforest
description: By piecing together a complex ecological puzzle, biologist Willie Smits believes he has found a way to re-grow clearcut rainforest in Borneo, saving local orangutans — and creating a thrilling blueprint for restoring fragile ecosystems. NOTE: The core content of this talk has been challenged on a number of grounds. For details, and Willie Smits' response, please see "A challenge to Willie Smits' talk" below.

authortitle: Brenda Laurel: Why not make video games for girls?
author: Brenda Laurel
title: Why not make video games for girls?
description: At TED in 1998, Brenda Laurel asks: Why are all the top-selling videogames aimed at little boys? She spent two years researching the world of girls (and shares amazing interviews and photos) to create a game that girls would love.

authortitle: Evan Williams: The voices of Twitter users
author: Evan Williams
title: The voices of Twitter users
description: In the year leading up to this talk, the web tool Twitter exploded in size (up 10x during 2008 alone). Co-founder Evan Williams reveals that many of the ideas driving that growth came from unexpected uses invented by the users themselves.

authortitle: Miru Kim: My underground art explorations
author: Miru Kim
title: My underground art explorations
description: At the 2008 EG Conference, artist Miru Kim talks about her work. Kim explores industrial ruins underneath New York and then photographs herself in them, nude -- to bring these massive, dangerous, hidden spaces into sharp focus.

authortitle: Richard Pyle: A dive into the reef's Twilight Zone
author: Richard Pyle
title: A dive into the reef's Twilight Zone
description: In this illuminating talk, Richard Pyle shows us thriving life on the cliffs of coral reefs and groundbreaking diving technologies he has pioneered to explore it. He and his team risk everything to reveal the secrets of undiscovered species.

authortitle: Charles Moore: Seas of plastic
author: Charles Moore
title: Seas of plastic
description: Capt. Charles Moore of the Algalita Marine Research Foundation first discovered the Great Pacific Garbage Patch -- an endless floating waste of plastic trash. Now he's drawing attention to the growing, choking problem of plastic debris in our seas.

authortitle: Ed Ulbrich: How Benjamin Button got his face
author: Ed Ulbrich
title: How Benjamin Button got his face
description: Ed Ulbrich, the digital-effects guru from Digital Domain, explains the Oscar-winning technology that allowed his team to digitally create the older versions of Brad Pitt's face for "The Curious Case of Benjamin Button."

authortitle: Jill Tarter: Join the SETI search
author: Jill Tarter
title: Join the SETI search
description: The SETI Institute's Jill Tarter makes her TED Prize wish: to accelerate our search for cosmic company. Using a growing array of radio telescopes, she and her team listen for patterns that may be a sign of intelligence elsewhere in the universe.

authortitle: Sylvia Earle: My wish: Protect our oceans
author: Sylvia Earle
title: My wish: Protect our oceans
description: Legendary ocean researcher Sylvia Earle shares astonishing images of the ocean -- and shocking stats about its rapid decline -- as she makes her TED Prize wish: that we will join her in protecting the vital blue heart of the planet.

authortitle: Gustavo Dudamel and the Teresa Carreño Youth Orchestra: El Sistema's top youth orchestra
author: Gustavo Dudamel and the Teresa Carreño Youth Orchestra
title: El Sistema's top youth orchestra
description: The Teresa Carreño Youth Orchestra contains the best high school musicians from Venezuela's life-changing music program, El Sistema. Led here by Gustavo Dudamel, they play Shostakovich's Symphony No. 10, 2nd movement, and Arturo Márquez' Danzón No. 2.

authortitle: José Antonio Abreu: The El Sistema music revolution
author: José Antonio Abreu
title: The El Sistema music revolution
description: José Antonio Abreu is the charismatic founder of a youth orchestra system that has transformed thousands of kids' lives in Venezuela. He shares his amazing story and unveils a TED Prize wish that could have a big impact in the US and beyond.

authortitle: David Merrill: Toy tiles that talk to each other
author: David Merrill
title: Toy tiles that talk to each other
description: MIT grad student David Merrill demos Siftables -- cookie-sized, computerized tiles you can stack and shuffle in your hands. These future-toys can do math, play music, and talk to their friends, too. Is this the next thing in hands-on learning?

authortitle: Milton Glaser: Using design to make ideas new
author: Milton Glaser
title: Using design to make ideas new
description: From the TED archives: The legendary graphic designer Milton Glaser dives deep into a new painting inspired by Piero della Francesca. From here, he muses on what makes a convincing poster, by breaking down an idea and making it new.

authortitle: Elizabeth Gilbert: Your elusive creative genius
author: Elizabeth Gilbert
title: Your elusive creative genius
description: Elizabeth Gilbert muses on the impossible things we expect from artists and geniuses -- and shares the radical idea that, instead of the rare person "being" a genius, all of us "have" a genius. It's a funny, personal and surprisingly moving talk.

authortitle: Bill Gates: Mosquitos, malaria and education
author: Bill Gates
title: Mosquitos, malaria and education
description: Bill Gates hopes to solve some of the world's biggest problems using a new kind of philanthropy. In a passionate and, yes, funny 18 minutes, he asks us to consider two big questions and how we might answer them. (And see the Q&A on the TED Blog.)

authortitle: Bill Gross: A solar energy system that tracks the sun
author: Bill Gross
title: A solar energy system that tracks the sun
description: Bill Gross, the founder of Idealab, talks about his life as an inventor, starting with his high-school company selling solar energy plans and kits. Learn here about a groundbreaking system for solar cells -- and some questions we haven't yet solved.

authortitle: Natalie MacMaster: Fiddling in reel time
author: Natalie MacMaster
title: Fiddling in reel time
description: Natalie MacMaster and her musical partner Donnell Leahy play several tunes from the Cape Breton tradition -- a sprightly, soulful style of folk fiddling. It's an inspired collaboration that will have you clapping (and maybe dancing) along.

authortitle: Joe DeRisi: Solving medical mysteries
author: Joe DeRisi
title: Solving medical mysteries
description: Biochemist Joe DeRisi talks about amazing new ways to diagnose viruses (and treat the illnesses they cause) using DNA. His work may help us understand malaria, SARS, avian flu -- and the 60 percent of everyday viral infections that go undiagnosed.

authortitle: Aimee Mullins: Changing my legs - and my mindset
author: Aimee Mullins
title: Changing my legs - and my mindset
description: In this TED archive video from 1998, paralympic sprinter Aimee Mullins talks about her record-setting career as a runner, and about the amazing carbon-fiber prosthetic legs (then a prototype) that helped her cross the finish line.

authortitle: Peter Ward: A theory of Earth's mass extinctions
author: Peter Ward
title: A theory of Earth's mass extinctions
description: Asteroid strikes get all the coverage, but "Medea Hypothesis" author Peter Ward argues that most of Earth's mass extinctions were caused by lowly bacteria. The culprit, a poison called hydrogen sulfide, may have an interesting application in medicine.

authortitle: Woody Norris: Hypersonic sound and other inventions
author: Woody Norris
title: Hypersonic sound and other inventions
description: Woody Norris shows off two of his inventions that use sound in new ways, including the Long Range Acoustic Device, or LRAD. He talks about his untraditional approach to inventing and education, because, as he puts it: "Almost nothing has been invented yet." So -- what's next?

authortitle: Sherwin Nuland: The extraordinary power of ordinary people
author: Sherwin Nuland
title: The extraordinary power of ordinary people
description: Sherwin Nuland, a surgeon and a writer, meditates on the idea of hope -- the desire to become our better selves and make a better world. It's a thoughtful 12 minutes that will help you focus on the road ahead.

authortitle: Barry Schuler: Genomics 101
author: Barry Schuler
title: Genomics 101
description: What is genomics? How will it affect our lives? In this intriguing primer on the genomics revolution, entrepreneur Barry Schuler says we can at least expect healthier, tastier food. He suggests we start with the pinot noir grape, to build better wines.

authortitle: Jamais Cascio: Tools for a better world
author: Jamais Cascio
title: Tools for a better world
description: We all want to make the world better -- but how? Jamais Cascio looks at some specific tools and techniques that can make a difference. It's a fascinating talk that might just inspire you to act.

authortitle: David Carson: Design and discovery
author: David Carson
title: Design and discovery
description: Great design is a never-ending journey of discovery -- for which it helps to pack a healthy sense of humor. Sociologist and surfer-turned-designer David Carson walks through a gorgeous (and often quite funny) slide deck of his work and found images.

authortitle: Paula Scher: Great design is serious, not solemn
author: Paula Scher
title: Great design is serious, not solemn
description: Paula Scher looks back at a life in design (she's done album covers, books, the Citibank logo ...) and pinpoints the moment when she started really having fun. Look for gorgeous designs and images from her legendary career.

authortitle: Joseph Pine: What consumers want
author: Joseph Pine
title: What consumers want
description: Customers want to feel what they buy is authentic, but "Mass Customization" author Joseph Pine says selling authenticity is tough because, well, there's no such thing. He talks about a few experiences that may be artificial but make millions anyway.

authortitle: Peter Reinhart: The art and craft of bread
author: Peter Reinhart
title: The art and craft of bread
description: Batch to batch, crust to crust ... In tribute to the beloved staple food, baking master Peter Reinhart reflects on the cordial couplings (wheat and yeast, starch and heat) that give us our daily bread. Try not to eat a slice.

authortitle: Scott McCloud: The visual magic of comics
author: Scott McCloud
title: The visual magic of comics
description: In this unmissable look at the magic of comics, Scott McCloud bends the presentation format into a cartoon-like experience, where colorful diversions whiz through childhood fascinations and imagined futures that our eyes can hear and touch.

authortitle: Rob Forbes: Ways of seeing
author: Rob Forbes
title: Ways of seeing
description: Rob Forbes, the founder of Design Within Reach, shows a gallery of snapshots that inform his way of seeing the world. Charming juxtapositions, found art, urban patterns -- this slideshow will open your eyes to the world around you.

authortitle: Greg Lynn: Organic algorithms in architecture
author: Greg Lynn
title: Organic algorithms in architecture
description: Greg Lynn talks about the mathematical roots of architecture -- and how calculus and digital tools allow modern designers to move beyond the traditional building forms. A glorious church in Queens (and a titanium tea set) illustrate his theory.

authortitle: Paul Moller: My dream of a flying car
author: Paul Moller
title: My dream of a flying car
description: Paul Moller talks about the future of personal air travel -- the marriage of autos and flight that will give us true freedom to travel off-road. He shows two things he's working on: the Moller Skycar (a jet + car) and a passenger-friendly hovering disc.

authortitle: Paul Sereno: Digging up dinosaurs
author: Paul Sereno
title: Digging up dinosaurs
description: Strange landscapes, scorching heat and (sometimes) mad crocodiles await scientists seeking clues to evolution's genius. Paleontologist Paul Sereno talks about his surprising encounters with prehistory -- and a new way to help students join the adventure.

authortitle: John Maeda: My journey in design
author: John Maeda
title: My journey in design
description: Designer John Maeda talks about his path from a Seattle tofu factory to the Rhode Island School of Design, where he became president in 2008. Maeda, a tireless experimenter and a witty observer, explores the crucial moment when design met computers.

authortitle: Kary Mullis: Play! Experiment! Discover!
author: Kary Mullis
title: Play! Experiment! Discover!
description: Biochemist Kary Mullis talks about the basis of modern science: the experiment. Sharing tales from the 17th century and from his own backyard-rocketry days, Mullis celebrates the curiosity, inspiration and rigor of good science in all its forms.

authortitle: Jennifer 8. Lee: The hunt for General Tso
author: Jennifer 8. Lee
title: The hunt for General Tso
description: Reporter Jennifer 8. Lee talks about her hunt for the origins of familiar Chinese-American dishes -- exploring the hidden spots where these two cultures have (so tastily) combined to form a new cuisine.

authortitle: Nicholas Negroponte: Taking OLPC to Colombia
author: Nicholas Negroponte
title: Taking OLPC to Colombia
description: TED follows Nicholas Negroponte to Colombia as he delivers laptops inside territory once controlled by guerrillas. His partner? Colombia's Defense Department, who see One Laptop per Child as an investment in the region. (And you too can get involved.)

authortitle: Steven Strogatz: The science of sync
author: Steven Strogatz
title: The science of sync
description: Mathematician Steven Strogatz shows how flocks of creatures (like birds, fireflies and fish) manage to synchronize and act as a unit -- when no one's giving orders. The powerful tendency extends into the realm of objects, too.

authortitle: Penelope Boston: There might just be life on Mars
author: Penelope Boston
title: There might just be life on Mars
description: So the Mars Rovers didn't scoop up any alien lifeforms. Scientist Penelope Boston thinks there's a good chance -- a 25 to 50 percent chance, in fact -- that life might exist on Mars, deep inside the planet's caves. She details how we should look and why.

authortitle: Benjamin Wallace: The price of happiness
author: Benjamin Wallace
title: The price of happiness
description: Can happiness be bought? To find out, author Benjamin Wallace sampled the world's most expensive products, including a bottle of 1947 Chateau Cheval Blanc, 8 ounces of Kobe beef and the fabled (notorious) Kopi Luwak coffee. His critique may surprise you.

authortitle: Dan Gilbert: Why we make bad decisions
author: Dan Gilbert
title: Why we make bad decisions
description: Dan Gilbert presents research and data from his exploration of happiness -- sharing some surprising tests and experiments that you can also try on yourself. Watch through to the end for a sparkling Q&A with some familiar TED faces.

authortitle: Jay Walker: My library of human imagination
author: Jay Walker
title: My library of human imagination
description: Jay Walker, curator of the Library of Human Imagination, conducts a surprising show-and-tell session highlighting a few of the intriguing artifacts that backdropped the 2008 TED stage.

authortitle: Dennis vanEngelsdorp: A plea for bees
author: Dennis vanEngelsdorp
title: A plea for bees
description: Bees are dying in droves. Why? Leading apiarist Dennis vanEngelsdorp looks at the gentle, misunderstood creature's important place in nature and the mystery behind its alarming disappearance.

authortitle: Eva Zeisel: The playful search for beauty
author: Eva Zeisel
title: The playful search for beauty
description: The ceramics designer Eva Zeisel looks back on a 75-year career. What keeps her work as fresh today (her latest line debuted in 2008) as in 1926? Her sense of play and beauty, and her drive for adventure. Listen for stories from a rich, colorful life.

authortitle: David Holt: The joyful tradition of mountain music
author: David Holt
title: The joyful tradition of mountain music
description: Folk musician and storyteller David Holt plays the banjo and shares photographs and old wisdom from the Appalachian Mountains. He also demonstrates some unusual instruments like the mouth bow -- and a surprising electric drum kit he calls "thunderwear."

authortitle: Philip Rosedale: Life in Second Life
author: Philip Rosedale
title: Life in Second Life
description: Why build a virtual world? Philip Rosedale talks about the virtual society he founded, Second Life, and its underpinnings in human creativity. It's a place so different that anything could happen.

authortitle: Richard Preston: The mysterious lives of giant trees
author: Richard Preston
title: The mysterious lives of giant trees
description: Science writer Richard Preston talks about some of the most enormous living beings on the planet, the giant trees of the US Pacific Northwest. Growing from a tiny seed, they support vast ecosystems -- and are still, largely, a mystery.

authortitle: Gregory Petsko: The coming neurological epidemic
author: Gregory Petsko
title: The coming neurological epidemic
description: Biochemist Gregory Petsko makes a convincing argument that, in the next 50 years, we'll see an epidemic of neurological diseases, such as Alzheimer's, as the world population ages. His solution: more research into the brain and its functions.

authortitle: Andy Hobsbawm: Do the green thing
author: Andy Hobsbawm
title: Do the green thing
description: Andy Hobsbawm shares a fresh ad campaign about going green -- and some of the fringe benefits.

authortitle: Dan Barber: A foie gras parable
author: Dan Barber
title: A foie gras parable
description: At the Taste3 conference, chef Dan Barber tells the story of a small farm in Spain that has found a humane way to produce foie gras. Raising his geese in a natural environment, farmer Eduardo Sousa embodies the kind of food production Barber believes in.

authortitle: Bill Joy: What I'm worried about, what I'm excited about
author: Bill Joy
title: What I'm worried about, what I'm excited about
description: Technologist and futurist Bill Joy talks about several big worries for humanity -- and several big hopes in the fields of health, education and future tech.

authortitle: George Smoot: The design of the universe
author: George Smoot
title: The design of the universe
description: At Serious Play 2008, astrophysicist George Smoot shows stunning new images from deep-space surveys, and prods us to ponder how the cosmos -- with its giant webs of dark matter and mysterious gaping voids -- got built this way.

authortitle: Franco Sacchi: A tour of Nollywood, Nigeria's booming film industry
author: Franco Sacchi
title: A tour of Nollywood, Nigeria's booming film industry
description: Zambia-born filmmaker Franco Sacchi tours us through Nollywood, Nigeria's booming film industry (the world's 3rd largest). Guerrilla filmmaking and brilliance under pressure from crews that can shoot a full-length feature in a week.

authortitle: Isaac Mizrahi: Fashion and creativity
author: Isaac Mizrahi
title: Fashion and creativity
description: Fashion designer Isaac Mizrahi spins through a dizzying array of inspirations -- from '50s pinups to a fleeting glimpse of a woman on the street who makes him shout "Stop the cab!" Inside this rambling talk are real clues to living a happy, creative life.

authortitle: Stewart Brand: The Long Now
author: Stewart Brand
title: The Long Now
description: Stewart Brand works on the Clock of the Long Now, a timepiece that counts down the next 10,000 years. It's a beautiful project that asks us to think about the far, far future. Here, he discusses a tricky side problem with the Clock: Where can we put it?

authortitle: Ursus Wehrli: Tidying up art
author: Ursus Wehrli
title: Tidying up art
description: Ursus Wehrli shares his vision for a cleaner, more organized, tidier form of art -- by deconstructing the paintings of modern masters into their component pieces, sorted by color and size.

authortitle: Charles Elachi: The story behind the Mars Rovers
author: Charles Elachi
title: The story behind the Mars Rovers
description: At Serious Play 2008, Charles Elachi shares stories from NASA's legendary Jet Propulsion Lab -- including tales and video from the Mars Rover project.

authortitle: Samantha Power: A complicated hero in the war on dictatorship
author: Samantha Power
title: A complicated hero in the war on dictatorship
description: Would you negotiate with someone you knew to be evil, to save lives? Samantha Power tells a story of a complicated hero, Sergio Vieira de Mello. This UN diplomat walked a thin moral line, negotiating with the world's worst dictators to help their people survive crisis. It's a compelling story told with a fiery passion.

authortitle: Lee Smolin: Science and democracy
author: Lee Smolin
title: Science and democracy
description: Physicist Lee Smolin talks about how the scientific community works: as he puts it, "we fight and argue as hard as we can," but everyone accepts that the next generation of scientists will decide who's right. And, he says, that's how democracy works, too.

authortitle: Luca Turin: The science of scent
author: Luca Turin
title: The science of scent
description: What's the science behind a sublime perfume? With charm and precision, biophysicist Luca Turin explains the molecular makeup -- and the art -- of a scent.

authortitle: Tim Brown: Tales of creativity and play
author: Tim Brown
title: Tales of creativity and play
description: At the 2008 Serious Play conference, designer Tim Brown talks about the powerful relationship between creative thinking and play -- with many examples you can try at home (and one that maybe you shouldn't).

authortitle: John Francis: Walk the earth ... my 17-year vow of silence
author: John Francis
title: Walk the earth ... my 17-year vow of silence
description: For almost three decades, John Francis has been a planetwalker, traveling the globe by foot and sail with a message of environmental respect and responsibility (for 17 of those years without speaking). A funny, thoughtful talk with occasional banjo.

authortitle: James Surowiecki: The power and the danger of online crowds
author: James Surowiecki
title: The power and the danger of online crowds
description: James Surowiecki pinpoints the moment when social media became an equal player in the world of news-gathering: the 2005 tsunami, when YouTube video, blogs, IMs and txts carried the news -- and preserved moving personal stories from the tragedy.

authortitle: Graham Hawkes: A flight through the ocean
author: Graham Hawkes
title: A flight through the ocean
description: Graham Hawkes takes us aboard his graceful, winged submarines to the depths of planet Ocean (a.k.a. "Earth"). It's a deep blue world we landlubbers rarely see in 3D.

authortitle: Robert Wright: The evolution of compassion
author: Robert Wright
title: The evolution of compassion
description: Robert Wright uses evolutionary biology and game theory to explain why we appreciate the Golden Rule ("Do unto others..."), why we sometimes ignore it and why there’s hope that, in the near future, we might all have the compassion to follow it.

authortitle: Robert Thurman: Expanding your circle of compassion
author: Robert Thurman
title: Expanding your circle of compassion
description: It's hard to always show compassion -- even to the people we love, but Robert Thurman asks that we develop compassion for our enemies. He prescribes a seven-step meditation exercise to extend compassion beyond our inner circle.

authortitle: Feisal Abdul Rauf: Lose your ego, find your compassion
author: Feisal Abdul Rauf
title: Lose your ego, find your compassion
description: Imam Faisal Abdul Rauf combines the teachings of the Qur'an, the stories of Rumi, and the examples of Muhammad and Jesus, to demonstrate that only one obstacle stands between each of us and absolute compassion -- ourselves.

authortitle: James Forbes: Compassion at the dinner table
author: James Forbes
title: Compassion at the dinner table
description: Join Rev. James Forbes at the dinner table of his Southern childhood, where his mother and father taught him what compassion really means day to day -- sharing with those who need love.

authortitle: Dayananda Saraswati: The profound journey of compassion
author: Dayananda Saraswati
title: The profound journey of compassion
description: Swami Dayananda Saraswati unravels the parallel paths of personal development and attaining true compassion. He walks us through each step of self-realization, from helpless infancy to the fearless act of caring for others.

authortitle: Jackie Tabick: The balancing act of compassion
author: Jackie Tabick
title: The balancing act of compassion
description: While we all agree that compassion is a great idea, Rabbi Tabick acknowledges there are challenges to its execution. She explains how a careful balance of compassion and justice allows us to do good deeds, and keep our sanity.

authortitle: Newton Aduaka: The story of Ezra
author: Newton Aduaka
title: The story of Ezra
description: Filmmaker Newton Aduaka shows clips from his powerful, lyrical feature film "Ezra," about a child soldier in Sierra Leone.

authortitle: Zach Kaplan + Keith Schacht: Toys and materials from the future
author: Zach Kaplan + Keith Schacht
title: Toys and materials from the future
description: The Inventables guys, Zach Kaplan and Keith Schacht, demo some amazing new materials and how we might use them. Look for squishy magnets, odor-detecting ink, "dry" liquid and a very surprising 10-foot pole.

authortitle: Rives: A story of mixed emoticons
author: Rives
title: A story of mixed emoticons
description: Rives tells a typographical fairy tale that's short and bittersweet ;)

authortitle: Jared Diamond: Why do societies collapse?
author: Jared Diamond
title: Why do societies collapse?
description: Why do societies fail? With lessons from the Norse of Iron Age Greenland, deforested Easter Island and present-day Montana, Jared Diamond talks about the signs that collapse is near, and how -- if we see it in time -- we can prevent it.

authortitle: Kristen Ashburn: The face of AIDS in Africa
author: Kristen Ashburn
title: The face of AIDS in Africa
description: In this moving talk, documentary photographer Kristen Ashburn shares unforgettable images of the human impact of AIDS in Africa.

authortitle: Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi: Flow, the secret to happiness
author: Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi
title: Flow, the secret to happiness
description: Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi asks, "What makes a life worth living?" Noting that money cannot make us happy, he looks to those who find pleasure and lasting satisfaction in activities that bring about a state of "flow."

authortitle: Paul MacCready: Nature vs. humans
author: Paul MacCready
title: Nature vs. humans
description: In 1998, aircraft designer Paul MacCready looks at a planet on which humans have utterly dominated nature, and talks about what we all can do to preserve nature's balance. His contribution: solar planes, superefficient gliders and the electric car.

authortitle: John Hodgman: Aliens, love -- where are they?
author: John Hodgman
title: Aliens, love -- where are they?
description: Humorist John Hodgman rambles through a new story about aliens, physics, time, space and the way all of these somehow contribute to a sweet, perfect memory of falling in love.

authortitle: Dean Ornish: Healing through diet
author: Dean Ornish
title: Healing through diet
description: Dean Ornish talks about simple, low-tech and low-cost ways to take advantage of the body's natural desire to heal itself.

authortitle: Garrett Lisi: An 8-dimensional model of the universe
author: Garrett Lisi
title: An 8-dimensional model of the universe
description: Physicist and surfer Garrett Lisi presents a controversial new model of the universe that -- just maybe -- answers all the big questions. If nothing else, it's the most beautiful 8-dimensional model of elementary particles and forces you've ever seen.

authortitle: James Burchfield: Playing invisible turntables
author: James Burchfield
title: Playing invisible turntables
description: Human beatbox James "AudioPoet" Burchfield performs an intricate three-minute breakdown -- sexy, propulsive hip-hop rhythms and turntable textures -- all using only his voice.

authortitle: Steven Johnson: The Web as a city
author: Steven Johnson
title: The Web as a city
description: Outside.in's Steven Johnson says the Web is like a city: built by many people, completely controlled by no one, intricately interconnected and yet functioning as many independent parts. While disaster strikes in one place, elsewhere, life goes on.

authortitle: Doris Kearns Goodwin: Lessons from past presidents
author: Doris Kearns Goodwin
title: Lessons from past presidents
description: Historian Doris Kearns Goodwin talks about what we can learn from American presidents, including Abraham Lincoln and Lyndon Johnson. Then she shares a moving memory of her own father, and of their shared love of baseball.

authortitle: David Perry: Are games better than life?
author: David Perry
title: Are games better than life?
description: Game designer David Perry says tomorrow's videogames will be more than mere fun to the next generation of gamers. They'll be lush, complex, emotional experiences -- more involving and meaningful to some than real life. With an excerpt from Michael Highland's film "As Real as Your Life."

authortitle: James Nachtwey: Moving photos of extreme drug-resistant TB
author: James Nachtwey
title: Moving photos of extreme drug-resistant TB
description: An ancient disease is taking on a deadly new form. James Nachtwey share his powerful photographs of XDR-TB, a newly drug-resistant strain of tuberculosis that has developed due to misused and inadequate medical treatments -- and that might be touching off a global medical crisis.

authortitle: Liz Diller: The Blur Building and other tech-empowered architecture
author: Liz Diller
title: The Blur Building and other tech-empowered architecture
description: In this engrossing EG talk, architect Liz Diller shares her firm DS+R's more unusual work, including the Blur Building, whose walls are made of fog, and the revamped Alice Tully Hall, which is wrapped in glowing wooden skin.

authortitle: Noah Feldman: Politics and religion are technologies
author: Noah Feldman
title: Politics and religion are technologies
description: Noah Feldman makes a searing case that both politics and religion -- whatever their differences -- are similar technologies, designed to efficiently connect and manage any group of people.

authortitle: Stefan Sagmeister: Things I've learned in my life so far
author: Stefan Sagmeister
title: Things I've learned in my life so far
description: Rockstar designer Stefan Sagmeister delivers a short, witty talk on life lessons, expressed through surprising modes of design (including ... inflatable monkeys?).

authortitle: Rodney Brooks: Robots will invade our lives
author: Rodney Brooks
title: Robots will invade our lives
description: In this prophetic talk from 2003, roboticist Rodney Brooks talks about how robots are going to work their way into our lives -- starting with toys and moving into household chores ... and beyond.

authortitle: Steven Pinker: Human nature and the blank slate
author: Steven Pinker
title: Human nature and the blank slate
description: Steven Pinker's book The Blank Slate argues that all humans are born with some innate traits. Here, Pinker talks about his thesis, and why some people found it incredibly upsetting.

authortitle: Caleb Chung: Playtime with Pleo, your robotic dinosaur friend
author: Caleb Chung
title: Playtime with Pleo, your robotic dinosaur friend
description: Pleo the robot dinosaur acts like a living pet -- exploring, cuddling, playing, reacting and learning. Inventor Caleb Chung talks about Pleo and his wild toy career at EG07, on the week that Pleo shipped to stores for the first time.

authortitle: Laura Trice: Remember to say thank you
author: Laura Trice
title: Remember to say thank you
description: In this deceptively simple 3-minute talk, Dr. Laura Trice muses on the power of the magic words "thank you" -- to deepen a friendship, to repair a bond, to make sure another person knows what they mean to you. Try it.

authortitle: Philip Zimbardo: The psychology of evil
author: Philip Zimbardo
title: The psychology of evil
description: Philip Zimbardo knows how easy it is for nice people to turn bad. In this talk, he shares insights and graphic unseen photos from the Abu Ghraib trials. Then he talks about the flip side: how easy it is to be a hero, and how we can rise to the challenge.

authortitle: Marvin Minsky: Health and the human mind
author: Marvin Minsky
title: Health and the human mind
description: Listen closely -- Marvin Minsky's arch, eclectic, charmingly offhand talk on health, overpopulation and the human mind is packed with subtlety: wit, wisdom and just an ounce of wily, is-he-joking? advice.

authortitle: David S. Rose: How to pitch to a VC
author: David S. Rose
title: How to pitch to a VC
description: Thinking startup? David S. Rose's rapid-fire TED U talk on pitching to a venture capitalist tells you the 10 things you need to know about yourself -- and prove to a VC -- before you fire up your slideshow.

authortitle: Eve Ensler: What security means to me
author: Eve Ensler
title: What security means to me
description: Playwright Eve Ensler explores our modern craving for security -- and why it makes us less secure. Listen for inspiring, heartbreaking stories of women making change.

authortitle: Jonathan Haidt: The moral roots of liberals and conservatives
author: Jonathan Haidt
title: The moral roots of liberals and conservatives
description: Psychologist Jonathan Haidt studies the five moral values that form the basis of our political choices, whether we're left, right or center. In this eye-opening talk, he pinpoints the moral values that liberals and conservatives tend to honor most.

authortitle: Ann Cooper: What's wrong with school lunches
author: Ann Cooper
title: What's wrong with school lunches
description: Speaking at the 2007 EG conference, "renegade lunch lady" Ann Cooper talks about the coming revolution in the way kids eat at school -- local, sustainable, seasonal and even educational food.

authortitle: Keith Bellows: The camel's hump
author: Keith Bellows
title: The camel's hump
description: Keith Bellows gleefully outlines the engineering marvels of the camel, a vital creature he calls "the SUV of the desert." Though he couldn't bring a live camel to TED, he gets his camera crew as close as humanly possible to a one-ton beast in full rut.

authortitle: David Gallo: Life in the deep oceans
author: David Gallo
title: Life in the deep oceans
description: With vibrant video clips captured by submarines, David Gallo takes us to some of Earth's darkest, most violent, toxic and beautiful habitats, the valleys and volcanic ridges of the oceans' depths, where life is bizarre, resilient and shockingly abundant.

authortitle: Brewster Kahle: A free digital library
author: Brewster Kahle
title: A free digital library
description: Brewster Kahle is building a truly huge digital library -- every book ever published, every movie ever released, all the strata of web history ... It's all free to the public -- unless someone else gets to it first.

authortitle: Irwin Redlener: How to survive a nuclear attack
author: Irwin Redlener
title: How to survive a nuclear attack
description: The face of nuclear terror has changed since the Cold War, but disaster-medicine expert Irwin Redlener reminds us the threat is still real. He looks at some of history's farcical countermeasures and offers practical advice on how to survive an attack.

authortitle: Jane Goodall: How humans and animals can live together
author: Jane Goodall
title: How humans and animals can live together
description: The legendary chimpanzee researcher Jane Goodall talks about TACARE and her other community projects, which help people in booming African towns live side-by-side with threatened animals.

authortitle: Jonathan Drori: What we think we know
author: Jonathan Drori
title: What we think we know
description: Starting with four basic questions (that you may be surprised to find you can't answer), Jonathan Drori looks at the gaps in our knowledge -- and specifically, what we don't about science that we might think we do.

authortitle: Peter Hirshberg: The web is more than "better TV"
author: Peter Hirshberg
title: The web is more than "better TV"
description: In this absorbing look at emerging media and tech history, Peter Hirshberg shares some crucial lessons from Silicon Valley and explains why the web is so much more than "better TV."

authortitle: Peter Diamandis: Our next giant leap
author: Peter Diamandis
title: Our next giant leap
description: Peter Diamandis says it's our moral imperative to keep exploring space -- and he talks about how, with the X Prize and other incentives, we're going to do just that.

authortitle: Paul Rothemund: DNA folding, in detail
author: Paul Rothemund
title: DNA folding, in detail
description: In 2007, Paul Rothemund gave TED a short summary of his specialty, DNA folding. Now he lays out in clear, abundant detail the immense promise of this field -- to create tiny machines that assemble themselves.

authortitle: Einstein the Parrot: A talking, squawking parrot
author: Einstein the Parrot
title: A talking, squawking parrot
description: This whimsical wrap-up of TED2006 -- presented by Einstein, the African grey parrot, and her trainer, Stephanie White -- simply tickles. Watch for the moment when Einstein has a moment with Al Gore.

authortitle: Ory Okolloh: How I became an activist
author: Ory Okolloh
title: How I became an activist
description: Ory Okolloh tells the story of her life and her family -- and how she came to do her heroic work reporting on the doings of Kenya's parliament.

authortitle: Sugata Mitra: Kids can teach themselves
author: Sugata Mitra
title: Kids can teach themselves
description: Speaking at LIFT 2007, Sugata Mitra talks about his Hole in the Wall project. Young kids in this project figured out how to use a PC on their own -- and then taught other kids. He asks, what else can children teach themselves?

authortitle: John Q. Walker: Great piano performances, recreated
author: John Q. Walker
title: Great piano performances, recreated
description: Imagine hearing great, departed pianists play again today, just as they would in person. John Q. Walker demonstrates how recordings can be analyzed for precise keystrokes and pedal motions, then played back on computer-controlled grand pianos.

authortitle: Nellie McKay: "The Dog Song"
author: Nellie McKay
title: "The Dog Song"
description: Animal fan Nellie McKay sings a sparkling tribute to her dear dog. She suggests we all do the same: "Just go right to the pound/ And find yourself a hound/ And make that doggie proud/ 'cause that's what it's all about."

authortitle: Ian Dunbar: Dog-friendly dog training
author: Ian Dunbar
title: Dog-friendly dog training
description: Speaking at the 2007 EG conference, trainer Ian Dunbar asks us to see the world through the eyes of our beloved dogs. By knowing our pets' perspective, we can build their love and trust. It's a message that resonates well beyond the animal world.

authortitle: Spencer Wells: A family tree for humanity
author: Spencer Wells
title: A family tree for humanity
description: All humans share some common bits of DNA, passed down to us from our African ancestors. Geneticist Spencer Wells talks about how his Genographic Project will use this shared DNA to figure out how we are -- in all our diversity -- truly connected.

authortitle: Patricia Burchat: Shedding light on dark matter
author: Patricia Burchat
title: Shedding light on dark matter
description: Physicist Patricia Burchat sheds light on two basic ingredients of our universe: dark matter and dark energy. Comprising 96% of the universe between them, they can't be directly measured, but their influence is immense.

authortitle: Bruno Bowden + Rufus Cappadocia: Watch me fold origami (blindfolded)
author: Bruno Bowden + Rufus Cappadocia
title: Watch me fold origami (blindfolded)

authortitle: Robert Lang: The math and magic of origami
author: Robert Lang
title: The math and magic of origami
description: Robert Lang is a pioneer of the newest kind of origami -- using math and engineering principles to fold mind-blowingly intricate designs that are beautiful and, sometimes, very useful.

authortitle: Kwabena Boahen: A computer that works like the brain
author: Kwabena Boahen
title: A computer that works like the brain
description: Researcher Kwabena Boahen is looking for ways to mimic the brain's supercomputing powers in silicon -- because the messy, redundant processes inside our heads actually make for a small, light, superfast computer.

authortitle: Kevin Kelly: The next 5,000 days of the web
author: Kevin Kelly
title: The next 5,000 days of the web
description: At the 2007 EG conference, Kevin Kelly shares a fun stat: The World Wide Web, as we know it, is only 5,000 days old. Now, Kelly asks, how can we predict what's coming in the next 5,000 days?

authortitle: Reed Kroloff: A tour of modern architecture
author: Reed Kroloff
title: A tour of modern architecture
description: Reed Kroloff gives us a new lens for judging new architecture: is it modern, or is it romantic? Look for glorious images from two leading practices -- and a blistering critique of the 9/11 planning process.

authortitle: Jonathan Harris: The web as art
author: Jonathan Harris
title: The web as art
description: At the EG conference in December 2007, artist Jonathan Harris discusses his latest projects, which involve collecting stories: his own, strangers', and stories collected from the Internet, including his amazing "We Feel Fine."

authortitle: Louise Leakey: A dig for humanity's origins
author: Louise Leakey
title: A dig for humanity's origins
description: Louise Leakey asks, "Who are we?" The question takes her to the Rift Valley in Eastern Africa, where she digs for the evolutionary origins of humankind -- and suggests a stunning new vision of our competing ancestors.

authortitle: Chris Abani: On humanity
author: Chris Abani
title: On humanity
description: Chris Abani tells stories of people: People standing up to soldiers. People being compassionate. People being human and reclaiming their humanity. It's "ubuntu," he says: the only way for me to be human is for you to reflect my humanity back at me.

authortitle: Marisa Fick-Jordan: The wonder of Zulu wire art
author: Marisa Fick-Jordan
title: The wonder of Zulu wire art
description: In this short, image-packed talk, Marisa Fick-Jordan talks about how a village of traditional Zulu wire weavers built a worldwide market for their dazzling work.

authortitle: Martin Seligman: The new era of positive psychology
author: Martin Seligman
title: The new era of positive psychology
description: Martin Seligman talks about psychology -- as a field of study and as it works one-on-one with each patient and each practitioner. As it moves beyond a focus on disease, what can modern psychology help us to become?

authortitle: Keith Barry: Brain magic
author: Keith Barry
title: Brain magic
description: First, Keith Barry shows us how our brains can fool our bodies -- in a trick that works via podcast too. Then he involves the audience in some jaw-dropping (and even a bit dangerous) feats of brain magic.

authortitle: A.J. Jacobs: My year of living biblically
author: A.J. Jacobs
title: My year of living biblically

authortitle: Billy Graham: On technology and faith
author: Billy Graham
title: On technology and faith
description: Speaking at TED in 1998, Rev. Billy Graham marvels at technology's power to improve lives and change the world -- but says the end of evil, suffering and death will come only after the world accepts Christ. A legendary talk from TED's archives.

authortitle: Helen Fisher: The brain in love
author: Helen Fisher
title: The brain in love
description: Why do we crave love so much, even to the point that we would die for it? To learn more about our very real, very physical need for romantic love, Helen Fisher and her research team took MRIs of people in love -- and people who had just been dumped.

authortitle: Freeman Dyson: Let's look for life in the outer solar system
author: Freeman Dyson
title: Let's look for life in the outer solar system
description: Physicist Freeman Dyson suggests that we start looking for life on the moons of Jupiter and out past Neptune, in the Kuiper belt and the Oort cloud. He talks about what such life would be like -- and how we might find it.

authortitle: Nellie McKay: "Mother of Pearl," "If I Had You"
author: Nellie McKay
title: "Mother of Pearl," "If I Had You"
description: The wonderful Nellie McKay sings "Mother of Pearl" (with the immortal first line "Feminists don't have a sense of humor") and "If I Had You" from her sparkling set at TED2008.

authortitle: Clay Shirky: Institutions vs. collaboration
author: Clay Shirky
title: Institutions vs. collaboration
description: In this prescient 2005 talk, Clay Shirky shows how closed groups and companies will give way to looser networks where small contributors have big roles and fluid cooperation replaces rigid planning.

authortitle: David Hoffman: What happens when you lose everything
author: David Hoffman
title: What happens when you lose everything
description: Nine days before TED2008, filmmaker David Hoffman lost almost everything he owned in a fire that destroyed his home, office and 30 years of passionate collecting. He looks back at a life that's been wiped clean in an instant -- and looks forward.

authortitle: Torsten Reil: Animate characters by evolving them
author: Torsten Reil
title: Animate characters by evolving them
description: Torsten Reil talks about how the study of biology can help make natural-looking animated people -- by building a human from the inside out, with bones, muscles and a nervous system. He spoke at TED in 2003; see his work now in GTA4.

authortitle: Corneille Ewango: A hero of the Congo forest
author: Corneille Ewango
title: A hero of the Congo forest
description: Botanist Corneille Ewango talks about his work at the Okapi Faunal Reserve in the Congo Basin -- and his heroic work protecting it from poachers, miners and raging civil wars.

authortitle: Raul Midon: "Peace on Earth"
author: Raul Midon
title: "Peace on Earth"
description: Guitarist and singer Raul Midon plays "Everybody" and "Peace on Earth" during his 2007 set at TED.

authortitle: Rick Smolan: The story of a girl
author: Rick Smolan
title: The story of a girl
description: Photographer Rick Smolan tells the unforgettable story of a young Amerasian girl, a fateful photograph, and an adoption saga with a twist.

authortitle: Peter Diamandis: Stephen Hawking's zero g flight
author: Peter Diamandis
title: Stephen Hawking's zero g flight
description: X Prize founder Peter Diamandis talks about how he helped Stephen Hawking fulfill his dream of going to space -- by flying together into the upper atmosphere and experiencing weightlessness at zero g.

authortitle: Sxip Shirey + Rachelle Garniez: A performance with breath, music, passion
author: Sxip Shirey + Rachelle Garniez
title: A performance with breath, music, passion
description: Composer Sxip Shirey makes music from the simple, dramatic act of breathing -- alone and together. Open your ears to a passionate 3 minutes.

authortitle: Nellie McKay: "Clonie"
author: Nellie McKay
title: "Clonie"
description: Singer-songwriter Nellie McKay performs the semi-serious song "Clonie" -- about creating the ultimate companion.

authortitle: Nicholas Negroponte: One Laptop per Child, two years on
author: Nicholas Negroponte
title: One Laptop per Child, two years on
description: Nicholas Negroponte talks about how One Laptop per Child is doing, two years in. Speaking at the EG conference while the first XO laptops roll off the production line, he recaps the controversies and recommits to the goals of this far-reaching project.

authortitle: Benjamin Zander: The transformative power of classical music
author: Benjamin Zander
title: The transformative power of classical music
description: Benjamin Zander has two infectious passions: classical music, and helping us all realize our untapped love for it -- and by extension, our untapped love for all new possibilities, new experiences, new connections.

authortitle: Steven Levitt: Surprising stats about child carseats
author: Steven Levitt
title: Surprising stats about child carseats
description: Steven Levitt shares data that shows car seats are no more effective than seatbelts in protecting kids from dying in cars. However, during the question and answer session, he makes one crucial caveat.

authortitle: Adam Grosser: A mobile fridge for vaccines
author: Adam Grosser
title: A mobile fridge for vaccines
description: Adam Grosser talks about a project to build a refrigerator that works without electricity -- to bring the vital tool to villages and clinics worldwide. Tweaking some old technology, he's come up with a system that works.

authortitle: Robert Full: Robots inspired by cockroach ingenuity
author: Robert Full
title: Robots inspired by cockroach ingenuity
description: Insects and animals have evolved some amazing skills -- but, as Robert Full notes, many animals are actually over-engineered. The trick is to copy only what's necessary. He shows how human engineers can learn from animals' tricks.

authortitle: Dean Ornish: Your genes are not your fate
author: Dean Ornish
title: Your genes are not your fate
description: Dean Ornish shares new research that shows how adopting healthy lifestyle habits can affect a person at a genetic level. For instance, he says, when you live healthier, eat better, exercise, and love more, your brain cells actually increase.

authortitle: Chris Jordan: Turning powerful stats into art
author: Chris Jordan
title: Turning powerful stats into art
description: Artist Chris Jordan shows us an arresting view of what Western culture looks like. His supersized images picture some almost unimaginable statistics -- like the astonishing number of paper cups we use every single day.

authortitle: Wade Davis: The worldwide web of belief and ritual
author: Wade Davis
title: The worldwide web of belief and ritual
description: Anthropologist Wade Davis muses on the worldwide web of belief and ritual that makes us human. He shares breathtaking photos and stories of the Elder Brothers, a group of Sierra Nevada indians whose spiritual practice holds the world in balance.

authortitle: Rokia Traore: "Kounandi"
author: Rokia Traore
title: "Kounandi"
description: Singer-songwriter Rokia Traore performs "Kounandi," a breathtaking song that blends Malian instruments with a modern, heartfelt vocal. Note: This song is not available for download.

authortitle: Nathan Myhrvold: Archeology, animal photography, BBQ ...
author: Nathan Myhrvold
title: Archeology, animal photography, BBQ ...
description: Nathan Myhrvold talks about a few of his latest fascinations -- animal photography, archeology, BBQ and generally being an eccentric genius multimillionaire. Listen for wild stories from the (somewhat raunchy) edge of the animal world.

authortitle: Susan Blackmore: Memes and "temes"
author: Susan Blackmore
title: Memes and "temes"
description: Susan Blackmore studies memes: ideas that replicate themselves from brain to brain like a virus. She makes a bold new argument: Humanity has spawned a new kind of meme, the teme, which spreads itself via technology -- and invents ways to keep itself alive

authortitle: Paul Collier: The "bottom billion"
author: Paul Collier
title: The "bottom billion"
description: Around the world right now, one billion people are trapped in poor or failing countries. How can we help them? Economist Paul Collier lays out a bold, compassionate plan for closing the gap between rich and poor.

authortitle: Seyi Oyesola: A hospital tour in Nigeria
author: Seyi Oyesola
title: A hospital tour in Nigeria
description: Dr. Seyi Oyesola takes a searing look at health care in underdeveloped countries. His photo tour of a Nigerian teaching hospital -- all low-tech hacks and donated supplies -- drives home the challenge of doing basic health care there.

authortitle: Arthur Ganson: Moving sculpture
author: Arthur Ganson
title: Moving sculpture
description: Sculptor and engineer Arthur Ganson talks about his work -- kinetic art that explores deep philosophical ideas and is gee-whiz fun to look at.

authortitle: Yves Béhar: Designing objects that tell stories
author: Yves Béhar
title: Designing objects that tell stories

authortitle: Robert Ballard: The astonishing hidden world of the deep ocean
author: Robert Ballard
title: The astonishing hidden world of the deep ocean
description: Ocean explorer Robert Ballard takes us on a mindbending trip to hidden worlds underwater, where he and other researchers are finding unexpected life, resources, even new mountains. He makes a case for serious exploration and mapping. Google Ocean, anyone?

authortitle: Mark Bittman: What's wrong with what we eat
author: Mark Bittman
title: What's wrong with what we eat
description: In this fiery and funny talk, New York Times food writer Mark Bittman weighs in on what's wrong with the way we eat now (too much meat, too few plants; too much fast food, too little home cooking), and why it's putting the entire planet at risk.

authortitle: Alisa Miller: How the news distorts our worldview
author: Alisa Miller
title: How the news distorts our worldview
description: Alisa Miller, head of Public Radio International, talks about why -- though we want to know more about the world than ever -- the media is actually showing us less. Eye-opening stats and graphs.

authortitle: Joshua Klein: A thought experiment on the intelligence of crows
author: Joshua Klein
title: A thought experiment on the intelligence of crows
description: Hacker and writer Joshua Klein is fascinated by crows. (Notice the gleam of intelligence in their little black eyes?) After a long amateur study of corvid behavior, he's come up with an elegant thought experiment: a machine that could form a new bond between animal and human.

authortitle: Michael Moschen: Juggling as art ... and science
author: Michael Moschen
title: Juggling as art ... and science
description: Michael Moschen puts on a quietly mesmerizing show of juggling. Don't think juggling is an art? You might just change your mind after watching Moschen in motion.

authortitle: Paul Ewald: Can we domesticate germs?
author: Paul Ewald
title: Can we domesticate germs?
description: Evolutionary biologist Paul Ewald drags us into the sewer to discuss germs. Why are some more harmful than others? How could we make the harmful ones benign? Searching for answers, he examines a disgusting, fascinating case: diarrhea.

authortitle: Paul Stamets: 6 ways mushrooms can save the world
author: Paul Stamets
title: 6 ways mushrooms can save the world
description: Mycologist Paul Stamets lists 6 ways the mycelium fungus can help save the universe: cleaning polluted soil, making insecticides, treating smallpox and even flu viruses.

authortitle: Hector Ruiz: The thinking behind 50x15
author: Hector Ruiz
title: The thinking behind 50x15
description: Hector Ruiz, the executive chair of AMD, wants to give Internet access to everyone. In this talk, he shares his extraordinary life story and describes AMD's 50x15 initiative that calls for connecting 50 percent of the world by 2015.

authortitle: They Might Be Giants: Wake up! It's They Might Be Giants!
author: They Might Be Giants
title: Wake up! It's They Might Be Giants!
description: In a very, very early-morning set, They Might Be Giants rock TED2007, playing "Older," "Bee of the Bird of the Moth," "Asbury Park," "Fingertips," and "The Alphabet of Nations." Plus they take phone calls from the dead.

authortitle: Brian Cox: CERN's supercollider
author: Brian Cox
title: CERN's supercollider
description: "Rock-star physicist" Brian Cox talks about his work on the Large Hadron Collider at CERN. Discussing the biggest of big science in an engaging, accessible way, Cox brings us along on a tour of the massive project.

authortitle: Brian Greene: Making sense of string theory
author: Brian Greene
title: Making sense of string theory
description: Physicist Brian Greene explains superstring theory, the idea that minscule strands of energy vibrating in 11 dimensions create every particle and force in the universe.

authortitle: Amy Tan: Where does creativity hide?
author: Amy Tan
title: Where does creativity hide?
description: Novelist Amy Tan digs deep into the creative process, looking for hints of how hers evolved.

authortitle: Ernest Madu: World-class health care
author: Ernest Madu
title: World-class health care
description: Dr. Ernest Madu runs the Heart Institute of the Caribbean in Kingston, Jamaica, where he proves that -- with careful design, smart technical choices, and a true desire to serve -- it's possible to offer world-class healthcare in the developing world.

authortitle: Yochai Benkler: The new open-source economics
author: Yochai Benkler
title: The new open-source economics
description: Yochai Benkler explains how collaborative projects like Wikipedia and Linux represent the next stage of human organization.

authortitle: Tod Machover + Dan Ellsey: Inventing instruments that unlock new music
author: Tod Machover + Dan Ellsey
title: Inventing instruments that unlock new music
description: Tod Machover of MIT's Media Lab is devoted to extending musical expression to everyone, from virtuosos to amateurs, and in the most diverse forms, from opera to video games. He and composer Dan Ellsey shed light on what's next.

authortitle: Johnny Lee: Free or cheap Wii Remote hacks
author: Johnny Lee
title: Free or cheap Wii Remote hacks
description: Building sophisticated educational tools out of cheap parts, Johnny Lee demos his cool Wii Remote hacks, which turn the $40 video game controller into a digital whiteboard, a touchscreen and a head-mounted 3-D viewer.

authortitle: Al Gore: New thinking on the climate crisis
author: Al Gore
title: New thinking on the climate crisis
description: In this brand-new slideshow (premiering on TED.com), Al Gore presents evidence that the pace of climate change may be even worse than scientists recently predicted. He challenges us to act.

authortitle: Stephen Hawking: Questioning the universe
author: Stephen Hawking
title: Questioning the universe
