description: In keeping with the theme of TED2008, professor Stephen Hawking asks some Big Questions about our universe -- How did the universe begin? How did life begin? Are we alone? -- and discusses how we might go about answering them.

authortitle: Jakob Trollback: A new kind of music video
author: Jakob Trollback
title: A new kind of music video
description: What would a music video look like if it were directed by the music, purely as an expression of a great song, rather than driven by a filmmaker's concept? Designer Jakob Trollback shares the results of his experiment in the form.

authortitle: David Hoffman: Sputnik mania
author: David Hoffman
title: Sputnik mania
description: Filmmaker David Hoffman shares footage from his feature-length documentary Sputnik Mania, which shows how the Soviet Union's launch of Sputnik in 1957 led to both the space race and the arms race -- and jump-started science and math education around the world.

authortitle: Siegfried Woldhek: The search for the true face of Leonardo
author: Siegfried Woldhek
title: The search for the true face of Leonardo
description: Mona Lisa is one of the best-known faces on the planet. But would you recognize an image of Leonardo da Vinci? Illustrator Siegfried Woldhek uses some thoughtful image-analysis techniques to find what he believes is the true face of Leonardo.

authortitle: Rokia Traore: "M'Bifo"
author: Rokia Traore
title: "M'Bifo"
description: Rokia Traore sings the moving "M'Bifo," accompanied on the n'goni, a lute-like Malian stringed instrument with a soulful timbre. A quietly mesmerizing performance.

authortitle: Clifford Stoll: The call to learn
author: Clifford Stoll
title: The call to learn
description: Clifford Stoll captivates his audience with a wildly energetic sprinkling of anecdotes, observations, asides -- and even a science experiment. After all, by his own definition, he's a scientist: "Once I do something, I want to do something else."

authortitle: Christopher deCharms: A look inside the brain in real time
author: Christopher deCharms
title: A look inside the brain in real time
description: Neuroscientist and inventor Christopher deCharms demonstrates a new way to use fMRI to show brain activity -- thoughts, emotions, pain -- while it is happening. In other words, you can actually see how you feel.

authortitle: Norman Foster: My green agenda for architecture
author: Norman Foster
title: My green agenda for architecture
description: Architect Norman Foster discusses his own work to show how computers can help architects design buildings that are green, beautiful and "basically pollution-free." From the 2007 DLD Conference, Munich; www.dld-conference.com

authortitle: Neil Turok: My wish: Find the next Einstein in Africa
author: Neil Turok
title: My wish: Find the next Einstein in Africa
description: Accepting his 2008 TED Prize, physicist Neil Turok speaks out for talented young Africans starved of opportunity: by unlocking and nurturing the continent's creative potential, we can create a change in Africa's future.

authortitle: Frank Gehry: My days as a young rebel
author: Frank Gehry
title: My days as a young rebel
description: Before he was a legend, architect Frank Gehry takes a whistlestop tour of his early work, from his house in Venice Beach to the American Center in Paris, which was under construction (and much on his mind) when he gave this talk.

authortitle: Jill Bolte Taylor: My stroke of insight
author: Jill Bolte Taylor
title: My stroke of insight
description: Jill Bolte Taylor got a research opportunity few brain scientists would wish for: She had a massive stroke, and watched as her brain functions -- motion, speech, self-awareness -- shut down one by one. An astonishing story.

authortitle: Nicholas Negroponte: 5 predictions, from 1984
author: Nicholas Negroponte
title: 5 predictions, from 1984
description: With surprising accuracy, Nicholas Negroponte predicts what will happen with CD-ROMs, web interfaces, service kiosks, the touchscreen interface of the iPhone and his own One Laptop per Child project.

authortitle: Craig Venter: On the verge of creating synthetic life
author: Craig Venter
title: On the verge of creating synthetic life
description: "Can we create new life out of our digital universe?" Craig Venter asks. His answer is "yes" -- and pretty soon. He walks through his latest research and promises that we'll soon be able to build and boot up a synthetic chromosome. NOTE: This talk was given in 2008, and this field of science has developed quickly since then. Read "Criticisms & updates" below for more details.

authortitle: Alan Kay: A powerful idea about ideas
author: Alan Kay
title: A powerful idea about ideas
description: With all the intensity and brilliance for which he is known, Alan Kay envisions better techniques for teaching kids by using computers to illustrate experience in ways -– mathematically and scientifically -- that only computers can.

authortitle: Roy Gould + Curtis Wong: A preview of the WorldWide Telescope
author: Roy Gould + Curtis Wong
title: A preview of the WorldWide Telescope
description: Educator Roy Gould and researcher Curtis Wong show a sneak preview of Microsoft's WorldWide Telescope, which compiles images from telescopes and satellites to build a comprehensive, interactive view of our universe.

authortitle: Steve Jurvetson: Model rocketry
author: Steve Jurvetson
title: Model rocketry
description: Moneyman Steve Jurvetson takes TEDsters inside his awesome hobby -- launching model rockets –- by sharing some gorgeous photos, his infectious glee and just a whiff of danger.

authortitle: Joseph Lekuton: A parable for Kenya
author: Joseph Lekuton
title: A parable for Kenya
description: Joseph Lekuton, a member of parliament in Kenya, starts with the story of his remarkable education, then offers a parable of how Africa can grow. His message of hope has never been more relevant.

authortitle: Raspyni Brothers: Juggle and jest
author: Raspyni Brothers
title: Juggle and jest
description: Illustrious jugglers the Raspyni Brothers show off their uncanny balance, agility, coordination and willingness to sacrifice (others). Now, if you'll just stand completely still...

authortitle: Jill Sobule + Julia Sweeney: The Jill and Julia Show
author: Jill Sobule + Julia Sweeney
title: The Jill and Julia Show
description: Two TED favorites, Jill Sobule and Julia Sweeney, team up for a delightful set that mixes witty songwriting with a little bit of social commentary.

authortitle: Moshe Safdie: Building uniqueness
author: Moshe Safdie
title: Building uniqueness
description: Looking back over his long career, architect Moshe Safdie delves into four of his design projects and explains how he labored to make each one truly unique for its site and its users.

authortitle: George Dyson: The story of Project Orion
author: George Dyson
title: The story of Project Orion
description: Author George Dyson spins the story of Project Orion, a massive, nuclear-powered spacecraft that could have taken us to Saturn in five years. His insider’s perspective and a secret cache of documents bring an Atomic Age dream to life.

authortitle: Pamelia Kurstin: The untouchable music of the theremin
author: Pamelia Kurstin
title: The untouchable music of the theremin
description: Virtuoso Pamelia Kurstin performs and discusses her theremin, the not-just-for-sci-fi electronic instrument that is played without being touched. Songs include "Autumn Leaves," "Lush Life" and David Mash’s "Listen, Words Are Gone."

authortitle: Howard Rheingold: The new power of collaboration
author: Howard Rheingold
title: The new power of collaboration
description: Howard Rheingold talks about the coming world of collaboration, participatory media and collective action -- and how Wikipedia is really an outgrowth of our natural human instinct to work as a group.

authortitle: Michael Pollan: A plant's-eye view
author: Michael Pollan
title: A plant's-eye view
description: What if human consciousness isn't the end-all and be-all of Darwinism? What if we are all just pawns in corn's clever strategy game to rule the Earth? Author Michael Pollan asks us to see the world from a plant's-eye view.

authortitle: David Macaulay: An illustrated journey through Rome
author: David Macaulay
title: An illustrated journey through Rome
description: David Macaulay relives the winding and sometimes surreal journey toward the completion of Rome Antics, his illustrated homage to the historic city.

authortitle: Jaime Lerner: A song of the city
author: Jaime Lerner
title: A song of the city
description: Jaime Lerner reinvented urban space in his native Curitiba, Brazil. Along the way, he changed the way city planners worldwide see what's possible in the metropolitan landscape.

authortitle: Robin Chase: The idea behind Zipcar (and what comes next)
author: Robin Chase
title: The idea behind Zipcar (and what comes next)
description: Robin Chase founded Zipcar, the world’s biggest car-sharing business. That was one of her smaller ideas. Here she travels much farther, contemplating road-pricing schemes that will shake up our driving habits and a mesh network vast as the Interstate.

authortitle: Chris Anderson: TED's nonprofit transition
author: Chris Anderson
title: TED's nonprofit transition
description: Chris Anderson gave this talk in 2002, prior to taking over leadership of TED. Co-founder Richard Saul Wurman was leaving, and TED's future was in the balance. He seeks to persuade TEDsters that what was then a for-profit conference had a secure future as an idea-based nonprofit endeavor.

authortitle: Alison Jackson: An unusual glimpse at celebrity
author: Alison Jackson
title: An unusual glimpse at celebrity
description: By making photographs that seem to show our favorite celebs (Diana, Elton John) doing what we really, secretly, want to see them doing, Alison Jackson explores our desire to get personal with celebs. Contains graphic images.

authortitle: David Pogue: The music wars
author: David Pogue
title: The music wars
description: New York Times tech columnist David Pogue performs a satirical mini-medley about iTunes and the downloading wars, borrowing a few notes from Sonny and Cher and the Village People.

authortitle: Bernie Dunlap: The life-long learner
author: Bernie Dunlap
title: The life-long learner
description: Wofford College president Bernie Dunlap tells the story of Sandor Teszler, a Hungarian Holocaust survivor who taught him about passionate living and lifelong learning.

authortitle: Bill Strickland: Rebuilding a neighborhood with beauty, dignity, hope
author: Bill Strickland
title: Rebuilding a neighborhood with beauty, dignity, hope
description: Bill Strickland tells a quiet and astonishing tale of redemption through arts, music, and unlikely partnerships.

authortitle: Raul Midon: "Tembererana"
author: Raul Midon
title: "Tembererana"
description: Singer/guitarist Raúl Midón performs "All the Answers" in a world premiere at TED2007, followed by the sprightly "Tembererana."

authortitle: Frank Gehry: A master architect asks, Now what?
author: Frank Gehry
title: A master architect asks, Now what?
description: In a wildly entertaining discussion with Richard Saul Wurman, architect Frank Gehry gives TEDsters his take on the power of failure, his recent buildings, and the all-important "Then what?" factor.

authortitle: Paola Antonelli: Treat design as art
author: Paola Antonelli
title: Treat design as art
description: Paola Antonelli, design curator at New York's Museum of Modern Art, wants to spread her appreciation of design -- in all shapes and forms -- around the world.

authortitle: David Gallo: Underwater astonishments
author: David Gallo
title: Underwater astonishments
description: David Gallo shows jaw-dropping footage of amazing sea creatures, including a color-shifting cuttlefish, a perfectly camouflaged octopus, and a Times Square's worth of neon light displays from fish who live in the blackest depths of the ocean. This short talk celebrates the pioneering work of ocean explorers like Edith Widder and Roger Hanlon.

authortitle: J.J. Abrams: The mystery box
author: J.J. Abrams
title: The mystery box
description: J.J. Abrams traces his love for the unseen mystery –- a passion that's evident in his films and TV shows, including Lost, Star Trek and the upcoming Star Wars VII -- back to its magical beginnings.

authortitle: Deborah Gordon: The emergent genius of ant colonies
author: Deborah Gordon
title: The emergent genius of ant colonies
description: Deborah Gordon studies ant colonies in the Arizona desert to understand their complex social system. She asks: How do these chitinous creatures get down to business -- and even multitask when they need to -- with no language, memory or visible leadership? Her answers could lead to a better understanding of all complex systems, from the brain to the Web. Thanks, ants.

authortitle: Yossi Vardi: We're worried about local warming ... in your lap
author: Yossi Vardi
title: We're worried about local warming ... in your lap
description: Investor and prankster Yossi Vardi delivers a ballsy lecture on the dangers of blogging. Specifically, for men.

authortitle: Isabel Allende: Tales of passion
author: Isabel Allende
title: Tales of passion
description: Author and activist Isabel Allende discusses women, creativity, the definition of feminism -- and, of course, passion -- in this talk.

authortitle: Gever Tulley: 5 dangerous things you should let your kids do
author: Gever Tulley
title: 5 dangerous things you should let your kids do
description: At TED U, Gever Tulley, founder of the Tinkering School, spells out 5 dangerous things you should let your kids do -- and why a little danger is good for both kids and grownups.

authortitle: Lakshmi Pratury: The lost art of letter-writing
author: Lakshmi Pratury
title: The lost art of letter-writing
description: Lakshmi Pratury remembers the lost art of letter-writing and shares a series of notes her father wrote to her before he died. Her short but heartfelt talk may inspire you to set pen to paper, too.

authortitle: Daniel Goleman: Why aren't we more compassionate?
author: Daniel Goleman
title: Why aren't we more compassionate?
description: Daniel Goleman, author of "Emotional Intelligence," asks why we aren't more compassionate more of the time.

authortitle: Murray Gell-Mann: Beauty, truth and ... physics?
author: Murray Gell-Mann
title: Beauty, truth and ... physics?
description: Armed with a sense of humor and laypeople's terms, Nobel winner Murray Gell-Mann drops some knowledge on TEDsters about particle physics, asking questions like, Are elegant equations more likely to be right than inelegant ones?

authortitle: Philippe Starck: Design and destiny
author: Philippe Starck
title: Design and destiny
description: Designer Philippe Starck -- with no pretty slides to show -- spends 18 minutes reaching for the very roots of the question "Why design?" Listen carefully for one perfect mantra for all of us, genius or not.

authortitle: Ron Eglash: The fractals at the heart of African designs
author: Ron Eglash
title: The fractals at the heart of African designs
description: 'I am a mathematician, and I would like to stand on your roof.' That is how Ron Eglash greeted many African families he met while researching the fractal patterns he'd noticed in villages across the continent.

authortitle: Robert Full: The sticky wonder of gecko feet
author: Robert Full
title: The sticky wonder of gecko feet
description: Biologist Robert Full shares slo-mo video of some captivating critters. Take a closer look at the spiny legs that allow cockroaches to scuttle across mesh and the nanobristle-packed feet that let geckos to run straight up walls.

authortitle: Larry Brilliant: The case for optimism
author: Larry Brilliant
title: The case for optimism
description: We've known about global warming for 50 years and done little about it, says Google.org director Larry Brilliant. In spite of this and other depressing trends, he's optimistic and tells us why. From Skoll World Forum, Oxford, UK, www.skollfoundation.org

authortitle: Juan Enriquez: Using biology to rethink the energy challenge
author: Juan Enriquez
title: Using biology to rethink the energy challenge
description: Juan Enriquez challenges our definition of bioenergy. Oil, coal, gas and other hydrocarbons are not chemical but biological products, based on plant matter -- and thus, growable. Our whole approach to fuel, he argues, needs to change.

authortitle: David Keith: A critical look at geoengineering against climate change
author: David Keith
title: A critical look at geoengineering against climate change
description: Environmental scientist David Keith proposes a cheap, effective, shocking means to address climate change: What if we injected a huge cloud of ash into the atmosphere to deflect sunlight and heat?

authortitle: Paul Rothemund: Playing with DNA that self-assembles
author: Paul Rothemund
title: Playing with DNA that self-assembles
description: Paul Rothemund writes code that causes DNA to arrange itself into a star, a smiley face and more. Sure, it's a stunt, but it's also a demonstration of self-assembly at the smallest of scales -- with vast implications for the future of making things.

authortitle: Lawrence Lessig: Laws that choke creativity
author: Lawrence Lessig
title: Laws that choke creativity
description: Lawrence Lessig, the Net’s most celebrated lawyer, cites John Philip Sousa, celestial copyrights and the "ASCAP cartel" in his argument for reviving our creative culture.

authortitle: Matthieu Ricard: The habits of happiness
author: Matthieu Ricard
title: The habits of happiness
description: What is happiness, and how can we all get some? Biochemist turned Buddhist monk Matthieu Ricard says we can train our minds in habits of well-being, to generate a true sense of serenity and fulfillment.

authortitle: Sherwin Nuland: How electroshock therapy changed me
author: Sherwin Nuland
title: How electroshock therapy changed me
description: Surgeon and author Sherwin Nuland discusses the development of electroshock therapy as a cure for severe, life-threatening depression -- including his own. It’s a moving and heartfelt talk about relief, redemption and second chances.

authortitle: Eleni Gabre-Madhin: A commodities exchange for Ethiopia
author: Eleni Gabre-Madhin
title: A commodities exchange for Ethiopia
description: Economist Eleni Gabre-Madhin outlines her ambitious vision to found the first commodities market in Ethiopia. Her plan would create wealth, minimize risk for farmers and turn the world's largest recipient of food aid into a regional food basket.

authortitle: VS Ramachandran: 3 clues to understanding your brain
author: VS Ramachandran
title: 3 clues to understanding your brain
description: Vilayanur Ramachandran tells us what brain damage can reveal about the connection between celebral tissue and the mind, using three startling delusions as examples.

authortitle: Jan Chipchase: The anthropology of mobile phones
author: Jan Chipchase
title: The anthropology of mobile phones
description: Nokia researcher Jan Chipchase's investigation into the ways we interact with technology has led him from the villages of Uganda to the insides of our pockets. He's made some unexpected discoveries along the way.

authortitle: Maira Kalman: The illustrated woman
author: Maira Kalman
title: The illustrated woman
description: Author and illustrator Maira Kalman talks about her life and work, from her covers for The New Yorker to her books for children and grown-ups. She is as wonderful, as wise and as deliciously off-kilter in person as she is on paper.

authortitle: Hod Lipson: Building "self-aware" robots
author: Hod Lipson
title: Building "self-aware" robots
description: Hod Lipson demonstrates a few of his cool little robots, which have the ability to learn, understand themselves and even self-replicate.

authortitle: Richard Branson: Life at 30,000 feet
author: Richard Branson
title: Life at 30,000 feet
description: Richard Branson talks to TED's Chris Anderson about the ups and the downs of his career, from his multibillionaire success to his multiple near-death experiences -- and reveals some of his (very surprising) motivations.

authortitle: Kenichi Ebina: My magic moves
author: Kenichi Ebina
title: My magic moves
description: Kenichi Ebina moves his body in a manner that appears to defy the limits imposed by the human skeleton. He combines breakdancing and hip-hop with mime using movements that are simultaneously precise and fluid.

authortitle: Carolyn Porco: This is Saturn
author: Carolyn Porco
title: This is Saturn
description: Planetary scientist Carolyn Porco shows images from the Cassini voyage to Saturn, focusing on its largest moon, Titan, and on frozen Enceladus, which seems to shoot jets of ice.

authortitle: Paul MacCready: A flight on solar wings
author: Paul MacCready
title: A flight on solar wings
description: Paul MacCready -- aircraft designer, environmentalist, and lifelong lover of flight -- talks about his long career.

authortitle: Stephen Petranek: 10 ways the world could end
author: Stephen Petranek
title: 10 ways the world could end
description: How might the human race end? Stephen Petranek lays out 10 terrible options and the science behind them. Will we be wiped out by an asteroid? Eco-collapse? How about a particle collider gone wild?

authortitle: John Maeda: Designing for simplicity
author: John Maeda
title: Designing for simplicity
description: The MIT Media Lab's John Maeda lives at the intersection of technology and art, a place that can get very complicated. Here he talks about paring down to basics.

authortitle: Zeresenay Alemseged: The search for humanity's roots
author: Zeresenay Alemseged
title: The search for humanity's roots
description: Paleoanthropologist Zeresenay Alemseged looks for the roots of humanity in Ethiopia's badlands. Here he talks about finding the oldest skeleton of a humanoid child -- and how Africa holds the clues to our humanity.

authortitle: Deborah Scranton: An Iraq war movie crowd-sourced from soldiers
author: Deborah Scranton
title: An Iraq war movie crowd-sourced from soldiers
description: Filmmaker Deborah Scranton talks about and shows clips from her documentary The War Tapes, which puts cameras in the hands of soldiers fighting in Iraq.

authortitle: Steven Pinker: The surprising decline in violence
author: Steven Pinker
title: The surprising decline in violence
description: Steven Pinker charts the decline of violence from Biblical times to the present, and argues that, though it may seem illogical and even obscene, given Iraq and Darfur, we are living in the most peaceful time in our species' existence.

authortitle: Steven Pinker: What our language habits reveal
author: Steven Pinker
title: What our language habits reveal
description: In an exclusive preview of his book The Stuff of Thought, Steven Pinker looks at language and how it expresses what goes on in our minds -- and how the words we choose communicate much more than we realize.

authortitle: Theo Jansen: My creations, a new form of life
author: Theo Jansen
title: My creations, a new form of life
description: Artist Theo Jansen demonstrates the amazingly lifelike kinetic sculptures he builds from plastic tubes and lemonade bottles. His creatures are designed to move -- and even survive -- on their own.

authortitle: Andrew Mwenda: Aid for Africa? No thanks.
author: Andrew Mwenda
title: Aid for Africa? No thanks.
description: In this provocative talk, journalist Andrew Mwenda asks us to reframe the "African question" -- to look beyond the media's stories of poverty, civil war and helplessness and see the opportunities for creating wealth and happiness throughout the continent.

authortitle: Erin McKean: The joy of lexicography
author: Erin McKean
title: The joy of lexicography
description: Is the beloved paper dictionary doomed to extinction? In this infectiously exuberant talk, leading lexicographer Erin McKean looks at the many ways today's print dictionary is poised for transformation.

authortitle: Dean Kamen: Luke, a new prosthetic arm for soldiers
author: Dean Kamen
title: Luke, a new prosthetic arm for soldiers
description: Inventor Dean Kamen previews the prosthetic arm he’s developing at the request of the US Department of Defense. His quiet commitment to using technology to solve problems -- while honoring the human spirit -- has never been more clear.

authortitle: Jeff Skoll: My journey into movies that matter
author: Jeff Skoll
title: My journey into movies that matter
description: Film producer Jeff Skoll (An Inconvenient Truth) talks about his film company, Participant Productions, and the people who've inspired him to do good.

authortitle: Vusi Mahlasela: "Woza"
author: Vusi Mahlasela
title: "Woza"
description: After Vusi Mahlasela's 3-song set at TEDGlobal, the audience wouldn't let him go. His encore, "Woza," showcases his brilliant guitar playing and multilingual lyrics.

authortitle: Vusi Mahlasela: "Thula Mama"
author: Vusi Mahlasela
title: "Thula Mama"
description: South African singer-songwriter Vusi Mahlasela dedicates his song, "Thula Mama," to all women -- and especially his grandmother.

authortitle: Jacqueline Novogratz: Patient capitalism
author: Jacqueline Novogratz
title: Patient capitalism
description: Jacqueline Novogratz shares stories of how "patient capital" can bring sustainable jobs, goods, services -- and dignity -- to the world's poorest.

authortitle: Euvin Naidoo: Why invest in Africa
author: Euvin Naidoo
title: Why invest in Africa
description: South African investment banker Euvin Naidoo explains why investing in Africa can make great business sense.

authortitle: William Kamkwamba: How I built a windmill
author: William Kamkwamba
title: How I built a windmill
description: When he was just 14 years old, Malawian inventor William Kamkwamba built his family an electricity-generating windmill from spare parts, working from rough plans he found in a library book.

authortitle: Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala: Aid versus trade
author: Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala
title: Aid versus trade
description: Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, the former finance minister of Nigeria, sums up four days of intense discussion on aid versus trade on the closing day of TEDGlobal 2007, and shares a personal story explaining her own commitment to this cause.

authortitle: George Ayittey: Africa's cheetahs versus hippos
author: George Ayittey
title: Africa's cheetahs versus hippos
description: Ghanaian economist George Ayittey unleashes a torrent of controlled anger toward corrupt leaders in Africa -- and calls on the "Cheetah generation" to take back the continent.

authortitle: Allison Hunt: How to get (a new) hip
author: Allison Hunt
title: How to get (a new) hip
description: When Allison Hunt found out that she needed a new hip -- and that Canada’s national health care system would require her to spend nearly 2 years on a waiting list (and in pain) -- she took matters into her own hands.

authortitle: David Bolinsky: Visualizing the wonder of a living cell
author: David Bolinsky
title: Visualizing the wonder of a living cell
description: Medical animator David Bolinsky presents 3 minutes of stunning animation that show the bustling life inside a cell.

authortitle: Rives: The  4 a.m. mystery
author: Rives
title: The  4 a.m. mystery
description: Poet Rives does 8 minutes of lyrical origami, folding history into a series of coincidences surrounding that most surreal of hours, 4 o'clock in the morning.

authortitle: Will Wright: Spore, birth of a game
author: Will Wright
title: Spore, birth of a game
description: In a friendly, high-speed presentation, Will Wright demos his newest game, Spore, which promises to dazzle users even more than his previous masterpieces.

authortitle: Emily Oster: Flip your thinking on AIDS in Africa
author: Emily Oster
title: Flip your thinking on AIDS in Africa
description: Emily Oster re-examines the stats on AIDS in Africa from an economic perspective and reaches a stunning conclusion: Everything we know about the spread of HIV on the continent is wrong.

authortitle: Jonathan Harris: The Web's secret stories
author: Jonathan Harris
title: The Web's secret stories
description: Jonathan Harris wants to make sense of the emotional world of the Web. With deep compassion for the human condition, his projects troll the Internet to find out what we're all feeling and looking for.

authortitle: Alan Russell: The potential of regenerative medicine
author: Alan Russell
title: The potential of regenerative medicine
description: Alan Russell studies regenerative medicine -- a breakthrough way of thinking about disease and injury, using a process that can signal the body to rebuild itself.

authortitle: Dan Dennett: Dangerous memes
author: Dan Dennett
title: Dangerous memes
description: Starting with the simple tale of an ant, philosopher Dan Dennett unleashes a devastating salvo of ideas, making a powerful case for the existence of memes -- concepts that are literally alive.

authortitle: Bill Stone: Inside the world's deepest caves
author: Bill Stone
title: Inside the world's deepest caves

authortitle: Hans Rosling: New insights on poverty
author: Hans Rosling
title: New insights on poverty
description: Researcher Hans Rosling uses his cool data tools to show how countries are pulling themselves out of poverty. He demos Dollar Street, comparing households of varying income levels worldwide. Then he does something really amazing.

authortitle: Stephen Lawler: Tour Microsoft's Virtual Earth
author: Stephen Lawler
title: Tour Microsoft's Virtual Earth
description: Microsoft's Stephen Lawler gives a whirlwind tour of Virtual Earth, moving up, down and through its hyper-real cityscapes with dazzlingly fluidity, a remarkable feat that requires staggering amounts of data to bring into focus.

authortitle: Ethel: A string quartet plays "Blue Room"
author: Ethel
title: A string quartet plays "Blue Room"
description: The avant-garde string quartet Ethel performs the third movement from Phil Kline's four-part suite "The Blue Room and Other Stories." Searching melodic lines show off the deep, emotional musicality of these passionate players.

authortitle: Thomas Barnett: Let's rethink America's military strategy
author: Thomas Barnett
title: Let's rethink America's military strategy
description: In this bracingly honest talk, international security strategist Thomas Barnett outlines a post-Cold War solution for the foundering U.S. military that is both sensible and breathtaking in its simplicity: Break it in two.

authortitle: David Rockwell: A memorial at Ground Zero
author: David Rockwell
title: A memorial at Ground Zero
description: In this emotionally charged conversation with journalist Kurt Andersen, designer David Rockwell discusses the process of building a viewing platform at Ground Zero shortly after 9/11.

authortitle: Robert Thurman: We can be Buddhas
author: Robert Thurman
title: We can be Buddhas
description: In our hyperlinked world, we can know anything, anytime. And this mass enlightenment, says Buddhist scholar Bob Thurman, is our first step toward Buddha nature.

authortitle: Anand Agarawala: Rethink the desktop with BumpTop
author: Anand Agarawala
title: Rethink the desktop with BumpTop
description: Anand Agarawala presents BumpTop, a user interface that takes the usual desktop metaphor to a glorious, 3-D extreme, transforming file navigation into a freewheeling playground of crumpled documents and clipping-covered "walls."

authortitle: Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala: Want to help Africa? Do business here
author: Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala
title: Want to help Africa? Do business here
description: We know the negative images of Africa -- famine and disease, conflict and corruption. But, says Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, there's another, less-told story happening in many African nations: one of reform, economic growth and business opportunity.

authortitle: John Doerr: Salvation (and profit) in greentech
author: John Doerr
title: Salvation (and profit) in greentech
description: "I don't think we're going to make it," John Doerr says in an emotional talk about climate change and investment. To create a world fit for his daughter to live in, he says, we need to invest now in clean, green energy.

authortitle: Blaise Agüera y Arcas: How PhotoSynth can connect the world's images
author: Blaise Agüera y Arcas
title: How PhotoSynth can connect the world's images
description: Blaise Aguera y Arcas leads a dazzling demo of Photosynth, software that could transform the way we look at digital images. Using still photos culled from the Web, Photosynth builds breathtaking dreamscapes and lets us navigate them.

authortitle: Tierney Thys: Swim with the giant sunfish
author: Tierney Thys
title: Swim with the giant sunfish
description: Marine biologist Tierney Thys asks us to step into the water to visit the world of the Mola mola, or giant ocean sunfish. Basking, eating jellyfish and getting massages, this behemoth offers clues to life in the open sea.

authortitle: Jeff Hawkins: How brain science will change computing
author: Jeff Hawkins
title: How brain science will change computing
description: Treo creator Jeff Hawkins urges us to take a new look at the brain -- to see it not as a fast processor, but as a memory system that stores and plays back experiences to help us predict, intelligently, what will happen next.

authortitle: Stewart Brand: What squatter cities can teach us
author: Stewart Brand
title: What squatter cities can teach us
description: Rural villages worldwide are being deserted, as billions of people flock to cities to live in teeming squatter camps and slums. Stewart Brand says this is a good thing. Why? It’ll take you 3 minutes to find out.

authortitle: David Kelley: Human-centered design
author: David Kelley
title: Human-centered design
description: IDEO's David Kelley says that product design has become much less about the hardware and more about the user experience. He shows video of this new, broader approach, including footage from the Prada store in New York.

authortitle: James Howard Kunstler: The ghastly tragedy of the suburbs
author: James Howard Kunstler
title: The ghastly tragedy of the suburbs
description: In James Howard Kunstler's view, public spaces should be inspired centers of civic life and the physical manifestation of the common good. Instead, he argues, what we have in America is a nation of places not worth caring about.

authortitle: Stew: "Black Men Ski"
author: Stew
title: "Black Men Ski"
description: What happens when a black man visits Aspen? Singer/songwriter Stew and his band are about to let you know.

authortitle: Sergey Brin + Larry Page: The genesis of Google
author: Sergey Brin + Larry Page
title: The genesis of Google
description: Google co-founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin offer a peek inside the Google machine, sharing tidbits about international search patterns, the philanthropic Google Foundation, and the company's dedication to innovation and employee happiness.

authortitle: Natalie MacMaster: Cape Breton fiddling in reel time
author: Natalie MacMaster
title: Cape Breton fiddling in reel time
description: Violinist Natalie MacMaster and TED Musical Director Thomas Dolby play Dolby's original song "Blue Is a River" in this ethereal duet -- with a little dancing.

authortitle: Chris Anderson: Technology's long tail
author: Chris Anderson
title: Technology's long tail
description: Chris Anderson, then the editor of Wired, explores the four key stages of any viable technology: setting the right price, gaining market share, displacing an established technology and, finally, becoming ubiquitous.

authortitle: Rachelle Garniez: "La Vie en Rose"
author: Rachelle Garniez
title: "La Vie en Rose"
description: Featuring the vocals and mischievous bell-playing of accordionist and singer Rachelle Garniez, the TED House Band -- led by Thomas Dolby on keyboard -- delivers this delightful rendition of the Edith Piaf standard "La Vie en Rose."

authortitle: Tom Rielly: A comic sendup of TED2006
author: Tom Rielly
title: A comic sendup of TED2006
description: Satirist Tom Rielly delivers a wicked parody of the 2006 TED conference, taking down the $100 laptop, the plight of the polar bear, and people who mention, one too many times, that they work at Harvard. Watch for a special moment between Tom and Al Gore.

authortitle: Eddi Reader: "What You've Got"
author: Eddi Reader
title: "What You've Got"
description: Singer/songwriter Eddi Reader performs "What You Do With What You've Got," a meditation on a very TED theme: how to use your gifts and talents to make a difference. With Thomas Dolby on piano.

authortitle: Eddi Reader: "Kiteflyer's Hill"
author: Eddi Reader
title: "Kiteflyer's Hill"
description: Singer/songwriter Eddi Reader performs "Kiteflyer's Hill," a tender look back at a lost love. With Thomas Dolby on piano.

authortitle: Rives: A mockingbird remix of TED2006
author: Rives
title: A mockingbird remix of TED2006
description: Rives recaps the most memorable moments of TED2006 in the free-spirited rhyming verse of a fantastical mockingbird lullaby.

authortitle: Jeff Bezos: The electricity metaphor for the web's future
author: Jeff Bezos
title: The electricity metaphor for the web's future
description: The dot-com boom and bust is often compared to the Gold Rush. But Amazon.com founder Jeff Bezos says it’s more like the early days of the electric industry.

authortitle: William McDonough: Cradle to cradle design
author: William McDonough
title: Cradle to cradle design
description: Green-minded architect and designer William McDonough asks what our buildings and products would look like if designers took into account "all children, all species, for all time."

authortitle: Evelyn Glennie: How to truly listen
author: Evelyn Glennie
title: How to truly listen
description: In this soaring demonstration, deaf percussionist Evelyn Glennie illustrates how listening to music involves much more than simply letting sound waves hit your eardrums.

authortitle: Dan Dennett: The illusion of consciousness
author: Dan Dennett
title: The illusion of consciousness
description: Philosopher Dan Dennett makes a compelling argument that not only don't we understand our own consciousness, but that half the time our brains are actively fooling us.

authortitle: Caroline Lavelle: Casting a spell on the cello
author: Caroline Lavelle
title: Casting a spell on the cello
description: Caroline Lavelle plays the cello like a sorceress casting a spell, occasionally hiding behind her wild mane of blond hair as she sings of pastoral themes. She performs "Farther than the Sun," backed by Thomas Dolby on keyboards.

authortitle: Jill Sobule: Global warming's theme song, "Manhattan in January"
author: Jill Sobule
title: Global warming's theme song, "Manhattan in January"
description: A happy song about global warming, from Jill Sobule.

authortitle: Craig Venter: Sampling the ocean's DNA
author: Craig Venter
title: Sampling the ocean's DNA
description: Genomics pioneer Craig Venter takes a break from his epic round-the-world expedition to talk about the millions of genes his team has discovered so far in its quest to map the ocean's biodiversity.

authortitle: Alex Steffen: The route to a sustainable future
author: Alex Steffen
title: The route to a sustainable future
description: Worldchanging.com founder Alex Steffen argues that reducing humanity’s ecological footprint is incredibly vital now, as the western consumer lifestyle spreads to developing countries.

authortitle: Nora York: Singing "What I Want"
author: Nora York
title: Singing "What I Want"
description: Nora York gives a stunning performance of her song "What I Want," with Jamie Lawrence (keyboards), Steve Tarshis (guitar) and Arthur Kell (bass).

authortitle: Jane Goodall: What separates us from chimpanzees?
author: Jane Goodall
title: What separates us from chimpanzees?
description: Jane Goodall hasn't found the missing link, but she's come closer than nearly anyone else. The primatologist says the only real difference between humans and chimps is our sophisticated language. She urges us to start using it to change the world.

authortitle: Seth Godin: How to get your ideas to spread
author: Seth Godin
title: How to get your ideas to spread
description: In a world of too many options and too little time, our obvious choice is to just ignore the ordinary stuff. Marketing guru Seth Godin spells out why, when it comes to getting our attention, bad or bizarre ideas are more successful than boring ones.

authortitle: Vik Muniz: Art with wire, sugar, chocolate and string
author: Vik Muniz
title: Art with wire, sugar, chocolate and string
description: Vik Muniz makes art from pretty much anything, be it shredded paper, wire, clouds or diamonds. Here he describes the thinking behind his work and takes us on a tour of his incredible images.

authortitle: Thom Mayne: How architecture can connect us
author: Thom Mayne
title: How architecture can connect us
description: Architect Thom Mayne has never been one to take the easy option, and this whistle-stop tour of the buildings he's created makes you glad for it. These are big ideas cast in material form.

authortitle: Stefan Sagmeister: Happiness by design
author: Stefan Sagmeister
title: Happiness by design
description: Graphic designer Stefan Sagmeister takes the audience on a whimsical journey through moments of his life that made him happy -- and notes how many of these moments have to do with good design.

authortitle: Susan Savage-Rumbaugh: The gentle genius of bonobos
author: Susan Savage-Rumbaugh
title: The gentle genius of bonobos
description: Savage-Rumbaugh's work with bonobo apes, which can understand spoken language and learn tasks by watching, forces the audience to rethink how much of what a species can do is determined by biology -- and how much by cultural exposure.

authortitle: Frans Lanting: The story of life in photographs
author: Frans Lanting
title: The story of life in photographs
description: In this stunning slideshow, celebrated nature photographer Frans Lanting presents The LIFE Project, a poetic collection of photographs that tell the story of our planet, from its eruptive beginnings to its present diversity. Soundtrack by Philip Glass.

authortitle: Chris Bangle: Great cars are great art
author: Chris Bangle
title: Great cars are great art
description: American designer Chris Bangle explains his philosophy that car design is an art form in its own right, with an entertaining -- and ultimately moving -- account of the BMW Group's Deep Blue project, intended to create the SUV of the future.

authortitle: Golan Levin: Software (as) art
author: Golan Levin
title: Software (as) art
description: Engineer and artist Golan Levin pushes the boundaries of what's possible with audiovisuals and technology. In an amazing TED display, he shows two programs he wrote to perform his original compositions.

authortitle: Juan Enriquez: The life code that will reshape the future
author: Juan Enriquez
title: The life code that will reshape the future
description: Scientific discoveries, futurist Juan Enriquez notes, demand a shift in code, and our ability to thrive depends on our mastery of that code. Here, he applies this notion to the field of genomics.

authortitle: Sheila Patek: The shrimp with a kick!
author: Sheila Patek
title: The shrimp with a kick!
description: Biologist Sheila Patek talks about her work measuring the feeding strike of the mantis shrimp, one of the fastest movements in the animal world, using video cameras recording at 20,000 frames per second.

authortitle: James Watson: How we discovered DNA
author: James Watson
title: How we discovered DNA
description: Nobel laureate James Watson opens TED2005 with the frank and funny story of how he and his research partner, Francis Crick, discovered the structure of DNA.

authortitle: Dean Kamen: To invent is to give
author: Dean Kamen
title: To invent is to give
description: Inventor Dean Kamen lays out his argument for the Segway and offers a peek into his next big ideas (portable energy and water purification for developing countries).

authortitle: Nick Bostrom: A philosophical quest for our biggest problems
author: Nick Bostrom
title: A philosophical quest for our biggest problems
description: Oxford philosopher and transhumanist Nick Bostrom examines the future of humankind and asks whether we might alter the fundamental nature of humanity to solve our most intrinsic problems.

authortitle: Al Seckel: Visual illusions that show how we (mis)think
author: Al Seckel
title: Visual illusions that show how we (mis)think
description: Al Seckel, a cognitive neuroscientist, explores the perceptual illusions that fool our brains. Loads of eye tricks help him prove that not only are we easily fooled, we kind of like it.

authortitle: Paul Bennett: Design is in the details
author: Paul Bennett
title: Design is in the details
description: Showing a series of inspiring, unusual and playful products, British branding and design guru Paul Bennett explains that design doesn't have to be about grand gestures, but can solve small, universal and overlooked problems.

authortitle: Janine Benyus: Biomimicry's surprising lessons from nature's engineers
author: Janine Benyus
title: Biomimicry's surprising lessons from nature's engineers
description: In this inspiring talk about recent developments in biomimicry, Janine Benyus provides heartening examples of ways in which nature is already influencing the products and systems we build.

authortitle: James Nachtwey: My wish: Let my photographs bear witness
author: James Nachtwey
title: My wish: Let my photographs bear witness
description: Accepting his 2007 TED Prize, war photographer James Nachtwey shows his life's work and asks TED to help him continue telling the story with innovative, exciting uses of news photography in the digital era.

authortitle: E.O. Wilson: My wish: Build the Encyclopedia of Life
author: E.O. Wilson
title: My wish: Build the Encyclopedia of Life
description: As E.O. Wilson accepts his 2007 TED Prize, he makes a plea on behalf of all creatures that we learn more about our biosphere -- and build a networked encyclopedia of all the world's knowledge about life.

authortitle: Bill Clinton: My wish: Rebuilding Rwanda
author: Bill Clinton
title: My wish: Rebuilding Rwanda
description: Accepting the 2007 TED Prize, Bill Clinton asks for help in bringing health care to Rwanda -- and the rest of the world.

authortitle: Carl Honoré: In praise of slowness
author: Carl Honoré
title: In praise of slowness
description: Journalist Carl Honore believes the Western world's emphasis on speed erodes health, productivity and quality of life. But there's a backlash brewing, as everyday people start putting the brakes on their all-too-modern lives.

authortitle: Neil Gershenfeld: Unleash your creativity in a Fab Lab
author: Neil Gershenfeld
title: Unleash your creativity in a Fab Lab
description: MIT professor Neil Gershenfeld talks about his Fab Lab -- a low-cost lab that lets people build things they need using digital and analog tools. It's a simple idea with powerful results.

authortitle: Anna Deavere Smith: Four American characters
author: Anna Deavere Smith
title: Four American characters
description: Writer and actor Anna Deavere Smith gives life to author Studs Terkel, convict Paulette Jenkins, a Korean shopkeeper and a bull rider, excerpts from her solo show "On the Road: A Search for American Character."

authortitle: Steven Johnson: How the "ghost map" helped end a killer disease
author: Steven Johnson
title: How the "ghost map" helped end a killer disease
description: Author Steven Johnson takes us on a 10-minute tour of The Ghost Map, his book about a cholera outbreak in 1854 London and the impact it had on science, cities and modern society.

authortitle: Charles Leadbeater: The era of open innovation
author: Charles Leadbeater
title: The era of open innovation
description: In this deceptively casual talk, Charles Leadbeater weaves a tight argument  that innovation isn't just for professionals anymore. Passionate amateurs, using new tools, are creating products and paradigms that companies can't.

authortitle: Robert Wright: Progress is not a zero-sum game
author: Robert Wright
title: Progress is not a zero-sum game
description: Author Robert Wright explains "non-zero-sumness" -- the network of linked fortunes and cooperation that has guided our evolution to this point -- and how we can use it to help save humanity today.

authortitle: Martin Rees: Is this our final century?
author: Martin Rees
title: Is this our final century?
description: Speaking as both an astronomer and "a concerned member of the human race," Sir Martin Rees examines our planet and its future from a cosmic perspective. He urges action to prevent dark consequences from our scientific and technological development.

authortitle: Phil Borges: Photos of endangered cultures
author: Phil Borges
title: Photos of endangered cultures
description: Photographer Phil Borges shows rarely seen images of people from the mountains of Dharamsala, India, and the jungles of the Ecuadorean Amazon. In documenting these endangered cultures, he intends to help preserve them.

authortitle: Wade Davis: Dreams from endangered cultures
author: Wade Davis
title: Dreams from endangered cultures
description: With stunning photos and stories, National Geographic Explorer Wade Davis celebrates the extraordinary diversity of the world's indigenous cultures, which are disappearing from the planet at an alarming rate.

authortitle: Bjorn Lomborg: Global priorities bigger than climate change
author: Bjorn Lomborg
title: Global priorities bigger than climate change
description: Given $50 billion to spend, which would you solve first, AIDS or global warming? Danish political scientist Bjorn Lomborg comes up with surprising answers.

authortitle: Robert Neuwirth: The hidden world of shadow cities
author: Robert Neuwirth
title: The hidden world of shadow cities
description: Robert Neuwirth, author of "Shadow Cities," finds the world's squatter sites -- where a billion people now make their homes -- to be thriving centers of ingenuity and innovation. He takes us on a tour.

authortitle: Richard St. John: 8 secrets of success
author: Richard St. John
title: 8 secrets of success
description: Why do people succeed? Is it because they're smart? Or are they just lucky? Neither. Analyst Richard St. John condenses years of interviews into an unmissable 3-minute slideshow on the real secrets of success.

authortitle: Dean Ornish: The killer American diet that's sweeping the planet
author: Dean Ornish
title: The killer American diet that's sweeping the planet
description: Forget the latest disease in the news: Cardiovascular disease kills more people than everything else combined -- and it’s mostly preventable. Dr. Dean Ornish explains how changing our eating habits can save lives.

authortitle: Rives: If I controlled the Internet
author: Rives
title: If I controlled the Internet
description: How many poets could cram eBay, Friendster and Monster.com into 3-minute poem worthy of a standing ovation? Enjoy Rives' unique talent.

authortitle: Peter Gabriel: Fight injustice with raw video
author: Peter Gabriel
title: Fight injustice with raw video
description: Musician and activist Peter Gabriel shares his very personal motivation for standing up for human rights with the watchdog group WITNESS -- and tells stories of citizen journalists in action.

authortitle: Ray Kurzweil: The accelerating power of technology
author: Ray Kurzweil
title: The accelerating power of technology
description: Inventor, entrepreneur and visionary Ray Kurzweil explains in abundant, grounded detail why, by the 2020s, we will have reverse-engineered the human brain and nanobots will be operating your consciousness.

authortitle: Kevin Kelly: How technology evolves
author: Kevin Kelly
title: How technology evolves
description: Tech enthusiast Kevin Kelly asks "What does technology want?" and discovers that its movement toward ubiquity and complexity is much like the evolution of life.

authortitle: Michael Shermer: Why people believe weird things
author: Michael Shermer
title: Why people believe weird things
description: Why do people see the Virgin Mary on a cheese sandwich or hear demonic lyrics in "Stairway to Heaven"? Using video and music, skeptic Michael Shermer shows how we convince ourselves to believe -- and overlook the facts.

authortitle: Peter Donnelly: How juries are fooled by statistics
author: Peter Donnelly
title: How juries are fooled by statistics
description: Oxford mathematician Peter Donnelly reveals the common mistakes humans make in interpreting statistics -- and the devastating impact these errors can have on the outcome of criminal trials.

authortitle: Bono: My wish: Three actions for Africa
author: Bono
title: My wish: Three actions for Africa
description: Musician and activist Bono accepts the 2005 TED Prize with a riveting talk, arguing that aid to Africa isn't just another celebrity cause; it's a global emergency.

authortitle: Robert Fischell: My wish: Three unusual medical inventions
author: Robert Fischell
title: My wish: Three unusual medical inventions
description: Accepting his 2005 TED Prize, inventor Robert Fischell makes three wishes: redesigning a portable device that treats migraines, finding new cures for clinical depression and reforming the medical malpractice system.

authortitle: Edward Burtynsky: My wish: Manufactured landscapes and green education
author: Edward Burtynsky
title: My wish: Manufactured landscapes and green education
description: Accepting his 2005 TED Prize, photographer Edward Burtynsky makes a wish: that his images -- stunning landscapes that document humanity's impact on the world -- help persuade millions to join a global conversation on sustainability.

authortitle: Ben Saunders: Why did I ski to the North Pole?
author: Ben Saunders
title: Why did I ski to the North Pole?
description: Arctic explorer Ben Saunders recounts his harrowing solo ski trek to the North Pole, complete with engaging anecdotes, gorgeous photos and never-before-seen video.

authortitle: Burt Rutan: The real future of space exploration
author: Burt Rutan
title: The real future of space exploration
description: In this passionate talk, legendary spacecraft designer Burt Rutan lambasts the US government-funded space program for stagnating and asks entrepreneurs to pick up where NASA has left off.

authortitle: Ashraf Ghani: How to rebuild a broken state
author: Ashraf Ghani
title: How to rebuild a broken state
description: Ashraf Ghani's passionate and powerful 10-minute talk, emphasizing the necessity of both economic investment and design ingenuity to rebuild broken states, is followed by a conversation with TED curator Chris Anderson on the future of Afghanistan.

authortitle: Sasa Vucinic: Why we should invest in a free press
author: Sasa Vucinic
title: Why we should invest in a free press
description: A free press -- papers, magazines, radio, TV, blogs -- is the backbone of any true democracy (and a vital watchdog on business). Sasa Vucinic, a journalist from Belgrade, talks about his new fund, which supports media by selling "free press bonds."

authortitle: Iqbal Quadir: How mobile phones can fight poverty
author: Iqbal Quadir
title: How mobile phones can fight poverty
description: Iqbal Quadir tells how his experiences as a kid in poor Bangladesh, and later as a banker in New York, led him to start a mobile phone operator connecting 80 million rural Bangladeshi -- and to become a champion of bottom-up development.

authortitle: Jacqueline Novogratz: Invest in Africa's own solutions
author: Jacqueline Novogratz
title: Invest in Africa's own solutions
description: Jacqueline Novogratz applauds the world's heightened interest in Africa and poverty, but argues persuasively for a new approach.

authortitle: Aubrey de Grey: A roadmap to end aging
author: Aubrey de Grey
title: A roadmap to end aging
description: Cambridge researcher Aubrey de Grey argues that aging is merely a disease -- and a curable one at that. Humans age in seven basic ways, he says, all of which can be averted.

authortitle: Eva Vertes: Meet the future of cancer research
author: Eva Vertes
title: Meet the future of cancer research
description: Eva Vertes -- only 19 when she gave this talk -- discusses her journey toward studying medicine and her drive to understand the roots of cancer and Alzheimer’s.

authortitle: Dan Gilbert: The surprising science of happiness
author: Dan Gilbert
title: The surprising science of happiness
description: Dan Gilbert, author of "Stumbling on Happiness," challenges the idea that we’ll be miserable if we don’t get what we want. Our "psychological immune system" lets us feel truly happy even when things don’t go as planned.

authortitle: Barry Schwartz: The paradox of choice
author: Barry Schwartz
title: The paradox of choice
description: Psychologist Barry Schwartz takes aim at a central tenet of western societies: freedom of choice. In Schwartz's estimation, choice has made us not freer but more paralyzed, not happier but more dissatisfied.

authortitle: Malcolm Gladwell: Choice, happiness and spaghetti sauce
author: Malcolm Gladwell
title: Choice, happiness and spaghetti sauce
description: "Tipping Point" author Malcolm Gladwell gets inside the food industry's pursuit of the perfect spaghetti sauce -- and makes a larger argument about the nature of choice and happiness.

authortitle: Steven Levitt: The freakonomics of crack dealing
author: Steven Levitt
title: The freakonomics of crack dealing
description: "Freakonomics" author Steven Levitt presents new data on the finances of drug dealing. Contrary to popular myth, he says, being a street-corner crack dealer isn't lucrative: It pays below minimum wage. And your boss can kill you.

authortitle: David Deutsch: Chemical scum that dream of distant quasars
author: David Deutsch
title: Chemical scum that dream of distant quasars
description: Legendary scientist David Deutsch puts theoretical physics on the back burner to discuss a more urgent matter: the survival of our species. The first step toward solving global warming, he says, is to admit that we have a problem.

authortitle: Richard Dawkins: Why the universe seems so strange
author: Richard Dawkins
title: Why the universe seems so strange
description: Biologist Richard Dawkins makes a case for "thinking the improbable" by looking at how the human frame of reference limits our understanding of the universe.

authortitle: Alice Pailhès: Secrets of the mind and free will -- revealed by magic tricks
author: Alice Pailhès
title: Secrets of the mind and free will -- revealed by magic tricks

authortitle: Barry Schwartz: What role does luck play in your life?
author: Barry Schwartz
title: What role does luck play in your life?

authortitle: Liene Ozoliņa: Why do we blame individuals for economic crises?
author: Liene Ozoliņa
title: Why do we blame individuals for economic crises?

authortitle: Mark Robinson: A day in the life of an ancient Greek architect
author: Mark Robinson
title: A day in the life of an ancient Greek architect

authortitle: Kiah Williams: You shouldn't have to choose between filling your prescriptions and paying bills
author: Kiah Williams
title: You shouldn't have to choose between filling your prescriptions and paying bills

authortitle: Iseult Gillespie: The Japanese folktale of the selfish scholar
author: Iseult Gillespie
title: The Japanese folktale of the selfish scholar

authortitle: Keith Payne: The psychology of inequality and political division
author: Keith Payne
title: The psychology of inequality and political division

authortitle: Emily King: "Distance" / "Sides"
author: Emily King
title: "Distance" / "Sides"

author: Jacqueline Novogratz

author: Daniel L. Schacter

authortitle: Yaël Eisenstat: Dear Facebook, this is how you're breaking democracy
author: Yaël Eisenstat
title: Dear Facebook, this is how you're breaking democracy

author: Shameran Abed

author: Joseph Isaac

author: Christiane-Marie Abu Sarah

author: Dan Katz and Alex Rosenthal

author: Abigail Disney

author: Matt Walker

author: David Epstein

author: Noah R. Bressman

author: Riitta Ikonen and Karoline Hjorth

author: Wanda Irving
